PROCTEXT.PARA: Madam SPEAKER (Hon. Joan Child) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS AND EXCISE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1987

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 18 November, on motion by Mr Barry Jones:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition seeks to delay the passage of the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987 until the autumn session to give customs agents and industry time to make appropriate representations. If we are unsuccessful in doing so, we will move amendments at the committee stage. The Bill seeks to reintroduce some provisions of the Customs Act which were deleted in a Bill in June. I refer to section 163 which allows the making of a regulation specifying the time in which applications for refunds, rebates and remissions of duty can be made, effectively imposing a fee of $200 on such applications. The Government is seeking to reintroduce the penalty by deleting the safety we had added in the June amendments. It is a difficult problem for importers and agents, who will be penalised where overpayments are made in reasonable commercial circumstances. It would be far better if the time of application had been set in the Act as is proposed for the recovery of short pay duty.

SPEECH.PARA: We also have an argument with the $200 fee. I raise that as the first item because the President of the Customs Agents Federation of Australia, Athol Flynn, states in a letter:

The current legislation re-introduces the abhorrent penalty conditions for lodgement of refund application, which was subject to our concern when introduced to Parliament in July. You will recall a successful amendment was moved in the Senate to make these conditions more realistic.
We do not believe importers or agents should be penalised where over payments are made in reasonable commercial circumstances.

This Bill indicates an acceptance that the agents themselves are put in the inappropriate position of making false entries and yet are adjudged in some respects to be guilty of misadventure without a reasonable position being taken. I have been advised-and from what I have seen of customs agents this is so-that customs agents have to declare goods both from ships and airports in a relatively quick time. At the point of entry the process of documentation and classification can be difficult. Honourable members would no doubt all be aware that on the importation of certain goods the bill of lading, and the documents associated with the items, have to be entered with the Australian Customs Service and the appropriate entry has to distinguish the classification. The classifications for entry of any range of goods can vary enormously up and down the scale. They are directly related to making a judgment, particularly in some areas dealing with aircraft. In other areas a classification under one item can produce a very different result, in terms of duty payable, to a classification under another item when the article is essentially the same. As a consequence, proposed section 163, in relation to refunds, on the face of it imposes an unreal expectation of commercial reality at the time.

The second area which we ask the Government to pay attention to is proposed section 165, under the heading in the Bill of `Short paid duty . . .'. The existing legislation allows for the short payment of duty to be collected retrospectively for a period of one year unless fraud is involved, in which case no time limit applies. The intention in this Bill is to extend that period to three years in relation to overpayments. That means, as the Minister for Science and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) would be well aware, that, in the case of overpayments, claims can be made only for up to one year, and in the case of underpayments, as proposed new section 165 (a) (1) (b), claims can be made retrospectively for up to three years. This is inconsistent. Apparently it is good enough for someone to claim an overpayment only within one year, but it is good enough for others to claim for a short payment within three years. I think it is probably well known that the Opposition will not support retrospective charges, be they taxes or charges imposed in this way. It seems that there is an undue weight there towards the payment area.

On the assumption that the Bill will be passed, the ability to collect retrospectively for three years means that the agent, and therefore the importer and subsequently the retailer, or the final user, is liable to pay three years tax. Can the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) expect that customers or even retailers in his electorate would be able to retrieve duty paid on an import three years after they had bought it? Not even the honourable member would be able to find that particular sum at that time. If the honourable member for Calwell could not find it, I doubt very much whether any citizen of Australia would be able to trace that figure around for that length of time.

The third aspect we mention relates to proposed section 243t. The Minister, being meticulous in his detail, will no doubt recall readily that this section means that it is intended that penalties be imposed on customs agents for lodging incorrect customs entries. These penalties will be set at twice the amount of duty concerned, whether the agent makes the error `knowingly, recklessly or otherwise'. The Minister would not do things like that, and I am quite sure that as a consequence of that, no reasonable agent would make claims under those headings, which then gives the Department of Science and Small Business the right to impose penalties under circumstances which are a bit hard to follow.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is 243t?

—Section 243t; it is intended that the penalties imposed on the customs agents for lodging incorrect customs entries will be set at twice the amount of duty concerned, whether he makes the error `knowingly, recklessly or otherwise'. I quote from the Executive Director's letter:

SPEECH.PARA: While the Bill provides for the Collector and Comptroller to have some flexibility in these matters, a capricious act of a Collector could cost a Customs Agent in excess of a million dollars for perhaps an incorrect decimal point which would undoubtedly be discovered and corrected before the duty was proffered.
Even in less dramatic circumstances a penalty of $50,000 for a simple error could bankrupt a Customs agent.

It is suggested that this is similar to legislation to cover Tax Agents. It should be noted in the first instance, Tax Agents have some months to prepare tax returns while Customs Agents are pressed by the Customs system to present customs entries within hours.

I am aware from past experience that sometimes customs agents are not up to the line in presenting their papers as quickly as the member for Calwell would. As a consequence, when they present their papers the Customs office has a limited time to process the paper and get the goods cleared from the airport or wharf. All these matters, to my mind, have never been a one-way street. A lot of blame has flowed to the Customs office which is not appropriate. I say that because of my high regard for the Customs office over many years. I suspect, from a reading of the letter from the Customs Agents Federation and having some knowledge, imperfect as it might be, of the processes of Customs, that there is a half-way house.

Because of those circumstances the Opposition seeks to defer this Bill until the autumn sittings so that some further consultation can be had with the agents who have represented to me and to other Opposition spokesmen in this area that the actions in sections 243t, 165 and 163 have been introduced quickly with inappropriate consultation. In respect of section 243t, the analogy drawn between the ability of the tax agents and the customs agents is worth considering. The Executive Director points out in his letter:
Secondly Tax Agents are able to overcome this obstacle-
that is, the obstacle of correctness, and therefore passing on the obligation-

by sending returns to taxpayers to sign. This not only takes away the responsibility but also provides the opportunity for the taxpayer to check the calculations. Customs Agents would love this luxury.

I do not shrink from the responsibility of the customs agents; they have a responsibility to be accurate. But the agents represent to me that in the time frame of getting the documentation and in view of the necessity to clear the goods from airport or wharf to meet customer demands speed is important. In view of commercial reality, sometimes mistakes will be made and as a consequence agents should not be subject to such a wide bracketing as `knowingly, recklessly or otherwise', and therefore open to penalty. There is no excuse for sloppy paperwork. At the same time, there has to be a commercial reality about it all. I continue to quote from the Executive Director's letter:

If this legislation is introduced obviously Customs Agents would follow the example of Tax Agents and insist on customs entries being sent first to importers for signature and checking, before lodgment.

If this comes about the entire waterfront and airport system will choke with cargo and all the proposed electronic systems for early lodgement of import information and speedier clearance can be forgotten.
Customs Agents are anxious to support more modern systems but not those where the Australian Customs Service simply abrogates its responsibilities and loads these onto the public sector.

The more I read the letter and the paper provided by Athol Flynn, who is known to me, the more it seems that the course proposed by the Opposition is correct-that this Bill should be deferred until the autumn session. If we do that, the operators in the area and the Australian Customs Service who, over many years, have had a very good relationship, can get together and sort out the most appropriate response to this matter.

Only a month ago I attended the annual dinner of the Customs Agents Federation, with the Comptroller-General of Customs and his deputy, Mr Frank Kelly, both of whom are well known to me. At that stage it seems that there was a great deal of agreement on all the approaches being made and the outcome of that night was particularly satisfactory. Therefore, it came as some surprise to me to receive this letter from Athol Flynn relating to this legislation, in which he claimed that there had been inadequate correspondence and contact. I hope that this can be overcome. By accepting the Opposition's proposition that this legislation be deferred until the new year and adequate consultation carried out, the Government will ensure that all parties are satisfied and happy with the outcome.

Nothing proposed in the legislation is to the detriment of revenue and there is nothing in the Opposition's proposals which would impinge upon efficiency within the area-either the agents or the Australian Customs Service. The agents are seeking consultation because of their regard for what they see as the particular penalties in this area. Because of that I intend to move the second reading amendment, the text of which has been circulated in my name. I move:
That all words after `that' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
`the House is of the opinion that the Bill should not be proceeded with until customs agents and the industry have had sufficient time to make appropriate representations in relation to the Bill'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) is the second instalment of the Government's strategy to combat commercial practices designed solely or predominantly to understate the value of imported goods in order to minimise or avoid Customs duty. This Bill is long overdue. For many years we have had, amongst customs agents and importers, practices which have understated the value of goods and have avoided duty. This situation became absolutely rampant during the last couple of years of the Fraser Government when imports poured into this country at an unprecedented rate. At that time we had statements from the now Senator Stone and others that more imports were good for Australia-that we should keep bringing in more and more imports. Nothing was done to regularise this process and to ensure that the duties and tariffs that were supposed to be paid were actually paid because a number of practices developed over this period for the understatement of the real value of the goods.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) seeks to protect the situation of the customs agents as though what the Government is proposing is somehow unreasonable. I put it to him that the Government has been very reasonable in the way in which it has treated the customs agents and their requests. The agents came to the Government with a request that a quick clearance method for imported goods be introduced. The new system that has been introduced is such that the customs agents have to rely on the statements made by the importers being true. Each importer states what he claims to be the value of the goods.

It is quite unreasonable for the customs agents to say, as they are saying, on the one hand, `We want quick clearance. We do not want anything held up. We want these goods to go through on the basis of a statement by the agents', and, on the other hand, to say, `But, of course, we should also restrict the capacity of the Australian Customs Service to check back to see whether those statements are correct and that the importers have not understated the value of goods and thereby avoided duty'. That is why we reject the proposal by the honourable member for Ryan for a reduction from three years to one year. With the greatest of respect to him, his argument was a foolish one. He said that the customer, the retailer, the wholesaler, and whoever is involved, would be responsible after three years. That is not correct. Under proposed new section 243t, the person who made the statement will be liable. If, after three years, two years or one year, it is discovered that that person made a false statement to Customs, that person will be liable, not the customer who received the end good; good luck to the receiver. Therefore, with the greatest of respect to the honourable member for Ryan, his argument is not correct. I could have said something else about it, but it is certainly not correct. Indeed, it is a bit foolish in this context.

There are very good reasons for retaining a three-year rule because it may take that amount of time for information to come to Customs about shonky practices on the part of some importers. I put it to the honourable member for Ryan that this proposal is not unfair to the customs agents. It is a fair proposal, especially given that changes have been made to ensure quick clearance, which is what the agents and importers wanted. I do not know what the honourable member for Ryan is seeking in wanting to make these changes, except that he may have been a bit over-influenced by the submissions of the Customs Agents Federation of Australia. Obviously, everyone wants to minimise their difficulties and to have it both ways. But the customs agents cannot have it both ways. If they want quick clearances, they will have to allow for the possibility of examination after the event to ensure that, if there have been understatements, there will be penalties. In this sort of process one is relying on the honesty of the people concerned.

As I have said, this is not a light matter. If people are able to import goods, understate their value and pay less duty, they are then in a much better position, competitively, than Australian manufacturers and producers. In this current economic climate, when we are trying to increase import substitution and get more Australian industries to compete with imports by manufacturing here, it is not fair that our industries should have to compete in an unfair way with shonky practices on the part of importers. Surely the honourable member for Ryan accepts that. In that context, the submissions of the Government are entirely reasonable and fair. As I said at the outset, there is no reason to delay the Bill further. Indeed, on the contrary, I would argue that the Bill is overdue and that we ought to institute these processes and ensure that importers and customs agents who are not following the rules or who have perhaps-especially, as I said, during the period of the Fraser Government-taken the view that they can virtually declare almost any value that they like for goods and pay whatever duty they wish are brought into line. That situation must and will change.

It is estimated that, in the last year alone, $146m of duty-that is a conservative estimate; I would say it was much higher than that-was lost to the Commonwealth from the understatement of values by importers and customs agents. In that context, therefore, this undervaluation must be challenged, and it will be challenged under this Bill whose clauses are important for achieving the situation that the Government wants. I have already answered the other argument presented by the honourable member for Ryan about some amendments to the various clauses-in particular, the one concerning the three years. Matters concerning a couple of other clauses will be answered by the Minister. But, in general terms, we believe this to be an important Bill.

I want to address the claim by the Customs Agents Federation of Australia that it was not sufficiently consulted. I point out that this is the second part of these changes and since the beginning of the year the Federation and other importers have been on notice that these changes were coming through; so I do not know where the honourable member for Ryan gets the idea that customs agents were not sufficiently consulted. They have known since the beginning of the year--

TALK.START.PARA: —I will show you the letter.

—I am sure that statement is made in the letter, but the fact of the matter is that these changes have been notified since the beginning of the year, and the first set of them went through this Parliament earlier in the year, so I do not know how the Federation is now saying that its members believed these changes would not come through this year. Indeed, we are right at the end of the year, so they have had virtually the whole of the year to make representations in relation to these matters. Representations are one thing, but getting everything that one wants is another. Even if the customs agents had had a much longer period in which to make representations, they would not have been satisfied. I put it to the Federation and to other importers that this is a fair set of measures.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Ryan mentioned that the $50,000 penalty could bankrupt some agents. Indeed, it could, but nobody will be bankrupted who has not deliberately gone out of his way to understate the value of goods and therefore to avoid duty. People who have not deliberately set out to do that or who have not done so in an entirely reckless manner will not be penalised, so I do not know why the honourable member for Ryan should seek to protect people who engage in shonky practices. As I said before, this is not a small matter of just catching some tax avoiders. It is a matter that has an impact on our domestic production because people who are understating their duty and are not paying enough duty on those imported goods are thus in a position to compete unfairly with Australian production, and Australian producers are unable to compete with them on fair terms.

Australia wants increased manufacturing production. If that is to be the case, we are not going to say to importers that they cannot import, but we are saying to them that they must import on fair terms and not on shonky terms, terms on which they are avoiding duty and which allow them to price goods in a way that undermines the Australian market-place and Australian production. Madam Speaker, I support the Bill. I do not think the honourable member for Ryan has given us any reason to delay the Bill. Indeed, I think it is important for the Bill to go through and for us to eradicate these shonky practices.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BARRY JONES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Small Business)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, first of all, on behalf of members of the House, I am pleased to see you back after your recent indisposition.
—Thank you.
—I was hoping the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) would have gone on for a few more minutes, but he has obviously felt a call to be elsewhere.

SPEECH.PARA: I wanted to respond to the points made by the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) and to indicate why we reject his amendment. Closing loopholes has to be seen in the broad context of the Government's reforms of revenue laws generally over the last five years to curb evasion and avoidance.

I was a little surprised by Mr Athol Flynn's letter of 23 November to me, quoted by the honourable member for Ryan, which suggested somehow that the proposals in this Bill had been sprung on him. That is simply not correct. The Bill follows inexorably from the Customs (Valuation) Amendment Bill 1987. It is reasonable to say that fair notice of this proposed legislation was given then. If I may quote myself briefly from that debate recorded on pages 2200 and 2201 of Weekly Hansard of 29 April 1987 where I said:

The measures in this Bill are the first stage of the Government's two-pronged legislative attack against certain avoidance and minimisation practices used by importers in valuing goods imported into Australia.
I further said that the matter has been the subject of:
a comprehensive examination of the effectiveness of the valuation provisions in the Customs Act. That examination has brought to light a number of apparent loopholes . . .
I also said:

. . . we have decided to correct the inadequacies in the Act that have been revealed to date. Because of the complexity of some of the arrangements, it is necessary that the amendments be done in two stages.
The first stage is covered by this Bill. We expect to introduce the second stage during the next sittings of the parliament.
Then, leaving out a few paragraphs of my deathless prose--

TALK.START.PARA: —It was so good, too.
—Yes, and very characteristic of me. I went on:

SPEECH.PARA: As indicated earlier, I give notice that the examination of valuation legislation is continuing and, as a second stage in the Government's strategy, we intend to introduce further amendments in the Budget sittings this year to eliminate any opportunity for avoidance or minimisation of the value of imported goods.

That was a reasonable indication of what we intended. The implication in Mr Flynn's letter on behalf of the Customs Agents Federation of Australia is that the Federation only found out about the legislation last week. That is not correct. This has been part of the continuing process, and it is not intended to apply the new proposed legislation in an arbitrary or capricious fashion. No doubt it will take some time for the system to work in.

I take the point made by the honourable member for Ryan that there is always a conflict between wanting to finish customs transactions very quickly and to put goods in the hands of importers. Of course, the pressure to speed up the process imposes additional obligations on the customs agents to get the paper work correct. I repeat to the House and the Customs Agents Federation of Australia that the measure will not be imposed in an arbitrary or capricious way. Ample notice of the Commonwealth's intention has been given.

Since this matter was dealt with by the honourable member for Ryan in his speech on the second reading, I will say just a few words about the Opposition's objections to sections 163 and 165. Amendments to section 163 relating to refund, rebate or remission of the duty provision in the Act make some minor changes to the exemption circumstances for the payment of the $200 fee, for the processing of refund applications and the like, introduced last sittings as a cost recovery measure only for the anticipated number of applications lodged, which was in excess of 30,000.

Honourable members will recall that the Government proposed certain exemptions from the payment of the fee, that is, in circumstances essentially where the overpayment of duty was through no fault of the importer or where the Australian Customs Service made an error. Where the Customs preferred option was to prescribe the exemption circumstances by regulation, on the grounds that the exemptions were of an administrative nature and the Customs regulations already carried the administrative provisions concerning refunds of duty in five regulations, we accepted the Opposition amend- ments made in the Senate last sittings-what else could we do?-to place the exemption circumstances into the Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is like Hawke and privatisation.

—Or the Queensland Premier. It should be remembered that the provisions inserted in the Act allowed for the prescription of further exemption circumstances by regulation. This was done on 16 October this year by statutory rules No. 244 of 1987 which prescribed three additional circumstances, again where an overpayment was made through no fault of the importer, where the refund application fee would not be payable.

SPEECH.PARA: However, the proposed amendment removes two exemption circumstances introduced by the Senate amendments last sittings, which were so broad and vague that, in practice, they could virtually make the imposition of the fee, in most circumstances, impossible. The Government accepts that there are legitimate circumstances in which an exemption from the proposed $200 fee should apply, but it also believes that these circumstances should be carefully worded so as not inadvertently to create a loophole which could effectively be used to avoid the intent of the fee in the first place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Give 165 a run now.

—I have just remembered the central point about section 165. The amendment, which will be moved in the committee stage, proposes to limit the time within which Customs might recover duties short paid or erroneously refunded to the same time period which applies where an applicant for a refund applies for such a refund, that is, 12 months after the duty is paid. This argument misses the essential point that the applicant for a refund and the persons who supply information to Customs on which it then values goods are the custodians of the information on which the duty can then be assessed. They have the information; Customs has not. It is quite consistent with other legislation, notably the bounty legislation, that when a claim--
—Customs has the papers.

—Of course, but, in a sense, the papers are produced by and through the agents. In terms of access to knowledge, Customs is not on level ground. If claims are to be made on the Commonwealth, they should be made within a reasonable administrative time. We think that 12 months is quite consistent with precedents. However, it is quite another question to consider how much time should be allowed for the authorities to recover money or duty short paid. Often Customs investigations take in excess of 12 months to reveal a shortfall in duty paid. It is, therefore, quite appropriate to be able to protect the revenue for longer than a period of just 12 months.

SPEECH.PARA: I note the point made by the honourable member for Ryan about the penalty for making false statements, which relates to an amendment to section 243t of the original Act. He is concerned that the penalty is imposed whether the false information is made `knowingly, recklessly or otherwise'. He feels that that is far too broad. I note that the penalty requirement says:

. . . the collector may, by notice in writing served on the person who pays or paid the duty, require that person to pay, within a period of 60 days after service of the notice, a penalty equal to twice the amount of the excess, or a penalty of $20-
which does not sound too draconian-
whichever is the greater.

Obviously if only very tiny amounts were involved in the misleading statement-for example, if there were a short payment of $2-it would really be a question of whether it was worth taking action for that very small amount.

In respect of proposed new section 243t in this legislation, as in all other revenue legislation, the provisions setting up offences are drawn fairly widely. The phrase `or otherwise', of course, is a drag-all phrase. But I have already given the undertaking that, within the Australian Customs Service, it will not be applied in a capricious or arbitrary way. We have no desire to block up the system. I would be very much concerned if what Mr Flynn is suggesting actually occurred-that the process of clearing goods through customs will be slowed down considerably to avoid any accidental misinformation. That obviously has to be monitored. I assure honourable members that the Customs people will be looking at the matter responsibly. I thank the honourable member for Ryan for his contribution and the honourable member for Calwell who played to a packed House on this matter. I commend the Bill to the House.
Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
