TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 14, page 43, lines 6-13, omit paragraph (a), substitute the following paragraph:
``(a) by omitting subsection (1a) and substitu- ting the following subsections:

`(1A) Without limiting the scope of paragraph (1) (b), the regulations may prescribe the amount, or the means of determining the amount, of any refund, rebate or remission of duty that may be made for the purposes of subsection (1).
`(1ab) A refund, rebate or remission is not payable under subsection (1) unless application for the refund, rebate or remission is made within 1 year after the payment of the duty.';''.
(2) Clause 14, page 43, lines 14 and 15, omit paragraphs (b) and (c), substitute the following word and paragraph:
``and (b) by omitting subsections (1c) and (1d).''.
(3) Clause 16, page 43, line 30, omit ``3 years'', substitute ``1 year''.
(4) Clause 26, page 49, line 28, omit ``, whether knowingly, recklessly or otherwise'', substitute ``knowingly or recklessly''.
(5) Clause 26, page 50, lines 17 and 18, omit proposed paragraph 243u (2) (a).

My amendments relate to the clauses amending section 163 and section 165 of the principal Act and proposed new section 243t. I point out that nothing that the Minister for Science and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) has said has any effect in relation to the area that I have described as consultation. We should bear in mind that with anything to do with government regulation in the market-place-including the processing of paper and the clearance of goods-everybody will gain if adequate consultation takes place and everybody knows where he is. The Minister said in a previous speech `fair notice'. `Reasonable indication' was another term he used. That is fine. That was a speech made many years ago. Surprisingly, people working in commerce do not read Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —This was in April of this year.

—Yes, but those people do not read Hansard. It is not one of those things that they take down off the shelf every night. Unless the people who are operating out in the market-place are contacted directly through their association or whatever, they will not know about these provisions. To quote the words `reasonable indication' or `fair notice' from Hansard is just nonsense, with due respect, to use the words of the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous). Consequently, I urge the Minister to hold the appropriate discussions and consultations. Everything will work much better, nerves will not be so frayed and even privatisation might get through if those discussions are held as the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) urges. I have to say that I am disappointed that the Minister does not accept that advice. If he did he might find the passage of this legislation much easier.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Calwell said that the Opposition is defending shonky practices. We are not defending shonky practices. I am sure that the honourable member was taking liberties when he said that. Quite clearly we are indicating that everyone should follow the law and that if agents or importers are breaking the law it is the right and the obligation of the Customs officers to pursue a certain course. If they are failing in that pursuit they should have more staff, more services and a better computer system-we have spent an enormous amount of money on computers-to be able to carry out those obligations. So to attempt to associate the Opposition with shonky practices is a nonsense. I am sure the honourable member for Calwell now thinks that was an unnecessary thing to say. I think the three proposed amendments reach the heart of the matter. They get around consultation. If consultation had occurred I am sure the amendments would not have been necessary.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BARRY JONES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Small Business)

TALK.START.PARA: —I outlined in broad terms some of the reasons the Government would be rejecting the amendments when I responded to the second reading debate. I will restate a couple of points. I take the point that, regrettably, Hansard is not by every bedside reading lamp-would that it were-and therefore sometimes people miss things. But I think professional associations-especially assiduous ones such as the Customs Agents Federation of Australia-do follow the Hansard debates.

SPEECH.PARA: In the broad context of our attempting to protect the revenue, ever since the Government came into office, we try to make the taxation law more certain, more uniform and less full of the anomalies and exceptions that were in the revenue laws when we came into office. The Federation would have been very well aware of the April 1987 legislation. That is something it has lived under since its legislation's proclamation. I think it would also have been aware that that Act was just one part of a two-part procedure of which it had a fair degree of understanding. There was a similarly vigorous but well-mannered debate between the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) and me at that time.

I turn to clause 16 of the Bill which deals with proposed new section 165. The provisions in that clause are exactly comparable to section 170aa of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936. It is an application of the well recognised principles in tax law to customs legislation. I refer to the explanatory memorandum which, concerning proposed new section 243t, states:

new s243t inserts a new automatic penalty provision which provides that where a person makes a statement to an officer which is false or misleading in a material particular, or omits from a statement any matter without which the statement is misleading in a material particular, and as a result the amount of duty properly payable on goods is more than what is or has been paid on the goods, the Collector may issue a notice requiring the person who pays or paid the duty to pay within 60 days a penalty of an amount of twice the amount of the difference between the amount of duty actually paid and the amount of duty actually owed new subsection (1). Should a person fail to pay the amount, the amount becomes a debt due to the Commonwealth and may be recovered in a Court of competent jurisdiction (new subsection (2)).
It is not entirely confined to an administrative act within the Customs Service. It can be referred to a court. The explanatory memorandum continues:

new subsection 243T(3) provides that where a Collector has served a notice on a person under this subsection, the Customs Service is precluded from prosecuting the same person for making the same misstatement or omission under section 234 of the Principal Act . . .

This provision provides another sanction against those persons who have paid less than the amount of duty that is owed to the Customs, and is similar to the automatic penalty provisions contained in taxation legislation (see section 233 of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936).

In addition to the principal Act concerning goods being forfeited, and so on, the goods will cease to be forfeited to the Crown on the payment of the penalty. The explanatory memorandum for proposed new section 243v states:

This concession acknowledges that one of the attractions of the automatic penalty system is that a penalty duty may be paid, but one's goods are not forfeited and seized, as could happen if a prosecution for an offence under section 234 and the forfeiture section 229 were allowed to run.

In a sense we have both a regularisation and, it is fair to say, a liberalisation. I conclude with a point that was restated by the honourable member for Ryan. It would be common ground that the system will not work on a basis of confrontation, with the Customs Service on one side of the wharf, with pistols drawn, and the Customs agents, determined to prevent the operation of the law, on the other. If that happened, of course, the situation would be intolerable and would slow the process down quite unacceptably. The new law can work only if there is perfect understanding on both sides. The Opposition would be well aware that under the enlightened regime of the Australian Customs Service at the moment-I think it was all right a few years ago when the honourable member for Ryan was there but it is even better now-there is no desire to gum up the works. We want the system to work properly. That depends on a proper flow of information, a fair degree of consultation and an understanding of what is going on.
Amendments negatived.
Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Mr Barry Jones)-by leave-read a third time.
Debate resumed from 18 November, on motion by Mrs Kelly:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: White Mr P.N.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Williamstown Dockyard Employees Bill 1987 sets out to ensure that if and when the Williamstown Naval Dockyard is sold to private enterprise the employees, who are currently there, will not be disadvantaged. We do not oppose the Bill in any way. It makes not an unpleasant change to come into this House to find that we agree with the Government on a defence matter. The Bill is to look after the employees who are there. It is all very well for the Government to go out of its way to make equitable arrangements for employees who are basically trade unionists at the instigation of the trade unions, but what about the 70,000 men and women who are in the forces who do not have a trade union to speak for them? What about their pay and conditions which have been slowly eroded by this Government over the last five years to the point where there is an enormous wastage rate in the Services? People are leaving in droves almost every day.

SPEECH.PARA: Apart from the fact that the Government will not release the wastage figures, the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly) put out guidelines to the Services about service spouses. They are being muzzled as well. They cannot do this: they cannot do that; they have to conform. One must ask whether such guidelines are ever issued by the Government when it meets with union members or their spouses. So why is the Government imposing military regulations on Service spouses? Is this an attempt to muzzle them, to stop them talking about the poor conditions of service that are applying to the uniformed defence forces of this country?

It is interesting that, according to the Minister's second reading speech, long negotiations have taken place and there has been `an exhaustive program of consultation'. The unions have apparently given the okay to what the Government is doing, so that is all right, it can go through! But I make the point that the uniformed personnel have no unions to speak for them. In recent years we have seen the misplacement of the Defence Force Remuneration Tribunal and the Defence Force Advocate and the opposition by the Government to every reasonable application for pay and conditions by the defence forces. The salaries of the Defence Force personnel are seriously out of kilter. In many cases the junior ranks are getting more than their senior officers because of various anomalies and allowances in pay.

The Defence Force retirement and death benefit 2 per cent discount is a disgrace. The defence service housing problems have almost caused riots around the country, and the Government's Caucus is in disarray on this matter. The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel is now seeking to muzzle the service wives. The relationship, or the comparison between what is happening to the unions, who have been looked after in this Bill, and what is not happening to uniformed servicemen and their wives is a disgrace.

We have to ask why the Williamstown Naval Dockyard is being privatised-a matter with which we agree. From the statement of the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley)-I welcome the Minister to the House, after his return from overseas-it is clear that the dockyard's `performance has continued to fall short of the yard's own commitments, and even further behind what might be expected from comparable yards'. That is quite true. I visited Williamstown yesterday, and from discussions I had with various people there, and from my own observations, it seems to me that there is only one thing to do if we are to make Williamstown a viable part of Australia's shipbuilding industry, and that is to privatise it. It is interesting that the Government took this decision-the decision was taken earlier this year-before the current debate on privatisation hotted up. I ask the Minister how he would like to be taking this to his Caucus now, in the current climate, and trying to get it through with the hostility that is there to privatisation.

TALK.START.PARA: —They would get overwhelming support, as they always do.

—Why do the proposals that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is taking to Caucus not get overwhelming support? We are talking about the principle of privatisation, are we not? How come the Prime Minister is now in such turmoil with his privatisation proposals? It is interesting to see the Government's approach to privatisation before its conversion this year. In May 1985 the Treasurer (Mr Keating) said:

SPEECH.PARA: No matter where one looks, whether it be at TAA or the other authorities, there is no case for the Opposition's argument in economics, except simply to indulge ideologically in a Thatcherite, vandalistic splurge to try and destroy these authorities.

All the sensible things that we have been saying about privatisation for some time and the sensible approach that the Government is now taking to the privatisation of the Williamstown Dockyard are not the things that the Government was saying last year and the year before. That is a quote from the Government's own Treasurer. Let us turn to some of the offers. The Treasurer said:

The Labor Party will fight tooth and nail to keep these public authorities in the hands of the Commonwealth. We are about refurbishing them and keeping them strong. We are not about wrecking them and selling them. The great public services they provide will continue to be provided while ever this Government has the breath to defend them.

That is the Treasurer, the Government's spokesman on economic matters, and here we have a Bill privatising one of these great public authorities. There has been a great conversion along the way. On 21 July 1985, the Prime Minister said that privatisation:
. . . is a one-off fire sale, a sale of the century, of your assets-the assets of the people of Australia.
They would transfer them into the hands of a privileged few, to the cost of every one of us.
The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden), in August 1985 said:

. . . when the economic Moonies attack public enterprise, they are really blowing smoke over their real target: that public resources should be preserved for the greater cause of the private interests they represent . . . In Labor's heartlands, the people are not stupid. They understand who the interests are who stand in the way of Labor's objective.
The then Minister for Transport, the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris), said:
Those who talk about privatisation really are trotting out a very tired old piece of ideology which has been around for a long time . . .
He continued:
There is one way to summarise all this talk about privatisation. Privatisation is really the supreme con-job.

TALK.START.PARA: -Order! I take it that the honourable member is dealing with the principles that he assumes are behind the sale of the Williamstown Dockyard. It might help if he did relate his remarks, at least in passing, to the sale of the Williamstown Dockyard.

—There will be plenty of remarks about the Williamstown Dockyard, Mr Deputy Speaker, and I take the point. The sale of the Williamstown Dockyard is a very important milestone in the ideology of the Government.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a quick point of order. I assume, from your ruling, that we will be allowed to respond in a reasonable fashion.

—I drew the honourable member's attention to what the Bill was about, and asked him to relate his remarks to the Bill. It is not within my mind what other members may say, and I will take them up on that if necessary as the time arises.

—I have one last quote on this issue, because it is an important issue. We are talking here about the sale to private enterprise of a dockyard that has been in existence for, I think, 130 or 140 years. It has been a public institution. The Government has come to the conclusion that it would be better off in the hands of private enterprise, and we agree with that. But it is a strange decision in view of Australian Labor Party history. It is also a very strange decision when we look at the great furore that it is causing within the Government at the moment. I finish with this quote from the Prime Minister on 24 September 1985:

SPEECH.PARA: Our opponents would sell off institutions which have been built up over generations. They should be left to serve our children as well as they have served our parents.

One could go on and on, but I will not continue in view of the request from the Chair. The fact is that every statement, until recently, has been totally opposed to privatisation. The Government, very sensibly, came to the conclusion earlier this year that the Williamstown Dockyard should be privatised, sold to private enterprise, but that sits strangely with previous statements made from the Prime Minister down-not the Minister, as far as I can determine-as to why all these public institutions should not be privatised. The question is: Why is this dockyard to be sold? There is no doubt that it is consuming a great deal of public funds and it is wasting a great deal of money. It cannot compete in the private sector. It has been plagued with union problems and with poor management for years, with inefficient work practices, single shifts and union intransigence, and it is overmanned.

One of the problems of the Williamstown Dockyard right now flowed from the decision in 1973 by the then Labor Government not to proceed with the DDL projects, but not to reduce the work force. It would appear that, although the yard had no shipbuilding program and relied on refit and maintenance from that period, and although the Minister of the day declined to go ahead with the shipbuilding program, he gave assurances that there would be no reduction in the work force. Since that time about 2,000 employees have been located at Williamstown, the justification for whose existence in many cases has been difficult to arrive at.

For all those reasons it is important that this be put on a commercial footing. But, above all, it would appear that the big problem in making Williamstown efficient is simply the inertia and the dead hand of the bureaucracy. It has stifled and removed any initiative that might be displayed in this old and historic dockyard. In some cases it has taken up to nine months to get materials into that dockyard, when a commercial dockyard would simply get on the telephone and order those items. Because of the tendering system and the long bureaucratic process, it has taken as long as nine months to get material. Is it any wonder when one visits Williamstown that one finds sections there waiting for another section to process the material to pass something on. Wherever one goes in Williamstown one sees people standing around staring into space, waiting for the flow of material to come to pass-which it does not. That is a result of the long, cumbersome ordering procedures.

It is also difficult to sack anyone. It is even more difficult in some circumstances to recruit. No wonder people have lost heart in the ability of Williamstown Dockyard to compete. On my visit yesterday I could sense the attitude, `Why should I care? If they cannot get their act together, if they cannot give me materials with which to ply my trade, why should I bother? It's not my responsibility'. As a public enterprise, it has proved hopeless.

It is interesting to examine the position of the unions in the proposal to sell off Williamstown naval dockyard. So far as I can determine, apart from some ritualistic opposition, the unions have agreed to go along with it. That is true not only of the union leadership but of the unionists themselves. They recognise the problems that have been inherent in this dockyard for many years. I think that they will be grateful for a new start, a chance to compete, to take pride again in their work and to get a reasonable flow of work through the dockyard. They see a better future, it seems to me, under private enterprise, and that is a heartening sign. In terms of the future of Williamstown and the future of the unionists and the unions in general, it will be up to them to work with management-one hopes a vastly improved management-to see that the dockyard performs. There will be no government protection from now on. It will be a case of perform or go under.

I wish to make a few comments on the two FFG frigates which are being built at the yard, to bring the total number to six. The first should be out of that dockyard in 1991 and the second in 1993. I shall be interested, as will many other people, to see the final cost of these frigates compared with the other four that were purchased from the United States of America. I understand that there was a factor built in when the estimates were done because it is a long time since we built frigates in Australia, and I think that is fair enough. How much fat should be allowed is another matter. It will be a test of Williamstown under private enterprise to see whether it can get rid of some inefficient work practices which have plagued the dockyard and whether it can produce the frigates on time and on cost. It will be a chance to see whether the vessels built at the dockyard compare favourably with frigates which traditionally for a number of years have been bought overseas. Because that is part of the new contract, whoever takes over the dockyard will have to finish the frigates. Therefore, the dockyard will have an opportunity to improve its techniques and learning curve before it embarks on what I hope will be its next project, the Anzac frigate project.

Let me say a few words about the Anzac frigate project. Many people are having serious doubts about how far the project will proceed. We support the project in general. I think that the New Zealanders are still far from the barrier. They have indicated general support, but one of the problems is that if the project is too expensive they will be tempted to go elsewhere. It is in our interests to have the New Zealanders in, of course. I am concerned to know whether, with the ceiling placed on these frigates-and perhaps the Minister for Defence will respond to this matter in his reply-we shall get eight shells which may in future be fitted with appropriate weapons systems. I think we have enough of those. If it comes to the crunch, as it well may, do we need eight shells or six or four fully-fitted frigates? That important question may well have to be decided in the months to come. There is no doubt that the financial constraints placed on the construction of these frigates will force some big decisions to be made. I understand that the Minister has already sent back certain proposals from the Navy on the basis of cost and perhaps design. What shall we finish up with in terms of weapons systems in these new frigates? No doubt in the coming months the Government will have to spend more money on personnel, and that will come out of the existing budget. One cannot allow wastage rates to go unaddressed, and the Government will have to spend more money on conditions of service. That also will affect the new frigate program.

I hope that Williamstown will be well placed to make a determined bid for the new frigate contract. There is no doubt that Williamstown has good facilities and has an advantage in that it is building the two FFGs. I presume that the matter will fall between Williamstown and Carrington Slipways Pty Ltd, and Cockatoo Dockyard Pty Ltd may be considered. I have no doubt that the New South Wales Government will be making a determined bid to put Newcastle back in the firing line. North Queensland Engineers and Agents Pty Ltd is no doubt interested; I am not sure whether it can compete with this size of ship. It has an excellent record and I hope that it can compete. From the point of view of building the frigates and reviving the Australian shipbuilding industry, the Opposition totally supports the Government's approach.

In the tabling speech the Minister mentioned the submarine project as part of the revival of shipbuilding in this country-again a matter we totally support. As the Minister for Defence is present, I wonder whether he will take on board some comments and questions that I have been asking and answer them definitively once and for all, instead of our having to have the answers dragged out of public servants in Estimates committees. In view of the Minister's statements about shipbuilding, technology transfer and submarines in Australia, and bearing in mind the fact that all the submarines are to be built here, it is now clear that a substantial part of the first submarine will be built in Sweden. Many people want to know how much of that first submarine is to be built in Sweden, what the percentage of the total cost will be in Sweden--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I draw the honourable member's attention to the fact that we are dealing with the Williamstown position, not the submarine position.

—I rise on a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. It is a fact that in the tabling statement the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel canvassed the submarine program as part of the overall shipbuilding statement. I wonder whether you might bear that in mind in ruling on this matter.
—I accept that.

—As I said when I was opening my remarks on submarines, the matter was mentioned in the Minister's tabling speech; therefore I think it is only appropriate that I should respond because this is part of the revival of shipbuilding in Australia. The design of the first submarine, and presumably subsequent submarines, is to be done in Sweden. That raises the question: If the design work is to be done in Sweden, who owns that design in the end? Who owns that property? When one is designing something in another country one tends to use the materials and design work from that country. Will it not be a problem when that design work is transferred to Australia and we proceed with the remainder of the first submarine and subsequently with the second, third and so on?

SPEECH.PARA: In conclusion, I wish to make the point that the Opposition totally agrees with the sale of Williamstown Dockyard. I believe that the Government has gone about this matter in a very sensible way. There are two strong bids on the books to be considered; the sooner the decision is made, the better for the employees of the dockyard and the sooner we will see that dockyard come to life and become a viable section of our shipbuilding industry. I am impressed by the fact that one of the consortiums that have tendered comprises employees of the dockyard. They have probably taken a considerable financial risk and put their own capital into that consortium, which proves to some degree that they believe it can be turned into a viable enterprise. That is very heartening. They also propose to sell shares to other employees in the dockyard. We need a viable shipbuilding industry in this country and I hope that Williamstown will be very much a part of that. In the end it will be up to the private sector, the unions, the employees and the management to make a go of it. The Opposition wishes them well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr D.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —A number of issues have been thrown into this debate on the Williamstown Dockyard Employees Bill, such as privatisation and pay rises, to which I will return a little later. This Bill enshrines agreements that have been reached among the Department of Finance, the Department of Industrial Relations, the Public Service Commission, the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) and the dockyards union. This exhaustive and comprehensive round of negotiations is in contrast to the confrontationist approach that was typical of the previous conservative Government and conservative governments in this country for many years. This agreement, which is before us in the form of legislation, has involved everyone connected with the yard.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's decision earlier this year to sell all or part of the Williamstown Dockyard to private enterprise was important. I remember when the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley), who is at the table now, first floated the idea with me earlier this year. In discussions with him I said I thought it was a good idea because, notwithstanding changes that had been made over a number of years, the Williamstown Dockyard simply was not competitive in comparison with some of the other dockyards around Australia. This was a particularly important factor with the Anzac program coming on stream. That is why the people involved-the Public Service unions, the ACTU and the blue collar dockyard unions-were able to get together and reach a comprehensive agreement on this issue. This is what the legislation is all about.

We will see a comprehensive and successful changeover to the successful tenderer, the new owner, as a result of the negotiations which this Government, through the Minister at the table, has seen fit to conduct over the past six months or so. Indeed, there are two consortiums on the short list for ownership of the dockyard. They are the Australian Marine Engineering Corporation, which has a few big and very well-known shipbuilders involved, and the Williamstown Dockyard Consortium, a diverse consortium including some employees at the dockyard. I wish them both well and the Government will make a decision on the successful tender in the near future.

That new owner will take over the building of the two FFG frigates which were announced in 1983 and which are being built there for delivery in 1991 and 1993. The new owners will also be able to tender for the Anzac program-for the possibly 12 light patrol frigates that were first mentioned in the Dibb Review of Australia's Defence Capabilities. The Government investigated this proposition and believed that it was the right tack to take, so we will see that come to fruition through the Anzac program, which will involve Australian and New Zealand and which will introduce a new concept in shipbuilding in this country. From the industry viewpoint, that project together with the submarine project will constitute the biggest shipbuilding program seen in this country since the Second World War. If one takes the two projects together, one is looking at some $9 billion worth of shipbuilding. I am not biased, but as a Victorian-and I know that you, Mr Deputy Speaker, are from New South Wales-I believe that the Williamstown Dockyard, under its new leadership, will be a certainty to get the main bulk of the Anzac program. Notwithstanding my viewpoint, obviously the Government will make its decision on the competitive tendering and comprehensive nature of all the shipbuilders around Australia.

I shall answer some of the questions that have been thrown up in this debate. I find it extra- ordinary that the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White) should come into the House and start talking about the pay and conditions of defence personnel. I remind him that, when we won government in 1983, we inherited a wage freeze which included a freeze of pay for military personnel. For a great many years during the Fraser Government, defence personnel did not get a pay rise at all. We introduced the first pay rise-5.9 per cent-that they had for many years. This may not have been enough and the recent decision also may not have been enough, but these people were coming from a relatively low base that was created by Liberal-National Party members. No one else created it; the Opposition was responsible. We introduced the Remuneration Tribunal, so it galls me that in nearly every debate we have in this House the Opposition comes in and talks about how dreadful conditions are here, there and everywhere. Yet, when the Government made the decision to sell all or part of Williamstown Dockyard last autumn, it was virtually on its fourth anniversary in government. We have had just four years. I remind the Opposition that for 31 of the previous 34 years conservative governments were in power in this country. What did they do about it? Nothing. In industrial terms, most of our problems were created by the no-planning, no-forethought, do-nothing governments of the 1950s and 1960s under that supposedly great Prime Minister Menzies. We are now having to pay for that do-nothing attitude. Opposition members come into this House and complain that this country is in a dreadful state; yet the Opposition created most of the dashed problems. Opposition members come in here and talk about wage rates for defence personnel after being responsible for freezing their salaries.

The honourable member for McPherson also talked about privatisation, saying that the selling off of Williamstown Dockyard is the first big thing that we have done and that we will privatise everything.

TALK.START.PARA: —How would you like to try to get it through at the moment?

—Quite easily. Contrary to what the honourable member thinks, there are people on this side of the House who acknowledge the fact that some enterprises-Williamstown is obviously one of them-are better off and much more competitive in private hands. That is the reason why this Government made the decision. The honourable member for Melbourne, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand), agrees with that decision because it will make it much more competitive.
—Which way did he vote?
—I voted for it. How else would I vote?

—He voted for it; that is right. We are not talking about privatisation in this debate. We are not talking about selling off Aussat Pty Ltd, the Overseas Telecommunications Commission, Australia Post or Telecom Australia, which members of the Opposition would like to do. Members of the Opposition talk about flogging off everything. That is what their leader said during the election campaign. Opposition members cannot get away from that. But, if we look at what Thatcher has done, if I may diverge for just a few seconds, British Telecom's service and costs are disastrous now compared with what they were when it was in public hands. Whilst things may not have been perfect, they have gone downhill since.
—We agree with what you are doing. Tell that to the people in the gallery.

—I am just telling the honourable member for McPherson not to hold his breath waiting for us to privatise anything in the communications area because I can tell him that that will never occur. The Opposition will not be able to do that either after we have finished.

SPEECH.PARA: We heard an incredible speech from the honourable member for McPherson in which he talked about pay rises, privatisation and all sorts of things which have nothing to do with this debate. The Government made the decision, I think back in March, to move towards selling off all or part of Williamstown. There will be negotiations with the new owners. I am sure that the new owners will be very competitive in the new tendering system for the Anzac project. As I have said-I am sure the honourable member for Melbourne will agree with me-Victoria will gain a very big share of that project.

TALK.START.PARA: —A good project.

—It is. Let me just finish on the point on which I started out. The way in which this Bill has come before the House is in complete contrast with the way in which conservative governments in this country operated. Instead of confrontation and the pitting of one group against another, we have seen various groups, from the Public Service unions to the blue collar unions to departments of the Government and the Public Service Commission, after about six months of negotiation, bring forward successful agreements that will work. That is what this Government is about. As Australians we should be proud of that. This legislation is a result of that. It is part of the Government's original decision to sell off all or part of Williamstown Dockyard. I support that decision, as does everyone else on this side of the House, and I wish the Minister and the Government well in the finalisation of the selling off of Williamstown. I wish the dockyard well with the Anzac project, which I am sure we will hear more about in the near future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McArthur Mr F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to see the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) here to defend the left wing of the Australian Labor Party in this interesting debate focusing on privatisation. The Government has now agreed with the coalition's position on privatisation, and this is manifested in the Williamstown Dockyard Employees Bill 1987. I support the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White), the shadow Minister for Defence, in his remarks about this Bill. We support the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) and the Government for moving the dockyard to a more commercial footing and getting away from the dead hand of bureaucracy.

SPEECH.PARA: In answer to the honourable member for Isaacs (Mr Charles), who suggested that former conservative governments encouraged confrontationist industrial relations, let me remind him who was the President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions during the 1970s. Who encouraged the arguments and the debates between management and the unions during that time and is now preaching consensus and all of that? Who was the real architect of the arguments between the management and the unions during that time? We are still handling the legacy of those times.

From the focus of this Bill, it is obvious that privatisation is now a key debate, surprisingly, amongst members of the Labor Party. I note that by one vote the Caucus supported the privatisation suggestions of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) which the Opposition has been putting forward over the last three or four years. It is a surprising change, and I look forward with interest to see what will happen at the Labor Party's National conference in June next year.

We in the Opposition agree with the general thrust of this Bill, which is that redundancy payments to the work force be reasonable in the changeover of the dockyard from government ownership to ownership by the private sector. I note that the present Minister for Defence has been instrumental in selling the Government Aircraft Factories to the private sector. Again, I support him in these endeavours. I have looked at the aircraft factory at Avalon and was impressed with its level of performance. I have no doubt that, with the change in attitude and change in approach, that aircraft factory will work a lot better in the private sector. Likewise, at the Williamstown Dockyard with which this Bill is concerned, I am sure that with the change of attitude there will be quite a remarkable change in productivity and output. There will also be a change of approach towards Garden Island Dockyard and it will be sold off to the private sector.

If we refer to the Review of Defence Project Management of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts in 1986, we see that it found that `difficulties, especially in material procurement, reflected the limited autonomy of the dockyard management and the lack of modern commercial practices'. So we see that the Parliament's own Public Accounts Committee brought to light a major problem which was known to everyone else associated with the Williamstown Dockyard. The report of the Auditor-General on audits to 30 June 1987 was very critical of progress made by the dockyard towards full commercial accounting and concluded that since its previous unsatisfactory findings of dockyard audits it was disappointing to see the lack of appropriate resources devoted to major changes to the Dockyard's accounting information systems. In fact the result of the audit was unsatisfactory. The Auditor-General's report also stated:
The failure of the management information systems to produce accurate and timely reports resulted in the Dockyard severely underestimating the projected loss from operations during the year.
I was pleased to see in the second reading speech of the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly) that she did concede these difficulties when she said:

Operating under public sector constraints, Williamstown Dockyard is not well structured to remedy these deficiencies and to compete for the full prime contractor role for the new surface combatant or even project Anzac.

So the general position of the Minister and the Government is one of agreeing with the coalition on the privatisation issue under public debate at this time. Both the Minister and the shadow Minister have mentioned the two consortia on the short list of tenderers to buy the dockyard. One is the Australian Marine Engineering Corporation and the other includes Tecnav Pty Ltd, which incorporates some of the current management of the Williamstown Dockyard and Byvest Pty Ltd. Again, the coalition supports the fact that those people who are in the work force of the dockyard have seen fit, both in the work place and in the management role, to take over the dockyard. Again, that supports our general philosophic thrust of co-operation between unions and management. The tenders were put out on 7 September and I understand that the results of these two consortium bids will be decided upon by the Government by February-March 1988.

It appears that the Government has spent about $80m in upgrading the dockyard, so the amount of new capital equipment and facilities is of a high order in some parts of the dockyard. However, various literature that I have read suggests that the value of the dockyard is in the area of $100m. So with the sale we will get a combination of good equipment, in which the Government has invested, and efficiency in naval construction and repairs and, above all, we will have the profit motive that the new consortium will bring to bear on the dockyard operation.

Turning to the dockyard work force, one sees a surprising change in the numbers and attitudes and again the quite remarkable overmanning of the dockyard that was historically the situation. A total of 600 personnel will no longer be needed at the dockyard. One might wonder what they were doing over the last 20 years. The total work force numbers will fall from about 1,800 or 1,900 to an objective of 1,300 personnel. The fact that about one-third of the work force is being made redundant by the effluxion of time, retirements and so on must indicate that quite considerable overmanning and faulty work practices existed in the dockyard. I am led to believe that the establishment still retains a sailmaker. I think the last Australian ship of combat that had sail was well before the 1914-18 War, and I wonder why the Williamstown Naval Dockyard retained a sailmaker. That is a job description, although one assumes the sailmaker would have had to find other activities to occupy his time.

The employees of the dockyard are employed under the Public Service Act 1922 and the Naval Defence Act 1910 and, as the shadow Minister for Defence indicated, there is no potential to sack any of those employees in this industrial type operation. The coalition supports clause 5 of the Bill, which guards against an employee who is offered employment by the new owner declining that offer, taking the redundancy and then re-applying for employment. Measures to prevent employees from abusing the redundancy package in this way are incorporated in the Bill, and the Opposition supports them. Any worker who refuses an offer of employment with the new owner will be deemed to have resigned and will therefore not be offered the redundancy package. In her second reading speech, the Minister indicated that this was done to save the Government $4m to $13m, and the coalition supports any measures to save taxpayers' funds.

The auditor's report indicates the tremendous problems in the procurement procedures-that is, getting the materials on hand-and on site evidence indicates that a number of workers have been idle for periods of days, weeks and months while waiting for vital parts to arrive. The shadow Minister indicated his personal observations only yesterday when saying that members of the work force were not fully employed during his inspection of the dockyard. Obviously some downtime must be experienced, as well as waiting time for parts to arrive. As the shadow Minister indicated, up to nine months waiting time had occurred for particular vital parts.

Dockyard authorities have taken no heed of the motor industry where work practices have been improved and `just in time' procedures have been adopted so that parts arrive ready for the production line with 24 to 48 hours to spare. That high level of efficiency is in stark contrast to the obvious delays in the delivery of parts and materials that have occurred at the Williamstown dockyard over the last 20 or 30 years.

Privatisation will produce a change of attitude and changes in respect of quality control and efficiency. The objective will be to ensure that the successful tenderer is able to compete with overseas shipbuilders. Again, the Opposition supports the view that in Australia we ought to be able to construct ships efficiently so that important defence contracts can be let to our own industry, creating jobs, profits and employment opportunities for our own people rather than providing work for overseas shipbuilding yards.

The eight frigates ordered by the Royal Australian Navy are worth something in the area of $3.5 billion in contracts and, coupled with the four New Zealand naval contracts, would total approximately $5 billion worth of contracts that could be taken on by the Williamstown Naval Dockyard. It is an encouraging situation which can be brought about only with a change in the operation of the dockyard. As the Minister for Defence has said, this is the best equipped dockyard in Australia, despite its management and work force problems.

The historic position of the dockyard is well known to Victorians. I have an interesting quote from the National Times of 14 November 1985, during the time of the Costigan Royal Commission into the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union of Australia, that typifies the position, as Victorians understand it, of the operations at the dockyard:

The boys in blue at Williamstown's naval dockyard are popularly associated with broken noses, tattoos, cement overcoats and royal commissions. Combine this with their reputation for industrial ratbaggery and you could say they have an image problem.

Two years ago the whole dockyard had an image problem. For more than a decade powerful blue-collar unions had been staging constant walkouts and work bans. They accused the naval management, for whom they felt a loathing that was fully reciprocated, of incompetence and at one stage voted to ``sack'' the management and run the yard themselves.

Unhappily for them, they were heading for a tragic denouncement. With up to 320,000 man hours a year lost because of disputes, costs were rising as fast as productivity was falling and the then Liberal Federal Government was threatening to close the yard altogether. More than 2,000 jobs would have gone with it.

That was the historic position; and the present Government has had to adopt the coalition's privatisation program and sell the dockyard off so that we can change the attitude of management, the work force and the unions and introduce a profit motive into the whole operation. The classical privatisation move will involve the work force in multiskilling and remove them from the potential demarcation dispute situation. It has been suggested that the unions now agree with that position. Of course, they had to agree because they could see that the remaining jobs in that establishment would disappear altogether unless dramatic changes occurred.

I conclude by drawing the attention of the House to the strange position of the Prime Minister and the Government in the privatisation debate. I quote from the Prime Minister's speech during the Nunawading by-election campaign when he said:
The efficient delivery of government services-many of which only government can provide-will be sacrificed on the altar of ideological expedience . . .
All the conservatives really want is to sell off the profitable areas of government activity . . .
Picking and choosing in this way is hardly the hallmark of a socially responsible government . . .

That is an interesting statement from the Prime Minister in light of the fact that the Government has now agreed to sell this operation which is losing $18m a year. That was his position then and I notice that yesterday the Prime Minister supported the privatisation argument. The headline in today's Age is: `Hawke supports asset sales but Left rallies troops'. It is interesting that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has now left the chamber. I shall quote what the Prime Minister now says about privatisation, accordancy to the Age:
It was a question of priorities for the use of Government funds.

``I can't see any social democratic principle that is involved in government running an airline'', he told a news conference. ``I have to also ask myself as I look down the track: are there going to be demands upon government to increase the capital base of those Government airlines? Is that going to involve a demand upon funds which could be better utilised in other ways? The same thing I think you can say of the bank''.

I presume he was talking about the Commonwealth Bank. I can add to that and say the same thing could be presumed about the Williamstown Naval Dockyard: funds would be better utilised in the private sector. The Government has now agreed to the general thrust of the Opposition's policy on privatisation: that more efficient operations will emanate from privatis- ation; that a change will take place in the Williamstown Dockyard in the quite drastic and dramatic industrial relations attitudes in that management will now become more co-operative with the work force in trying to produce a quality product; and that there will be a new era of shipbuilding in Australia because of this change by the Minister for Defence and the Government, contrary to the general thrust of the Labor Party at this time.
I commend the Minister and the Government for their adoption of the privatisation principles, as set out by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) and the coalition over the last five years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is nice to be preceded by a speech with which one can agree in its entirety. I thank the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price) for his contribution to this debate. I view with some gratitude the fact that this legislation is drawing support from both sides of the House. The Opposition is keen to portray the course of action that we have proposed as a course of action it has long advocated. Unfortunately, when I took up this portfolio, indeed when we got into government, we were confronted with a situation in which something like a $300m subsidy was effectively applying across the board in government defence enterprises of which the Williamstown dockyard is one. Total outlays into these areas was some $600m, a ratio of about 2 : 1. Those figures are not exact but they are of that order.

SPEECH.PARA: Enormous inefficiencies, enormous overmanning and extremely poor management had been allowed to develop over the seven years prior to our coming into government. That was the situation with which we were confronted when we came to office. Since that time, by a process of negotiation with the trade union movement and by rigorously addressing the cost structure of those organisations, we have reduced that subsidy. Within another year or so we will be at a point where, effectively, government factories are not subsidised at all. This is a course of action that has been made possible by the attitude this Government has to negotiations with the trade union movement and the attitude we have on the essential program of making certain that government enterprise works effectively.

As the Williamstown Dockyard Employees Bill 1987 is directly related to industrial provisions associated with the sale of Williamstown Dockyard, it is appropriate to acknowledge in the consultation process the role of the trade union movement. We are now at the position in which we have an attractive package for sale basically because we have had the co-operation of the union movement in negotiations. Fears that may have been apparent among would-be purchasers of the dockyard have been laid to rest by the fact that we have been able to achieve agreement. I pay tribute to the trade union negotiators involved for the fact that we have arrived at that position. I also pay tribute to the work force generally which is now looking forward to the various changes that will be associated with the program that is outlined in the legislation.

This legislation is a small element of a total approach to defence shipbuilding in this country. This Government has, to a very large extent, revived the shipbuilding industry by the policy decisions that we have been taking. I cite as examples of this the fact that we are now prepared to build two frigates at Williamstown; the fact that we are prepared to construct all six submarines in Australia; the fact that we have been prepared to construct hydrographic vessels in this country-a contract for which has recently been let-and the fact that we are proceeding to construct minehunters. It is a massive shipbuilding program that will be continuous. By the time all of those projects are completed it will be necessary to replace other craft in the inventory and the successful tenderers for the construction of the ships and submarines will, of course, be entitled to bid for subsequent programs.

After the 1960s we had effectively moved ourselves out of shipbuilding programs altogether, except for the odd one here and there and patrol boats, and we are back to the situation in which from now on, and for the foreseeable future, we will build ships and submarines and our naval needs will be met in this country. This will have a major impact on our industrial posture as a nation. In building our naval needs in this country we are required to protect the defence dollar to ensure that the product we obtain is obtained at the best possible price and this legislation is directly related to achieving that objective.

A number of questions were raised by honourable members on both sides of the House and I will attempt to deal with them very briefly. Firstly, a question was raised about the light patrol frigate program-the Anzac program. It is our intention to keep costs constrained. Invariably, when one is entailed in a process of keeping costs constrained, one will occasionally make sacrifices in capability. It does not matter which weapons system one is dealing with; that will be the case. We will be ensuring that if there is a requirement to send frigates into a hotter situation than we might anticipate in our current strategic environment, there will be a capacity to make the necessary modifications rapidly. But we would be foolish to do that in advance in this program because we have to remember that this is a zero sum game. If we build excess capacity into ships by divorcing the program from the overall defence equipment program, sacrifices will be made elsewhere. It is quite conceivable that those sacrifices would be made with particular weapons systems which are more important than the marginal improvement that would take place as a result of proceeding to do a full fit on the frigates.

We also have to recognise the situation of our partner. We have a $A7 1/2 billion a year defence budget, of which some $2 billion is spent on equipment. That $2 billion spent on equipment is alone approximately twice the size of the total New Zealand defence budget. So we have to be mindful of the fact that in dealing with New Zealand we are dealing with a country which, as the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) outlined yesterday, we wish to involve intensely in this project but which has to keep its own expenditure within reasonable constraints. New Zealand is offering us, by its participation, a very substantial industrial benefit. We would not wish to see that abused and we would not wish to see New Zealand drop out of the process through decisions we took that unnecessarily increased the cost.

It also has to be recognised that we are dealing with a restructured navy based on several tiers of warship. We are not with this ship trying to replicate the FFGs and DDGs. When we come to replace the FFGs and DDGs we will be replacing them with a higher capability ship than we envisage here in this program. However, if we fail to recognise this and go for too much in this class of ship, we may well compromise our capacity in the long haul to build even more into their subsequent replacements. That is a matter for the Navy to have regard to, because I do not think that any of the participants in this debate will necessarily be participants in the debates that occur in about 15 or 20 years time when that issue becomes a matter of public consideration in this country.

So these are the constraints that are acting on the way in which we approach the light patrol frigate program. There is one other constraint, and this, I think, makes it doubly important that we keep the New Zealanders in the project if we possibly can-as I believe we will be able to do. I refer to the question of the size of our surface fleet. It is my view that our surface fleet is too small. Its present size has been arrived at basically because that was the number considered necessary to make a carrier battle group viable. Equivalent countries such as Canada and some countries in our neighbourhood operate 20 or 30 frigates. As a result of this program we will go to about 16 or 17. One of the questions put to me was whether or not we would be prepared to sacrifice numbers for capability. It would be with extreme reluctance that I would sacrifice numbers for capability, because there is a value in having a substantial number of platforms, particularly in respect of the tasks of choke point protection around the coast of Australia. Twelve is probably not enough to do it with. Sixteen or 17 is probably not enough either, but it is better than 12. There are four New Zealand craft as well. That makes 21, and that is a heck of a lot better than 16 or 17. These increases start to make a difference.

TALK.START.PARA: —I don't think you can be sure that they would be with you.

—The New Zealanders have alliance commitments to us and nothing that they have said to me indicates that they in any way intend to renege on them. A question was raised, too, about submarines and the construction that would be done in this country. The Opposition spokesman on defence matters, the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White), raised a question which he has raised a couple of times in this Parliament. I will answer it again. It was made quite clear at the time to Cabinet and to all the committees that were briefed that the bits and pieces of the first submarine hull would be produced overseas. The package we signed was a total package which provided for 70 per cent to be constructed in Australia and 30 per cent to be constructed overseas. This particular contract that we have signed happens to be included among the 30 per cent that was to be constructed overseas. Unless we were doing 100 per cent of the construction here, logically some portion will be constructed overseas. This contract is within that overseas portion.

SPEECH.PARA: It will be constructed of Australian material. It will be Australian steel that goes into the work that will be done in Sweden. It will provide our engineers with a substantial advantage. By the time they are doing the complex engineering on these parts of the submarine, equivalent facilities will not have been completed in Australia. We will be starting that early. So Australian engineers will have an opportunity to gain skills in submarine production by learning in those Swedish yards and they will be able to apply those skills in Australia at exactly the right point in time when equivalent facilities for construction become available in Australia.

So a substantial benefit is coming to us and this contract is appropriately a part of the overseas portion, given the significance of these parts of the submarine to its own overall performance when it is up and running. When we are dealing with a scheme in which 70 per cent of the funds are being spent in this country-exactly reversing the ratio that was associated with the FA18 program-I think it is rather foolish to worry about what constitutes about 25 per cent to 30 per cent of the first platform when the benefits we are gaining from this contract are so substantial in the subsequent production activity associated with the program.

This piece of legislation will enable the Williamstown Naval Dockyard to compete effectively in all these great projects. It will enable it to ensure its continuing existence forever. That ought to be a matter of great encouragement for the members of the work force who will be retained in the dockyard under its new ownership. It also ought to be a matter of encouragement for the people in that region whose employment is to some degree ancillary to or dependant upon servicing the Williamstown Naval Dockyard. It is part of what has been the most consistent effort in naval shipbuilding in this country to ensure that Australian industry capacity is enhanced and that, in being enhanced, a major strategic benefit accrues to the Australian people and the Australian Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen), who is not available at this stage, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill continues the practice of introducing an omnibus Bill into each sittings of the Parliament as an expeditious way of making a large number of non-contentious amendments to legislation. Some of the amendments made by this Bill tidy up, correct and update existing legislation. Other amendments are of minor policy significance or are matters of routine administration. None of the amendments made by the Bill has any significant financial impact.

The amendments proposed in this Bill are, for the most part, a reproduction of the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill (No. 1) 1987 which lapsed after the second reading debate in the House earlier this year. The current Bill is different from Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) (No. 1) in two respects. Firstly, it contains some further changes to amendments previously included in the Bill. Some of these are necessary because of the effluxion of time, for example, the amendments to the Honey Industry Act 1962, and some are minor drafting amendments. Secondly, this Bill includes amendments to the following Acts which were not present in the earlier Bill: Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976; Acts Interpretation Act 1901; Canned Fruits Marketing Act 1979; Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918; Conciliation and Arbitration Act 1904; Currency Act 1965; Customs Tariff (Miscellaneous Amendments) Act 1987; Extradition (Commonwealth Countries) Act 1966; Foreign States Immunities Act 1985; Minerals (Submerged Lands) Act 1981; Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters (Consequential Amendments) Act 1987. Many of the proposed amendments will be self-evident or sufficiently explained by the explanatory memorandum circulated with the Bill. I propose to confine my comments to addressing mainly the new amendments included in this Bill, and amendments in the lapsed Bill that were queried.

The Bill was passed by the Senate with amendments, on 7 October 1987. The Senate amended the Bill by omitting certain proposed amendments to the Acts Interpretation Act and the Audit Act. The omissions are reflected in the supplementary explanatory memorandum No. 1 circulated with the Bill. Four of the omitted provisions are substantive, and there are two consequential amendments. Three of the substantive amendments were referred to Senate standing committees for inquiry and report. This course of action was adopted to permit the Bill's speedy passage through the Senate. These amendments have been considered by the Senate committees which have approved the amendments subject to a minor drafting change in the amendment to the Acts Interpretation Act. I foreshadow that I will be moving that this Bill be amended to restore these three amendments with that minor change and the consequential amendments.
Acts Interpretation Act 1901

The amendments to the Acts Interpretation Act are intended to advance the policy of simplifying the language of Acts of parliament. For this purpose the amendments will permit some standard forms of words to be shortened, or omitted from Acts. I will be moving an amendment to the Bill, similar to that omitted from the Bill as introduced in the Senate to further amend the Acts Interpretation Act to make it clear that regulations may be expressed to commence at the commencement of a specified Act, even if the Act is to commence on a proclaimed date. It is also intended to provide that regulations may be expressed to commence at a specified time on a specified day.
Anglo-Australian Telescope Agreement Act 1970

The Anglo-Australian Telescope Agreement Act currently restricts the functions of the Anglo-Australian Telescope Board to those specified in the agreement annexed to the Act. The United Kingdom and Australian governments have agreed that it is desirable for the board to assume from the United Kingdom authorities responsibility for the future management of some additional facilities already in place at Siding Spring. The amendments will enable the board to undertake other functions as prescribed by regulations and so assume those responsibilities without the need for amendment of the agreement.
Audit Act 1901

The amendments proposed to the Audit Act in this Bill are aimed at improving the efficiency of the Commonwealth's financial administration and allowing the Auditor-General a discretion in reporting minor breaches of legislative requirements. Financial administration will be improved by an amendment to enable the Minister for Finance to approve methods of performing accounting functions which do not involve written signatures. The amendments will ensure that Departments report to Parliament on their special operations-a requirement which has not existed previously. The Auditor-General will also be given some discretion on which matters are included in his reports. The Auditor-General, when so requested by a Minister, will be able to audit the financial statements of bodies such as incorporated companies controlled by the Commonwealth. Currently there is doubt whether the Act permits such an audit, as the existing provision refers to the audit of accounts and records only.

Other amendments will enable regulations to be made to re-establish a policy adopted by previous governments and arising directly from the policy of self-insurance, that the liability of Commonwealth drivers for the cost of replacing or repairing damaged vehicles should be the same as for a driver in the private sector who is covered by motor vehicle insurance. The Senate omitted some proposed amendments from the Bill as introduced in that House. I will be moving amendments to this Bill to amend further the Audit Act to simplify the processes by which funds that have already been appropriated by law are subsequently distributed to departments.
Canned Fruits Marketing Act 1979

Amendment to the Canned Fruits Marketing Act 1979 is proposed in order to extend the current marketing arrangements for canned deciduous fruits undertaken through the Australian Canned Fruits Corporation for one year until 31 December 1988. The Government is aware of current efforts by canneries to amalgamate their activities in order to improve efficiency and reduce costs. The extension of the marketing arrangements by one year will facilitate industry discussions on cannery amalgamation.
Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918

The proposed amendment to the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 is designed to put beyond doubt the power of the Electoral Commissioner to direct Australian electoral officers, divisional returning officers and other officers as defined in that Act. The amendment also puts beyond doubt the power of Australian electoral officers to direct divisional returning officers and they in their turn to direct officers under their control.
Conciliation and Arbitration Act 1904

The amendment of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act 1904 is intended to remove doubts about the certification of rule alterations. The Act requires that certain rule alterations made by organisations registered under the Act do not take effect unless certified by an industrial registrar as not contrary to law, the Act and regulations, an award or the rules of the organisation. Some doubt exists about the power of a registrar to certify only part of a rule alteration submitted to him.

The proposed amendment is intended to remove any doubt as to the validity of any certification in part, made by a registrar in the past and any doubt as to the validity of the rule alteration. The provision will not operate to alter any prior decision made by a court regarding any such certification or to pre-empt any decision in a proceeding before a court at the time the sub-section takes effect. A court will, however, be able to hold that a certification in part was valid if the court considers that it is just and equitable so to find.
Currency Act 1965

The proposed amendment of the Currency Act 1965 will permit the issue of coins of the same denomination with differing characteristics and dimensions. This will facilitate the issue of special commemorative coins in 1988.
Dairy Produce Act 1986

The amendments to the Dairy Produce Act 1986 will prevent persons who are members of the Executive Council of the Australian Dairy Conference, which is the peak policy council of the dairy industry, from being appointed as members of the Australian Dairy Corporation. This change is in accordance with the Government's policy that, where a statutory marketing authority is required to account to the peak industry body, the members of the executive council of that body are not to be eligible for appointment as members of the authority, because of the possibility of a conflict of interests.
Honey Industry Act 1962

The proposed amendments to the Honey Industry Act 1962 will enable the Minister to reappoint the immediate past members of the Australian Honey Board to hold office until the end of 1988. The Board is to be restructured with the new membership.

Under the Bill which lapsed at the end of the last sittings, the tenure of Board members was to be extended pending the restructuring of the Board. However, in the intervening period the Board members' appointments have expired.
Housing Loans Insurance Act 1965

The Bill proposes a number of minor amendments to the Housing Loans Insurance Act 1965. The most important of these fall into two areas. The first will allow greater flexibility in the appointment of a person to act as Chairman and Managing Director of the Corporation. Under the proposed amendments, the Treasurer will be able to appoint someone to act as chairman in the absence of the Chairman. This will overcome difficulties that have arisen when the Deputy Chairman's position has been vacant.

The second area of amendment will allow the Corporation to enter into reinsurance contracts with a subsidiary of an approved lender in respect of loans made by the approved lender and insured by the subsidiary. A recent trend for some lenders to insure their loans through their own newly established subsidiaries, and the fact that the Corporation is currently prevented by its Act from offering reinsurance, have restricted the Corporation's ability to compete for business it has traditionally serviced. The proposed amendments will enable the Corporation to respond to developments in the mortgage insurance market.
Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act 1986, Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security Act 1986, Intelligence and Security (Consequential Amendments) Act 1986

Several consequential amendments are to be made to these Acts following on the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act 1986. The amendments also will make it clear that the Inspector-General may inquire into an act or practice of an intelligence agency that is or may be contrary to any human right, may constitute discrimination or may be unlawful under the Racial Discrimination Act 1975 or the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 where it has been referred to the Inspector-General by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission.
Minerals (Submerged Lands) Act 1981

The Minerals (Submerged Lands) Act provides a regime to allow exploration for, and exploitation of minerals from the seabed. Administration, pursuant to the Offshore Constitutional Settlement, is to be shared between the States and the Northern Territory and the Commonwealth. Although passed in 1981 proclamation of the Act has been held up pending passage by the States and the Northern Territory of complementary legislation. The proposed amendment is to allow proclamation of only portions of the Act.

Governments are working on the full set of legislation and administrative arrangements required to implement the regime. Meanwhile, however, while the States and the Northern Territory can consider applications to explore areas to the outer limit of the territorial sea-the `three mile limit'-in accordance with their existing on-shore mining legislation, the Commonwealth is unable to consider applications for the much larger area of continental shelf outside the limit. There have been several expressions of interest by companies in respect of exploration in the Commonwealth's area. The Government is disposed to encourage commencement of mineral exploration activity, though mining would not be authorised until all arrangements are in place. It is proposed to proclaim only so much of the Act as is necessary to allow exploration to proceed.

Given the role of the States and the Northern Territory in the administration of the Act, their views on partial proclamation have been sought. None of them has raised objections in principle. Discussions between officials are taking place.
Navigation Act 1912, Shipping Registration Act 1981

The most noteworthy amendments of the Navigation Act will benefit the maritime industry by eliminating unnecessary duplication of certificating of ships. The amendments of the Shipping Registration Act are intended to promote the prompt provision to the Registrar of Shipping of accurate information on ships entitled to be registered in Australia.
Pig Industry Act 1986

The amendment to the Pig Industry Act provides that if the Australian Pork Corporation requests that a company auditor be appointed the auditor of the Corporation, the Auditor-General shall advise the Minister on the suitability of the proposed company auditor. At present the Auditor-General is required to decide on the suitability of a company auditor. Another amendment removes the restriction on the Australian Pork Corporation Selection Committee which prevents it from nominating for appointment to the Corporation anyone who is a member of the executive of an eligible industry body, that is, the Australian Pork Producers' Federation or the National Meat Processors Association. A person will still be ineligible for actual appointment to the Corporation if he or she is such a member. Removal of this restriction will mean that such a person will need to resign his or her position in the Federation or Association only if and when offered appointment to the Corporation by the Minister. This amendment will bring the selection procedures for the Corporation into line with those for other statutory marketing authorities.
Wine Grapes Levy Collection Act 1979

The proposed amendments to the Wine Grapes Levy Collection Act update the penalties and revise some of the offences. The amendments as they now appear differ from the original version of the Bill introduced earlier this year to rectify a defect in a provision removing the right to refuse to provide information on the grounds of self-incrimination. This matter was raised by the Senate Standing Committee on the Scrutiny of Bills.

I have not dealt with most of the amendments proposed by this Bill which were contained in the lapsed Bill. The explanatory memorandum has been revised and expanded in relation to all these amendments and honourable members will be able to find details of these amendments, and the new amendments, in that memorandum. Supplementary explanatory memorandum No. 1 provides replacement pages for the explanatory memorandum to take account of the amendments made to the Bill by the Senate. I have foreshadowed some amendments to restore some of the provisions omitted by the Senate. I also foreshadow amendments to the National Measurement Act 1960 relating to contracts for the sale of land. Details of all the proposed amendments are contained in supplementary explanatory memorandum No. 2. I will deal with the background to the foreshadowed amendments when moving those amendments in Committee. I present the explanatory memorandum and supplementary memorandum No. 1 to this Bill. I commend the Bill to the House.

I compliment Senator Stone and of course Mr Ewart Smith, who has worked for this Parliament. They did a great job on this matter and it highlights the need to be careful about regulations.
