TALK.START.PARA: —General incompetence.

—As my neighbour in Victoria says, it is a mark of the muddle that this Government finds itself in. At this point I should say that the coalition will not be opposing the Bill in principle, although there are some aspects which will be commented on both in this House and in the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: I mentioned briefly the National Measurement Act. The proposals before us today provide a new definition of `interest in land' to include stratum-strata title and time sharing, so that all references to an `interest in land' do actually include all property transactions. In future, after 31 December 1987, all real estate transactions will be obliged to use metric units of measurements, except where, for example, the Act would have a retrospective effect, a State or Territory torrens land registration system applies, or countries which do not use metric units of measurement enter into transactions. As passed in the Senate, the Bill provides that real estate contracts and transactions would be void if non-metric measurements were used, unless the documents of title relating to the land included non-metric measurements. However, the Government has revised its position since then and proposes that such offences will be punishable by a fine rather than by invalidating contracts. The coalition parties support the proposed amendments, which remove the possibility of contravention of the Act.

In regard to the National Standards Commission, the proposals change the Commission's operations. Included are a number of amendments relating to the appointment, procedures, qualifications, terms of appointment, duties and powers of the Executive Director and members of the Commission. In future the Commission will be able to enter contracts up to $100,000, in comparison with the present limit of $50,000, without the approval of the Minister. This accords with the limit now governing some other statutory authorities. I mention these substantial matters because the Opposition's view is that they should be in a substantive amendment and not in a miscellaneous provisions Bill.

In the short time remaining for this debate, I wish to address myself to the concerns raised in both chambers about the adequacy, or should I say inadequacy, of the guidelines to regulate the scope of Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bills. In summary, these guidelines are intended to limit the scope of amendments to those dealing with uncontentious matters such as those required for tidying up, the correction and updating of legislation, and routine administrative changes. I refer members who are interested to comments made by Senator Macklin on this Bill in the Senate on 7 October 1987, as recorded at page 778 of the Hansard, where he incorporates the guidelines. It is clear from what has been said often in this Parliament, not only in relation to the current saga but in relation to earlier SLMP Bills, that not infrequently these Bills encroach into areas of substantive law and policy. In fact, I have just mentioned one, that relating to measurements. Indeed, I expect that similar sentiments will be expressed by some of my colleagues later in this debate.

The problem has been referred to by several parliamentary committees, including the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. As recently as 23 October 1987 the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, in the context of its report on this Bill, suggested that the guidelines could usefully be reviewed. I fully appreciate that, on occasion, the deviations, or straying from the straight and narrow, can be explained by pressures and time constraints that attend upon these Bills, no doubt compounded by the sheer immensity and volume of the exercise. However, there is in this chamber, and certainly within the Senate, a feeling that the guidelines should be reviewed. The Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration expressed the view as set out on page 1179 of the Senate Hansard:

. . . a distinction should be made between purely technical and routine amendments and matters which are of greater significance but which may nevertheless be legislatively straightforward. In the latter instance, a separate omnibus Bill would assist such matters to be considered more carefully.
Those words echo words of my own when I wrote to the Minister for Justice on 9 October to bring this matter to his attention:
It can be said against the practice that:
1. It effectively limits the speaking time of MPs on the various policy matters;
2. The Government can fail to properly draw controversial matters to the attention of the Parliament-
in other words, by slipping things in in the fine print-
3. It tends to treat the Parliament as a processing machine.

That is very much a feature of Labor governments because they reckon that parliaments are just here to do their bidding. That is why they like to chop into the powers of the Senate. My letter continued:
4. It may allow matters to go through without proper scrutiny.

That is a reasonable summation of four complaints and causes against the practice of these omnibus Bills. I do not think that I have said anything that is novel to Labor members. I simply say to them that the proposal I have put to the Minister should be taken up. I hope that a reference will be made by the Minister to the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee to examine all these procedures to see whether we can reach a bipartisan position in dealing with these Bills so that Parliament can, in the difficult circumstances created by these Bills, operate most effectively and efficiently.

That is not a matter of party politics, but a matter which is founded on concern for the manner in which we conduct our Parliament. I hope that the senator and members of the new Committee will take up this suggestion. I also hope that the guidelines can be reviewed quickly. We support the Bill in principle, although there are further matters to be raised and discussed. I look forward to the deliberations of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs on these Bills, and I hope that we can grapple with the situation and come up with recommendations before Parliament next finds itself dealing with a Bill of a similar type and description.

—Has the Minister for Defence seen recent comments by the honourable member for McPherson, the shadow Minister for Defence, that the Royal Australian Air Force's (RAAF) FA18 squadrons cannot be called operational squadrons? Has he also seen suggestions from the same source that there is a serious shortage of technicians at Williamtown and of maintenance and test equipment? ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. Normally I do not respond to the plethora of Press releases that come from the honourable member for McPherson, mainly because there is nothing in them to respond to. But I am glad that the honourable member for Brisbane raised this matter because this particular Press release, unlike most of those issued by the honourable member for McPherson, contained implications which were most untoward-that is, the suggestion that the farrago of nonsense that was produced was in some way based on briefings he had when he was at Williamstown. This Government has allowed unprecedented access by the Opposition to defence establishments, a practice which I intend to continue because I think that that is appropriate. However, Opposition members should reflect on the fact that when they receive briefings they are effectively under an obligation not to implicate their briefers. When we have done this sort of thing in the past we have had the common sense to have our views attributed solely to ourselves, rather than suggest that they have come from someone else. Indeed, the honourable member produced a plethora of nonsense. His release says breathlessly:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . things have now reached a stage where our FA-18 squadrons cannot be called operational squadrons.

What a discovery! We have not yet had half the number of FA18 aircraft delivered to us; we are in the process of making those squadrons operational. In fact there is only one unit which, as a result of a plan produced four or five years ago, is planned to be operational at this stage and that is No. 2 Operational Conversion Unit. That unit is fully operational. The two designated FA18 squadrons at Williamtown are at present converting to FA18 operations under that plan which is several years old. The plan is for No. 3 Squadron to be fully operational by the middle of next year and No. 77 Squadron a year later. No. 75 Squadron will be operational at Tindal by the end of 1990.

The Press release goes on to talk about `a shortage of technicians'. There is no shortage of senior technicians at Williamtown. All established posts are manned and Williamtown is receiving preferential treatment in obtaining surplus technicians so that such people can gain experience before they are ultimately transferred to Tindal. The Press release also claims that there are shortages of maintenance and test equipment. That is true; there are shortages of maintenance and test equipment but they have not prevented the FA18 program from achieving its authorised flying hours program. The reason there is that shortage of equipment is related to the introduction of maintenance and test equipment phased with the United States Navy's (USN) procurement of similar equipment and based on the United States Navy's statistical base. The Royal Australian Air Force has had to work around USN budgetary restrictions. The sort of nonsense expounded by the honourable member reveals his complete ignorance of the processes by which a program is properly managed inside the defence forces. The only thing that is unique about this Press release from the honourable member is that he, in some way, attributes by implication this farrago of nonsense to the RAAF officers who briefed him. He did them no service by proceeding down that path.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: PRIME MINISTER: VISIT TO SOVIET UNION

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Prime Minister, in his forthcoming meeting in the Soviet Union with Mr Gorbachev, request from him a clear and unambiguous timetable for the withdrawal of Soviet forces from Afghanistan; advise him of his Government's opposition to any attempt by the Soviet Union to extend its economic and political influence in South East Asia or the South Pacific; press him for the restoration of basic human rights, including the right of self-determination, for the peoples of Latvia, Estonia and Lithuania, whose occupation by the Soviet Union has never been recognised by Australia as lawful; and lastly request from him an undertaking to permit the free migration from the Soviet Union of all Soviet citizens who wish to settle in other countries? If the Prime Minister is not willing to do these things, will he explain why?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the honourable member for North Sydney will understand if I address the substance of the question without going into the details of what I intend to discuss with Mr Gorbachev or the way in which I intend to do it. For instance, I can assure the honourable member that my Government has not forgotten Afghanistan. We continue to express our very deep concern about the situation in that country. We have done so in this Parliament, we have done so in international forums and we have done so directly to the Soviet authorities. So that the position in regard to Afghanistan is quite clear, I point out that under this Government, Australia does not recognise the Afghan regime. Australia delivered a major statement at the current United Nations General Assembly strongly supporting the call by the majority of UN members to the Soviet Union to withdraw its forces from Afghanistan.

ANSWER.PARA: In the United Nations General Assembly, and in the United Nations Commission on Human Rights in Geneva, Australia has also addressed the denial of fundamental human rights to the Afghan people. We will continue to oppose the Soviet occupation of Afghanistan and support fully efforts by the United Nations special representative to achieve an early negotiated settlement of the conflict. Australia's condemnation of the continuing Soviet occupation of Afghanistan was repeated to the Soviet Foreign Minister, Mr Shevardnadze, when he visited Australia in March of this year. The subject will be raised again when I visit and talk with the leadership in the Soviet Union.

With regard to Afghanistan, I inform the honourable gentleman-he may not be aware of it-that this year Australia will provide food aid for Afghan refugees valued at approximately $4m. I also make the point that Australia is one of the few countries which have accepted any Afghan refugees for resettlement. So, quite clearly, on the question of Afghanistan the record of this Government has been consistent and clear. I will make the same representations and points again when I am in Moscow.

Among the other questions raised by the honourable gentleman was the presence of the Soviet Union in South East Asia. Obviously, again, on appropriate occasions we have expressed our concern and the concern of other countries in the South Pacific at the military presence of the Soviet Union in the region, and most particularly, of course, at Cam Ranh Bay, where it has a very substantial presence. With regard to the economic involvement of the Soviet Union in the region, we have said to the Soviet Union that we recognise that it has a specific interest there and that there can be no legitimate concern about the Soviet Union, as an independent sovereign nation, seeking to have economic relationships in the region. But the point has been made to Soviet representatives by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, and I made it particularly to Mr Shevardnadze here in March when I was speaking to him, that if, for instance, the Soviet Union makes fishing agreements with island states in the South Pacific, we will watch extremely closely to see that they are fishing agreements and nothing more than fishing agreements.

The honourable member also raised the question of basic human rights. I repeat that on this issue I doubt whether there is any country which has been more consistent and, I suggest, more effective than Australia under my Government in raising these issues.
Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —If there be any doubt about that observation, I suggest to the honourable gentleman-I notice that he did not interject, and I am not suggesting that he did-that there are authorities and interest groups in this country with which that statement can be checked. We have had significant discussions here with representatives of the Baltic communities and they have expressed considerable satisfaction with the way in which this Government has addressed the issue of the rights of their people in regard to the Soviet presence in those countries. We have from their representatives in this country an expression of their very deep satisfaction with the way that my Government has made representations directly and in relevant international forums on this issue.

ANSWER.PARA: Finally, the honourable member mentioned the question of migration. Let me say on that issue that I respect the way in which the honourable gentleman has raised that point. Obviously, what we all want to see is a situation in the Soviet Union in which all citizens have the same right to be able to move freely in and out of their country as they wish. That is the appropriate situation that should emerge and it is one that will be addressed in my representations in the Soviet Union.

ANSWER.PARA: I thank the honourable member for his question. He has shown an extraordinary interest in the environmental protection of his area. Its importance has been recognised, quite surprisingly, by the Queensland Government, which has promised for many years to declare large parts of the island as a national park. But, like most of the promises in Queensland, that promise has never been kept. As yet, no action has been taken to declare the park.

Press reports indicate that the Emanuel Group, possibly in a joint venture with overseas interests, plans to develop areas both on the mainland and on Bribie Island for large scale tourist and residential purposes. While, of course, this Government welcomes any sort of tourist proposition, we are very alert to make sure that such ventures complement the existing environment, particularly in areas such as Bribie Island, the Pumicestone Passage and the adjoining mainland. Accordingly, my colleague Senator Richardson, the Minister for the Environment and the Arts, has written to the Treasurer advising him that a decision in relation to foreign investment in the proposed development would be considered environmentally significant in terms of the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act. —I think we should acknowledge an act so honourable, but Peter cannot give up his seat.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Minister for Resources inform the House of the progress made towards uniform safety regulations for liquefied petroleum gas (LPG)?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —This issue is of considerable interest to the liquefied petroleum gas industry. It was raised at the conference of the Australian Liquefied Petroleum Gas Association which I addressed earlier this month, and more recently by the Chairman of the New South Wales Local Government Gas Advisory Committee, Alderman Arthur Campbell, in company with the honourable member for Calare. I point out that LPG regulations are a State responsibility. However, both State and Commonwealth governments have recognised the economic and safety advantages of a uniform system of regulation. For its part, our Government has actively encouraged the creation and updating of standards by the Standards Association of Australia and we have published a national code for the transport of dangerous goods by road and by rail.

ANSWER.PARA: Additionally, in September this year, the Australian Minerals and Energy Council established a working party of State, Territory and Commonwealth officials to work closely with the industry with a view to reviewing existing legislation affecting the LPG industry, to identifying areas where State legislation falls outside the principles suggested by the industry and, further, to advising on the development of information and standards for the safe use of LPG.

The working party has met on two occasions since September. It is due to report to the next meeting of the Australian Minerals and Energy Council, and I assure the honourable member for Hunter and the House that this Government will continue to work with the States to achieve greater uniformity of regulations for the use of LPG.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: CAPE YORK PENINSULA: PROPOSED SPACE FACILITY

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Science and Small Business. Can the Minister inform the House whether there are any further developments in proposals for a spaceport on the Cape York Peninsula?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —Now that the Premier of Queensland has gone into orbit, the whole question will need to be re-examined. The Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce is currently examining the reports of the latest studies on the Cape York Peninsula proposal. It would be premature for me to comment on the technical or economic viability of the proposal until we know a good deal more.

ANSWER.PARA: As I have remarked on a number of occasions, a precondition to setting up a spaceport would be to establish not only the technical viability but also the economics to find out how much of the anticipated market for the 1990s it could attract. Due to the wide range of Commonwealth responsibilities affected by the proposal, Commonwealth agreement would be necessary before the proposal could be implemented. That is because treaty engagements would have to be entered into for liability and other important issues.

Of course, there have been suggestions that the Commonwealth could become a participant in the proposed spaceport or in some way assist its establishment, but until the costs and the benefits of the proposal have been thoroughly examined, that suggestion is slightly premature. I took the opportunity to talk to the aerospace technical centre in Sao Jose dos Campos Brazil a couple of weeks ago because a very large rocket launching facility is being constructed at Alcantara in Brazil, only two degrees south of the Equator. The great advantage of having a rocket site close to the Equator is that the closer it is the smaller amount of fuel is needed to get a satellite of a given size into orbit. In other words, the further away from the Equator, the smaller the payload.

Cape York is 12 degrees south of the Equator while Alcantara is two degrees south. Nevertheless, there are other factors that seem to point in Queensland's direction. Firstly, Alcantara is an area with a lot of lightning strikes and very intense winds. I understand at Cape York the incidence of lightning and heavy winds is much less serious. There is still a window of opportunity and it needs to be looked at seriously. But it is not an easy issue. Unless we can attract something between one-quarter and one-third of the likely worldwide traffic for sending up very large satellites it is difficult to see that it would be economically a goer. It is something to which we will be paying very close attention.

Will the Minister guarantee that existing nursing homes in smaller isolated rural communities will not be disadvantaged as a result of changes to government funding arrangements?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the honourable member is probably aware, the majority of nursing homes in the country benefited from the first stage of the rearrangement of nursing home funding. We recognise that there have been problems with some of the smaller nursing homes. My departmental officers have been involved in consultation in those matters. This morning I met with members of the Australian Voluntary Care Association to discuss the whole issue of funding the nursing home area. We are engaged in a major reform proposal which will extend over several years. That transition is designed to last several years in order to cope with any of the problems that inevitably occur in a transformation of the system of this order.

ANSWER.PARA: I believe most of the nursing home organisations in this country agree with the Government that the direction in which we are moving is desirable for the old people in their care. But I do recognise that the changes are fairly massive and it is important to address the particular problems that will occur along that transition phase. That is one of the reasons we are extending the program over a considerable period.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support. The Minister will recall the Government Press release of 18 March 1987 in which it was stated that millions of dollars of taxpayers' money would be wasted on a contract for coastal surveillance by not accepting the lowest technically conforming tender. —I thank the honourable member for his question. I have had the opportunity of reviewing the findings of the Menzies review which was tabled in this House on, I think, 19 November. As honourable members will know, the review was carried out by Mr Andrew Menzies, a former Deputy Secretary to the Attorney-General's Department, a Mr Stan Perry and a Mr Barry Slingo, who are both serving assistant secretaries drawn from departments not involved with the letting of this contract. However, they have special responsibilities in the area of contract administration. In essence, they found that there was no evidence indicating corruption or other illegal conduct by any officer of the Commonwealth.
—Madam Speaker, I raise a point of order. Would the Minister like me to read the question again?
—The honourable member will resume his seat and the House will come to order while the Minister answers the question.

—They also determined that had a more skilled and comprehensive investigation been carried out of Mr Amann's financial capacity and other capacities, competence to perform the contract for its full life and his costings, there would have been sufficient reason to put the tender aside.
—So the Minister failed in his duty.

—If the right honourable member will just listen he will hear further in relation to the question in a moment. —My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. —Come on, Julian!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beale Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Okay, Mick. Have you read this savage indictment of the Government? Have you read about the incompetent mob over there?
—Order! The honourable member will speak through the Chair.
—Just listen to the rabble. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House censures the Minister for Resources in the exercise of his former responsibilities as Minister for Transport and Minister for Aviation in that he:
(1) Failed to exercise proper Ministerial standards;
(2) Misled the House and the Australian public over the circumstances associated with the Amann Coastal Surveillance Contract;
(3) Failed adequately to supervise his Department in that he did not require full responses to difficulties raised in questions in the House; and
(4) Ignored his Parliamentary and Ministerial responsibilities by pursuing his own personal sympathies for the preferred tenderer against his obligations to the Australian public.

The Opposition brings before the House today this censure motion against the Minister for Resources (Mr Peter Morris) for his abject failure to exercise proper ministerial standards over the Amann Aviation Pty Ltd coastal surveillance contract when he was the Minister for Transport and Aviation, and for misleading the House on that matter. The final report of the Review of Tender Procedures for the Coastwatch Contract prepared under the chairmanship of Mr Menzies is an extraordinary document and a savage indictment of the performance of Ministers in this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!

—The honourable member has not read it. That is what he has not done. If he had read the report he would have seen how the report criticises the incompetence of this Government. The report is critical of two Ministers who acted for the Minister, it is critical of the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) and it is critical of the Cabinet office. My colleague the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown), in supporting me in this censure motion, will spend some time talking about the whole shemozzle and the complete incompetence of this Government. In terms of the report being critical of Ministers, in terms of the report identifying failures in administration and in terms of the report detailing the functioning of departments, the one Minister whose incompetence shines out is the Minister for Resources, who was then the Minister for Transport and Aviation.

SPEECH.PARA: In a report commissioned in 1986 by this Parliament, David Solomon had the following to say about ministerial responsibility:

At the core of the concept of responsible government is the term ministerial responsibility. Ministerial responsibility concerns amongst other things the relationship between a Minister and his colleagues, both individually and collectively, when they are in Cabinet; and the responsibility that individual members have to the Parliament. Ministers are responsible for actions by their departmental officers in the sense of being liable to be held to account for them.

There is no question of the Minister for Resources not understanding fully the concept of ministerial responsibility. He may well seek to avoid being called to account in the matter of the Amann Coastwatch fiasco, but he certainly understands ministerial responsibility. In a speech to this House on 27 October 1981, the Minister commended the Joint Committee of Public Accounts for its thoroughness in producing a report and assessing departmental performance, public expenditure and ministerial responsibility. In the course of that speech he said-this was in 1981:
The Parliament was misled in statements made by the Minister to the Parliament.

They were prophetic words that today will come back to haunt this Minister. The Minister for Resources understands all about ministerial responsibility, and he understands that Ministers fail in that responsibility when they mislead the Parliament and the Australian people. The Minister for Resources, who was then the Minister for Transport, said in a Press release of 18 March 1987:

The Federal Government would be irresponsible if it allowed millions of dollars of taxpayers' money to be wasted on a contract for coastal surveillance by not accepting the lowest technically conforming tender.

Today we heard from the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support (Mr Duncan) another weaselling answer to the question raised by the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) on this matter. In this last quotation, the Minister for Resources was discussing the coastal surveillance contract which had, a week before 18 March, been awarded to Amann Aviation. But this is not what the Menzies report says. The Menzies report specifically states that the Amann tender was incomplete and failed to provide other information, including a statement of compliance required under the tender. The Menzies report says that the Commonwealth purchasing manual suggests that the Amann tender should have been ruled informal.

The Minister clearly misled the Australian people. He said that Amann was the lowest technically conforming tender, whereas the Menzies report makes it clear that not only was it incomplete and did not conform, but also it should have been ruled informal. The Minister--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a clear conflict.

—We have not got to the end of it. This is a lot of fun-or it would be if it were not such a tragic matter that honourable members opposite put at risk Australia's northern coastal surveillance. The Minister went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: The tender process, set down in strict government guidelines, had been scrupulously adhered to.

These words used by the Minister are worth repeating. He said that the tender process had been `scrupulously adhered to'. Let us see what the Menzies report has to say about the tender process. The Menzies report devotes 40 of its 80 pages to that issue. The whole question of the tender process takes up half of the document. The criticisms the report makes of the tender process are so widespread and so detailed as to preclude the possibility that the Minister did not know of this fiasco taking place in his own Department under his own eyes. It is worth while quoting from some of the findings that the Menzies report made on the tender process. It said that Amann's capacity-financial and otherwise-and competence to perform the contract for its full life should have been included in a thorough investigation. It said that the investigation failed to bring to notice errors and other deficiencies in Amann's financial statements. It said:
. . . if Amann's costings had been competently investigated-
I stress the word `competently'-
the result would have been to cast considerable doubt on Amann's financial and administrative competence.

TALK.START.PARA: —Didn't the Minister insist on that?

—The Minister will have a chance to answer for himself on this when he answers this censure motion. The Menzies report raised the question of whether the services of a specialist financial investigator should have been obtained from the Department, elsewhere in the Public Service or from a private consultant. It said that `this is normal practice for high value, complex Government contracts'. It said that the assessment of tenders had proceeded:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . under a basic misconception as to the approach to be adopted and the criteria to be applied in dealing with tenders for contracts of this nature.
The Menzies report said:
. . . a full and competent evaluation of matters, other than technical compliance of tenders does not appear to have been undertaken.
It is said that the Department did not exercise sufficient supervision of this matter. The report said:
. . . repeated approaches to Amann for financial and technical information should have alerted them-
that is, the Department-
to the fact that either the tender document-
we are back dealing with the tender document-
or the tender or both were deficient.
The Menzies report said that reports:
. . . were not accompanied by detailed analysis in accordance with normal cost investigations and financial reporting procedures;

I have spent the last few minutes telling the House what the Menzies report said about what the Minister has described as the tender process having been `scrupulously adhered to'. With this extraordinary litany of criticisms of the tender process, is it any wonder that we are seeking to censure this Minister for his appalling performance on this matter? The Minister, in his Press release of 18 March 1987, went on to say:

The tender committee was satisfied that the successful tenderer had sound financial backing, fully understood the requirements of the contract on offer, had made realistic provision for costs and that it had the necessary arrangements in hand to enable an early start up.
In view of what the Menzies report had to say, that statement by the Minister grossly deceives the Australian people about this important contract for Australia's northern coastal surveillance.

Let me tell the House what the then Minister for Territories, the honourable member for Corio (Mr Scholes), who was Acting Minister for Transport, said when he announced the letting of the contract to Amann on 12 March. He said:

Because of our largely unpopulated northern coastline, aerial coastal surveillance is a vitally important part of the Federal Government's watch for breaches of Australian laws, particularly those concerning drug smuggling, animal and plant quarantine, oil pollution at sea and unlicensed fishing in Australian waters by foreign fishing vessels.

If the Acting Minister at the time thought the Coastwatch contract was so important and given what the Menzies report has to say about the tender process, the statements by the Minister for Resources constitute not only a gross deception of the Australian people but also an extraordinary dereliction of duty. The Minister for Resources went on to say on 12 March:
The aircraft to be imported are already being fitted out.

That is not what the Menzies report states. On 19 February Amann asked the Department whether he could use a different kind of aircraft for coastal surveillance from that specified in his tender. He was told he could do so. From that date the Department was on notice that Amann proposed to use a different type of aircraft from that specified in his tender. Senator Evans said in the Senate Estimates hearings on 19 October that the aircraft type change was not brought to the attention of the Department until 23 April. It is not appropriate in this place to attempt to determine what the motives of Senator Evans were in making his statement, but it is sufficient that the Menzies report stated that on 7 May Amann advised the Department that he was purchasing a different kind of aircraft from that specified in his tender. On 19 February the Department was on notice that Amann intended to change its aircraft and it did so somewhere between 23 April and 7 May. How, then, can the Minister have said on 18 March that the aircraft to be imported `are already being fitted out'? The way in which the Minister misled the House and the Australian people on this Coastwatch contract is beyond belief.

Some time before 2 March 1987-that is, 10 days before the contract was awarded to Amann-as part of the process leading up to the Cabinet submission seeking approval for expenditure of amounts necessary to award the coastal surveillance contract, which approval, incidentally, should have been obtained from Cabinet prior to the calling of tenders, as the Menzies report points out, the Department of Transport advised the Minister, in writing, according to the Menzies report:

The Department of Aviation observes that the preferred tenderer is not the holder of an air service licence and does not as yet possess aircraft, personnel or other facilities necessary under the contract.

It went on to say that there was a risk that that could lead to delay in the commencement of operations. This was the commencement of operations to protect Australia's northern coastline. The Minister knew, therefore, before the submission to Cabinet, of the Department of Aviation's advice, and he got it in writing. He knew it before he said on 18 March:
It would have been an abrogation of this Government's responsibility to have overturned a decision of an expert tender panel and to have awarded the contract to a more expensive tenderer.
The Minister knew this when he answered a question from the honourable member for Murray on 7 May 1987. He said in his answer:

There was no legitimate reason, after consideration of the tenders received and the procedures followed, why the contract should not have been awarded to Amann. If he wants a rigged tender process he will not get it from this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have heard in my days some weak and pathetic defences by Ministers, but that must surely take the prize. SPEECH.PARA: There are three reasons why this Minister should be censured by this motion. The first is that there was, as has been revealed by the Menzies Review of Tender Procedures for the Coastwatch Contract, the most damning indictment of public administration that this country has ever seen. If anyone under our system of government is to be held responsible for that, it must be the Minister. It is the Minister for Resources, as he now is, who must on any test carry all the responsibility for the series of bungles which was revealed over this contract by the Menzies report. Secondly, it is the very principle itself, because this Department has abandoned all the principles of ministerial responsibility. I could not believe what I was reading the other day when I read the Senate Hansard report of the words of the great luminary, Senator Evans, who was doing what he could to defend himself on these charges. This is what he said about ministerial responsibility:
. . . these days there is no foundation whatsoever for any claim for resignation on the ground of individual ministerial responsibility.

Members of this Government are writing the rules to suit their own convenience, and they have abandoned the basis of the whole system of ministerial responsibility that we operate under-and how different it was when they were in opposition. The Minister for Resources in his pathetic defence went back to the events of 1982 and said that the issue of the extent of ministerial responsibility was being discussed then. What view did the Australian Labor Party take of that principle in 1982? Labor members said, and it was set out clearly on a number of occasions by the then Leader of the Opposition and by the the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate and present Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button.

Let us look, because time prevents our going over all the evidence, at what Senator Button said when he gave consideration to how that principle should be applied. He said that there were three rules. He said that if the Minister knew of incompetence in his Department and that incompetence was proved then he should resign. And how right he was. But Senator Button went further and said that if the Minister did not know, then he should have known; he should have been making inquiries because he was responsible for the sound running of his Department, and if his Department was not being run properly then the Minister should have found out about it.

A Minister is not just there to sit like a stuffed dummy, as the Minister for Resources seems to suggest, to put plugs in his ears and not hear. He is there to ask questions. He is there because he is paid as a Minister on behalf of the people to ask questions. He is there to put public servants under the hammer and under scrutiny. He did not do that. Senator Button laid down even a third principle. He said that even if the Minister could not be expected to know what was going on, if the scandal was of a great magnitude the Minister should resign. To return to Senator Evans's words, this Government has said that all those rules go out the window. Forget this ministerial responsibility; there is no such thing. There is no obligation on a Minister to resign simply because he has messed up, to a substantial extent, the administration of his Department. There is no responsibility at all, according to this Government. I would like the Leader of the House (Mr Young)-or whoever stands up next-to tell us whether this really is the Government's position or whether there is still some shred of respect given here for the principle of ministerial responsibility.

I go back again to 1982 and those examples that were given. What did the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce say about Mr Nixon because of the so-called meat scandal? He said that he should resign and the only reason he gave was that he was responsible for those bodies within his ministerial responsibility. The Minister pressed for Mr Nixon's resignation simply because he was the Minister. What has happened to that grand principle these days? What did that great paragon of ministerial principle and propriety, the present Leader of the House and Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, say? What lofty principle did he lay down then? This is what he said:
Nothing is more important than the way in which these people who are called Ministers behave themselves and set an example to other people in Australia.

If that was the principle then it should be the principle now. If this principle of ministerial responsibility has any shred of standing left in it so far as this Government is concerned, the Government should stand as one and say that this Minister should go. If it does not stand and say that this Minister should go, then it has no right to take part in this democratic process that is the foundation of our system of government.

The third point is-and one can go into the details later-that there was a complete and utter shambles when this matter was taken to the Hawke Cabinet. I will tell honourable members what happened. The Minister who is being censured today did not even bother to attend that Cabinet meeting. What was he doing when this major matter involving $17m of expenditure was before Cabinet? Today I had a look to see where he was. He was wandering around investigating the shipyards in Shanghai and forging close transport relationships between China and Australia. That is what he was doing on the day this matter went to Cabinet. Did he leave behind proper instructions as to how this matter should be handled? Of course not. He gave it to the then Acting Minister, the honourable member for Corio (Mr Scholes), and asked him to look after it. He then went off to China to have a look at the shipyards and the airports there.

Unfortunately, Mr Scholes was ill on that day; so what did Cabinet members do? Did they put it off because it was a major matter? After all, one would have thought that the surveillance of our coastline was pretty important. Ministerial Press releases seem to indicate that it is. Did they put it off or call some people in to give them some advice? No, they threw it to the present Minister for Trade Negotiations (Mr Duffy). They probably gave it to him as he came in the door and said `All right, Mike, look after this will you. We do not know what it is about, but look after it'. That is the way it was handled. As I understand it-and this point has not been made as yet at any stage in the course of public discussion on this issue-the Cabinet submission that went forward to the members of the Hawke Cabinet warned them about the dangers of letting this contract to Amann Aviation Pty Ltd. The Department of Aviation was asked for co-ordination comments which it gave. Those comments ended up in the Cabinet submission; they were there to see for any Minister who wanted to take his eyes off the racing guide, Pix or People or whatever Ministers were reading in the Cabinet on that day. The submission stated:
Aviation-
that is, the Department of Aviation-
notes-
one would think that the word `notes' would catch their attention-
that the preferred tenderer is not the holder of an air service licence . . .
Cabinet was told in the co-ordination comments, `The preferred tenderer does not have a licence-but do not let that deter you'. The submission goes on:
. . . the preferred tenderer . . . does not as yet possess aircraft, personnel or other facilities necessary under the contract.

Do Cabinet members not read Cabinet submissions? It was not only that it was put in front of them; it was not only that it should have been a red light standing out to warn them about what they were doing, but the Department had also thoughtfully prepared a briefing note which set out exactly the same thing. Both documents said the same thing to the Minister who walked off, clutching his Cabinet submission under his arm as he headed down to the Cabinet ante room for a cup of tea before starting on that day's weighty business. They both said that this outfit, which incidentally changed its name from Myruse Pty Ltd-that is what Mr Amann very appropriately called his company which is a two-bob shelf company; Ministers had not even inquired about that-did not have any aeroplanes, hangars or facilities. It did not employ anyone and it had not had any experience. It had not got a licence.

How many members are there in the Cabinet? Are there 12, 13 or 14? The most competent ministry in the history of this country-so we are all told-could not even read that submission. It is not only the Minister for Resources; but it is also all of those who turned a blind eye of ignorance to this whole matter. They were warned and they were told, but they went ahead irrespective of that advice and awarded this contract. The Minister should not come in here and say, with this cowardly defence, that he did not know and that they did not tell him. That defence will not wash at all. He was warned, he was told and he had adequate notice but did nothing about it whatsoever. He stands condemned for presiding over what is undoubtedly the greatest administrative shemozzle in the history of this country. Even if that were not so and even if the Minister had not been warned, he stands condemned and should be censured because he was presiding over a fiasco. He was not presiding over what Senator Evans, with his glib style, called a systems failure. It was not a systems failure. It was a system of bungles, one after the other, over which this Minister presided. He was personally responsible for it. When he went away to Shanghai he did not leave proper instructions for other Ministers and they all stand condemned because they were warned. Finally if this principle of ministerial responsibility means anything at all, this Minister should be censured.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to stand here and defend the actions of the Minister for Resources (Mr Peter Morris) who is the subject of this censure motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a new doctrine.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to quote to the Parliament a couple of things from the Menzies report which relate to Minister Morris's involvement in this matter. On page 59, under the heading `Observations and Comments', paragraph 1 states:

The submission to the Minister should have disclosed that Amann had limited experience in the aviation industry, he did not have an organization in existence and, while he stated that he had made arrangements to acquire the necessary aircraft from overseas, he did not at that date own any of the required aircraft. The information in fact provided including the information provided to the Minister a few days earlier in relation to the Cabinet Submission was insufficient to alert the Minister to any of these matters nor, of course, to the unreliability of the costings investigation.

There it is. The Menzies report clearly indicates that Minister Morris in those circumstances did not have information before him which would have enabled him to make any other judgment. On page 73, finding 12 states:

Information put before Ministers in relation to the Cabinet Submission seeking funds authorization and the submission seeking authority under regulation 48 (c) of the Finance Regulations to enter into the contract with Amann did not reveal either the facts set out in (4) or the unreliability of the financial investigation described in (6).

That sets out pretty clearly the Menzies view of Minister Morris's involvement. That is the view that we on this side have always held-that it was an administrative exercise which went wrong. The reason we set up the Menzies inquiry was quite specifically to seek advice on what procedures should be implemented in the future in relation to the Coastwatch contract to ensure that the tender process can continue to operate at arm's length from the Minister, but with much upgraded administrative arrangements to ensure that the contract, when it is subsequently let, will be let properly and that the administration will be carried out effectively.

I want to deal with just a couple of other matters which are important in the context of the suggestions that have been made that in some way the matter involved some breach of ministerial responsibility. It is very interesting to refer to things said previously by others. I refer to the 1983 report of the Committee of Review of Commonwealth Administration, which states:

At the outset, we shall try to dispose of one myth. When ministerial responsibility is discussed in Australia, many assert that in the United Kingdom ministers automatically, regularly, or often resign when there are acts of maladministration by their departments, allegedly amounting to a convention of resignation.

This is a fallacy. As Appendix 8 demonstrates, this has never really been a convention in the UK. Indeed, we have not been able to identify (in well over 100 years) a single case that can properly and confidently be claimed as a resignation for that reason.

It is also interesting to note that, even in the 1954 Crichel Down case involving the resignation of Sir John Dugdale, which has been regarded by others as an example of just that instance, it is not so regarded by Mr Reid, the person who wrote the report of the Committee of Review of Commonwealth Administration. He said:

Ministers-in Australia as well as in the UK-have of course proffered resignations for a wide range of reasons, such as personal actions or indiscretions, misleading of the Parliament, policy failures, policy differences with colleagues, and so on. But they raise quite different issues from the handling of cases of maladministration by a department.

There we have it. The situation is patently obvious: in the circumstances such as we have in this matter, according to precedent, the issue of the resignation of the Minister should not even arise. That shows what an empty sham this motion which has been put before the Parliament today really is.
