TALK.START.PARA: —Although the terms of the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill 1987 are complex and, some might think, somewhat turgid, effecting as they do mainly mechanical and procedural alterations to the legislation, they do contain a number of provisions which are interesting and deserve comment. In particular, I draw the attention of the House to the provisions in relation to the Acts Interpretation Act 1901. The Acts Interpretation Act is a provision of statute law which is intended to assist those who are given the responsibility of interpreting Commonwealth legislation guides to that interpretation process. Over the years provisions have been inserted in the Acts Interpretation Act to ensure that judges and administrators are better able to carry out the intention of the Parliament. Of course, one of the great criticisms of the legislative forms of this House and many other parliaments has been that they are written in extraordinarily complex language-language which is difficult, unattractive and not accessible to even the educated reader.

SPEECH.PARA: The Office of Parliamentary Counsel is currently looking to remedy some of those defects and is actively pursuing a policy of simplifying the language that is used in drafting statutes. That is a very major job which can be undertaken only over a long period. Inevitably it means that statutes will be significantly altered in terms of the manner of their expression. The words that are used to express the will of the Parliament will be changed quite significantly. They will be made simpler and accessible so that an ordinary educated reader can at least have some clear understanding of what the Parliament intended. There is, however, a problem in that in the past judges have assumed, as a matter of assistance to them in their understanding of the intention of Parliament, that, where there was a change in the way a provision was expressed, Parliament probably intended to change the effect of the legislation. So, if a judge was seeking to apply the test of what was meant by the Parliament when it expressed a provision in new language, it would assume that the Parliament was trying to do something different from what it had done in the past.

That presents a problem to the parliamentary draftsman, because, in the process of taking the very admirable course that he has set out upon-that is, of expressing our statutes more clearly and more simply-obviously there must be significant change to many provisions in older legislation. So the Acts Interpretation Act is to be amended to make sure that mere changes of style are not interpreted as being intended to convey different meanings in substance. What this means is that, when a new provision expresses an idea in new language in an Act which already contains a similar idea but expressed in older, more technical, more complex style, the court should assume first that the new language is not intended to convey a different meaning.

So the proposed new section 15a will add a general provision in the Act to ensure that the courts do apply this very new policy in their treatment of the intention of the Parliament, so that when the language is brought up to date and made more accessible it is not understood by the courts as being intended to convey a different meaning.

Also necessary to help the courts and the public to understand the meaning of the legislature are provisions relating to the words `may' and `shall'. These words have in the past been a lawyer's delight, because when the courts have had occasion to interpret provisions they have always had to grapple with whether or not the intention of the draftsman, in expressing language in a particular way, was that something must occur or was discretionary. The problem arose of the words `may' and `shall' having been used somewhat interchangeably in the past. This has forced the courts to find on a number of occasions that the word `may' actually did mean shall and that the word `shall' actually meant may. So we had a problem in terms of the ordinary person reading legislation not being able to perceive straight away the intention of the legislature.

One would have thought that this is a matter of common sense. But until now the courts have had this difficulty and it will be remedied by this Bill's insertion of these new provisions in the Act. Out of caution it had become necessary in legislation to follow the word `may' with the words `at the court's discretion', `at the judge's discretion' or some similar words. This is obviously cumbersome and Parliamentary Counsel now has adopted an invariable practice of using the word `shall' only when the Parliamentary Draftsman, and the Parliament, intend that an action is mandatory, and using the word `may' only when Parliament is expressing the intention that an action is discretionary. Given that this new drafting model has been adopted and will be adopted invariably into the future, a new provision is inserted, proposed new section 32 (2A), to apply to Acts which are assented to after the amendment to ensure that such an interpretation shall be followed in the future. That will make it much easier for people reading Acts to understand precisely what was intended by the Parliament and what the drafting of new Bills comprehends.

The third point about the Acts Interpretation Act that should attract the attention of the House is that it continues the process of removing sexist language from the statutes. That practice is also reflected in another provision of the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill. I refer, of course, to the amendments to the Australian Security Intelligence Organization Act 1979, whereby sexist language is removed. But, more generally, in the Acts Interpretation Act there will be a provision that, in the establishment of an office of chairperson, the person who holds that office may be called either chairman or chairwoman as the case requires. Proposed new section 18B will put this provision into the Act.

So the package of provisions that relate to the Acts Interpretation Act will be very useful. Although they are fairly straightforward and simple, they will go a long way to making sure that our legislation is cleaned up and made more simple and more accessible. They will help us in terms of our public relations, because one of the chief complaints of the public has always been that the language which has been used by Parliamentary Counsel, and adopted, of course, by parliamentarians in this House, is just too unnecessarily complex, unnecessarily turgid and unnecessarily legalistic.

Having mentioned those provisions in relation to the Acts Interpretation Act I draw attention to one other provision that deserves some comment which relates to the National Measurement Act. The proposed amendments to this Act seek to put into effect finally the new metric system. In almost all areas of our daily life metrics have taken over. Old-fashioned people such as I who grew up learning about feet and inches are gradually having to comprehend the new order where currency is decimalised and weights and measures are metricated. We simply have to come to terms with these new changes. In almost every area of our life people have got used to the metric system; litres are used in measuring petrol and decimal currency is in vogue.

But in one area the non-metric measurements persist and that is in the measurements relating to land and the like. We still talk in terms of acres. Often in ordinary language we use feet and inches or miles rather than metres and centimetres or kilometres. The Government is seeking to consolidate the progress that has been made towards decimalisation, towards the use of metric measurements.

The Government originally intended to make a clear prohibition on the expression of measurements in any contracts for the sale of land to be expressed other than in metric measurements. The way that was intended to be carried out was by declaring void any such contract that was written in non-metric terms. The problem with that approach was that the contract of an innocent party-say, a farmer who wrote to another farmer seeking to make a contract to buy a few acres of land at the bottom of the farm, and who exchanged correspondence relating to those acres-would be void. Considerable injustice might have been done to innocent parties.

Following discussions within the Government and, in particular, within the Caucus legal committee, the Government has changed its approach in relation to this issue. Whilst it still will be proceeding with provisions that ensure that in the future all contracts in relation to the sale of land or interests in land must be expressed in metric measurements, it has not maintained the drastic and draconian effect that would have occurred if contracts expressed in non-metric terms were made void. Instead, it has prohibited, under pain of penalty-the maximum fine being $500-the expressing of such contracts in non-metric measurements.

That will have the substantial effect that the Government intended. It will mean that law societies and the like will draft all standard form contracts from now on in metric measurements and that all those practising daily conveyancing will use metric measurements. That will clearly carry through the Government's intention in this area, but it will not have the rather awesome but unintended effect of meaning that the contracts of those innocent individuals who do not have professional legal skills and who choose innocently to express themselves in non-metric language when forming their contracts will be void and therefore capable of being struck down at any time in the future with perhaps arbitrary and harsh results. The Government has responded to the concerns of Government back bench members in this regard and has proposed an amendment which I understand the Minister will be moving at a later stage in this debate.

Although there is a multitude of provisions in a Bill such as this which are designed essentially to clear up a number of technical problems which require attention but which, in a sense, do not involve great matters of substance, there are quite interesting provisions which go a long way towards simplifying and clarifying the organisation of the legal system. I commend the provisions to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am surprised to hear the honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr) in his opening remarks make comments which suggest that this omnibus Bill, the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill, somehow contains essentially machinery measures. I was somewhat reassured by his subsequent remarks that indicated that the provisions were a little more serious than he at first indicated.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill sets out to amend 87 different Acts as well as to repeal another 24. Of the Acts to be amended it might be said that there are two main categories. The first category includes those which the Government wants changed for specific, albeit arguable, reasons. The second category which involves some 30 Acts out of the 87 is worthy of some comment. Each of those 30 Acts are to be in whole or in part amended for one of the following reasons: Because of a need for a formal drafting amendment; to make the language in the Act gender neutral; or in one case to correct an oversight; or in another to correct five errors in cross-referencing-and that in a fairly recent Bill that came before the House.

It seems that the terms `formal drafting amendment' and `correct an oversight' are euphemisms for mistakes in the legislation which are not picked up when a Bill appears in this House for debate. In time honoured bureaucratic style it would be too much, it seems, for people involved in drafting the original legislation to admit to a simple, if not excusable, mistake. But no, apparently it sounds better to term mistakes as oversights or more commonly as needing formal drafting amendments, thereby avoiding any acknowledgment of fallibility on the part of those responsible.

I intend to remark on what that also says about us as members of parliament a little later. Before I do so I briefly note the time and resources involved in amending Acts to make the wording gender neutral. I would have thought that it is hardly necessary to waste time and money on that sort of nonsense. Surely, the old legal axiom that the male gender shall automatically apply to females and vice versa already applies. Apparently, the Australian Bureau of Statistics does not think so because it sees the compelling need to go to great lengths to amend the Australian Bureau of Statistics Act 1975. Some 16 or more sections or sub-sections in its principal Act are to be amended by these measures to make the words gender neutral, who knows for what worthwhile purpose.

I would have thought that the Bureau, the Government and this Parliament had better things to do. Although I am bound to offend some people who have strong feelings on the subject of what they perceive to be the neutrality of gender in real life or in language, I reiterate that these changes involve many people with better and more productive things to do. If all departments and statutory authorities indulge in the same thought processes as the Australian Bureau of Statistics, the next omnibus Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill will be equally prolific-even more so, I suspect.

In returning to the 30 or so amendments to the Acts that are necessary because of basic or elementary errors in drafting which I have described, it is at least arguable that amendments would be largely avoidable if the Parliament were given an opportunity to examine and debate proposed legislation without exception. The truth is-and I have raised this subject on more than one occasion-that the House and to a lesser extent the Senate are effectively deprived of the opportunity to examine and debate Bills thoroughly. While we may legitimately claim under the circumstances that parliamentary draftsmen are the perpetrators of elementary mistakes in Bills we pass, the remedy rests with us. It is not quite that simple because the Government, by the use of the gag and its numbers in the House, is prepared to legislate on the basis of E and OE-that is, errors and omissions excepted-and to hell with the consequences. In turn, that is the logical outcome of the increasing tendency of the Government to legislate by Press release and then to rely unduly on legislation in the Acts Interpretation Act. In this approach is to be found the formula for the sloppy procedures in government that we see so much in evidence these days. Whilst it may be reasonably presumed that drafting errors will occur, and we will not pick up all of them, the extent identified in this Bill is indefensible. Although after the election in 1984 the numbers of members and senators in the House and the Senate were increased by about 20 per cent, and although the number of Bills introduced has since increased, the time available for their consideration by the Parliament has remained essentially the same. As we approach the Christmas break we will no doubt see the Government ruthlessly apply its numbers to curtail debates on Bills, to the undoubted detriment of the parliamentary process. It can safely be predicted that the Leader of the House (Mr Young) will-as he did today in negativing a discussion on a matter of public importance-on behalf of his Government trot out the lame and time-worn, and therefore lamentable, excuse that application of the gag in the House is necessary because the Senate is adamant that it will not consider Bills unless they appear on its Notice Paper before a certain date. It has become a ritual of rhetoric, with little to commend it, and even less by way of justification. The inevitable outcome will in future be more and more statute law miscellaneous provisions Bills due to the so-called formal drafting mistakes, oversights and the like. A not so obvious outcome will be the erosion of the relevance of the House in the legislative process and a greater reliance on the Senate and its committees to identify simple but avoidable errors in Bills.

Of the 87 Acts in the Bill under consideration, three or four merit consideration in isolation. Those which I would identify are, amendments to the Audit Act 1901, the National Measurement Act 1960 and the Navigation Act 1912. Each of these is worthy of consideration and debate separately, and not as part of an omnibus Bill. In other words, separate Bills should be brought before the Parliament. Others, such as amendments to the Exports Control Act 1982 and related amendments, should also be debated separately, albeit it cognately, being both important and complex. Whether or not the device of including far reaching and important proposals to change laws and correct avoidable drafting errors is part of a deliberate intention to deny the opportunity for parliamentary debate, it certainly has that affect. With at least three or four of the series of amendments before the House deserving of separate and detailed consideration, we are no longer left to wonder how the Executive Government can further erode the influence of this chamber and the elected representatives in it from both sides. The outcome is that only in the Senate, where the Government does not have the ability arrogantly to use its superior numbers, is there opportunity for elected representatives to carry out their legislative duty, as distinct from purely political duty.

Because of factors mentioned, and given the ridiculous fact that speaking time on amendments to 87 Acts is limited to a total of 20 minutes in this second reading debate, I now turn to the proposals to amend the Audit Act 1901. It is proposed, firstly, to substitute a new section 32. The reasons given for excluding the Governor-General from the process of certifying warrants prior to the appropriate amounts being dispersed are eminently sensible. However, to remove the Auditor-General from the procedure may not be. Certainly the Government's assertion that `the involvement of the Auditor-General in the issuing of appropriated amounts . . . is also inappropriate and contrary to the modern concepts of the independence of the Auditor-General' is more than hard to swallow. The proposal will be of detriment to the authority, and therefore to the independence of the Auditor-General, and not the other way around, as might be supposed if one reads the words of the Government.

Whilst it may be administratively sound to give unfettered power to the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) to certify payment of appropriated amounts, it has all the hallmarks of a matter of convenience and not one arising out of consideration for the Auditor-General and the role he is bound to play.

Proposed amendments to section 34 also come into this category. These amendments envisage the use of electronic signatures to permit an officer to certify future payments. It seems that the present requirements place `an unnecessary constraint on the use of computer-based systems for processing accounts by departments'. The present system also provides internal checks and balances in requiring payments to be certified in writing, and hence facilitates subsequent audits. These are not to be replaced, it seems, and we are left to wonder whether there will be any safeguards at all, and if so, what will be the form of those safeguards against inefficiency and possible fraud. There is a body of opinion along the lines that sophisticated computer-based systems merit equally sophisticated safeguards and audit techniques which, if they exist, we have not been told about.

It is also proposed to repeal section 48h. An entity other than a department will no longer have to pay for an efficiency audit conducted by the Auditor-General. That is fair enough, particularly if one is imposed rather than requested. It is a great shame, I think, that the Government does not apply the same principle to taxpayers in general, and fringe benefits taxpayers in particular. The enormous administration costs incurred by individuals in collecting taxes imposed and in answering or complying with bureaucratic demands for information make many taxpayers fair game and not protected from uncalled for costs, as will be government instrumentalities which are to benefit from the repeal of section 48h of the Audit Act.

It is also proposed to amend sub-section 49 (2), to give the Minister for Finance the authority to approve variations to the format of his future monthly statements. It will mean that the Minister and his Government will no longer need the prior approval of both Houses of Parliament. I am not sure whether that has changed. We have had amendments to the amendments, and an explanatory memorandum has been brought into the House today, and I am not sure whether that clause is still in the legislation or not. I am dealing with it as if it is.

I go on to point out that while the complimentary amendment to the sub-section is sub-section 49 (3), it will require the Minister to table explanations for future variations in the Parliament, but nevertheless we will be deprived of an opportunity to debate proposed changes before they are adopted. There is a great difference in the procedure which is now envisaged. This will see yet another victory by executive government over this Parliament.

Amendments proposed to section 51 of the Audit Act empower the Auditor-General to exercise a discretion to include or exclude mention in future reports of what are described as `details of inconsequential or trivial breaches of the Constitution or legislation'. This is hardly synonymous with the concept of glasnost, which the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) will have an opportunity to see first hand when he visits Moscow in a couple of weeks. Whilst I have the greatest faith in the Auditor-General and his office, it should be this Parliament which judges whether a breach of the Constitution of the Commonwealth of Australia is trivial. Deciding the significance of a discovered breach of our Constitution is not a matter for anyone other than members and senators. If, in the opinion of the Auditor-General, a breach of the Constitution is `minor and of little technical consequence, have the effect of detracting from the overall materiality of the report', as the rationale goes in the explanatory memorandum, the Auditor-General may be obliged to say so in his report. He may be able to say it is trivial. I do not want him judging for me-and honourable members in this House should not want him judging for them-whether a breach of the Constitution is trivial. That is what is needed. Not the granting of discretion, which could mean no reference at all to a discovered breach of the Constitution. After all, a breach by a government department, which the Auditor-General may judge to be `of little technical consequence', may be of great political importance. To me, the proposed amendment of section 51 is totally unacceptable as an individual, as a member of Parliament and as a representative.

As if to add to my discontent, the memorandum tells us that the proposed amendment offers us the little gem of being consistent with professional audit standards. What a lot of hogwash. If a company's auditors detected a breach of the articles or memorandum of association and did not report it, the wrath of those administering company laws would descend on them with a resounding thud. One should make no mistake about that. Proposed amendments to sections 63h and 63m are consequential and have the same effect as the proposed amendment to section 51. Future audit reports on some public authorities need not include `breaches of an authority's enabling legislation which are inconsequential or trivial'. We are again given an example to illustrate what is meant by that, which says that `if an unauthorised overdrawing of a bank account to the extent of $1 is found', it is not required to be reported. Well, it is easy to agree that $1 is trivial and insignificant-even more so under this Government given the value of our dollar overseas. Equally, $10 is insignificant. Are sums of $100 or $1,000 trivial? Is $10,000 trivial? A sum of $10,000 relative to the total budgets of most authorities is insignificant and trivial, but if an amount of a few hundred or a few thousand dollars goes astray, it may indicate sloppy management and sloppy accounting practices of great significance not in proportion to the sums of money involved.

Should not the Parliament have the duty to judge the significance of any identified breach of an authority's enabling legislation? If the Auditor-General is of the opinion that discovered breaches are indeed trivial, he can say so in his report. In fact, if there is more than one trivial breach, they could be listed-but listed in the report. The length of such a list might tell us more about the performance of an authority than would trivial or insignificant examples if considered in isolation. It is the number of mistakes that is often a warning to this Parliament. I do not care to leave the judgment of what is trivial and insignificant in this connection with the Auditor-General. To amend section 63p as proposed, there could arise some reservations about giving the executive government the power to request an audit of certain bodies. If such requests have the effect of making the Auditor-General divert his limited finite resources from other tasks, there is scope in that power for manipulation by a government. There is scope, deliberately or otherwise, to make sure that the more important and pressing work of the Auditor-General cannot proceed.

Despite soothing noises from the Government, and despite the scrutiny of two Senate committees, I have feelings about amendments proposed to the Audit Act which range from uneasiness to outright offence. The entire Bill, comprising amendments to all 87 Acts, is in itself an example of the supremacy of the executive government over tried and true parliamentary practice. The proposed amendments to the Audit Act give stark examples, and I have mentioned some of them. To include major and detailed amendments in an omnibus Bill such as this only emphasises the point about the supremacy of executive government. There is a lot to be learned about the way in which the government has legislated in this instance. I hope that I shall never have to get up in this House and talk about a similar Bill in these terms. Half of the provisions in this Bill should be in separate Acts of Parliament so that they are able to be given the complete consideration they deserve.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chynoweth Mr R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It gives me great pleasure to speak on the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill 1987. There are 87 Acts mentioned in this Bill, and I want to talk about just two. The Bill is written in formal and legalistic terms, but I want to take this opportunity to speak about the first Act, the National Water Resources Financial Assistance Act 1978. I want to talk about it in relation mainly to the electorate of Dunkley where water, which effects everyone's life in my electorate, is of such poor quality. First, I would like to read some things which have been written recently about the quality of Australian water.

SPEECH.PARA: Once upon a time we believed that water was the purest substance we could drink. Today, the odour, taste and colour of some water supplies in Australia make that sound like a very sick joke. Last year Australians drank almost 48 million litres of plain mineral water compared with 43 million litres in 1984, and about twice as much of the flavoured variety. People are doing that because of the quality of our water.

Before gulping down that next glass of water honourable members may care to reflect on what else they are swallowing along with it. Have honourable members ever looked into the bottom of an old kettle to see what has been left after years of use? It may be coated with chloroform, benzene, toluene, carbon tetrachloride, dichloromethane and bromo dichloromethane. Then there is phenol, hexachlorophene and polyvinyl chloride, with perhaps a sprinkle of dieldrin or DDT. And, finally, honourable members may even find a few asbestos fibres or polynuclear aromatic hydrocarbons that are by-products of coal-tar linings used in some old steel pipes. All these things can be found in our water.

In a recent test in various capital cities, three gentlemen were blindfolded, given glasses of water and asked to comment on them. They said that the water in Melbourne tasted disgusting and sweaty; in Adelaide it was swampy; in Brisbane it was like salty sand; Sydney water had a chlorine taste; the water in Canberra was good; and rainwater was said to have a terrific taste. Last year a State Government planning document entitled `Victoria, State of the Environment', raised as an important environmental issue the bacteriological and micro virological contamination of the domestic water supply in Victoria. Most domestic supplies consistently failed to meet World Health Organisation standards for bacteria levels. Outside Melbourne, only 7 per cent of town supplies complied with these standards at that time.

In February of this year I wrote to the Mornington Peninsula and District Water Board in relation to the quality of the water supplied not only to my constituents but also to me. I would like to read some of the correspondence which I have received from the Board. I have spoken to a large number of my constituents and their main complaint relates to water quality. The letter from the Board reads:
I refer to your letter dated 20 January 1987, in which you made reference to water quality problems observed by yourself . . .
They were also observed by a constituent of mine at Mornington. The letter continues:
In common with Water Authorities throughout the world, and in accordance with World Health Organisation guideline, the Board treats water with the following chemicals:

Sodium silicofluoride is added in accordance with the Health Act 1973 to raise a small amount of naturally occurring fluoride in the water to an optimum level of 0.9 parts per million that children need to develop resistance to tooth decay. Copper sulphate for the control of algae and other aquatic nuisances that can be toxic and cause taste, odour and colour. This treatment concentration is 0.5 parts per million and is carried out only when algae is visually detected . . . Lime to correct pH . . . Chlorine is used for disinfection of the water supply to remove the risk of water-borne diseases such as gastro-enteritis. It is normally added in the range of 1-3 ppm depending on the bacterial quality or chlorine demand of the raw water. The majority of the Board's chlorination plants utilise gaseous chlorine; the rest use Sodium Hypochlorite.

Ammonia is used in conjunction with chlorine at some chlorination plants. The ammonia is added at half the concentration of the chlorine to produce combined chlorine-ammonia compounds (monochloramines) which are less potent bacteriocides than chlorine alone, but remain longer in the water. These compounds are useful for treating long reticulation systems.
In your letter, you mentioned that you have noticed chlorine in the water supplied to your Frankston home.
This letter is directed to me in this case. I continue:

Generally speaking, the presence of chlorine should not be regarded as a deterioration in the water quality, but rather an improvement, as it indicates that a chlorine `residual' is present in the reticulation for protection against deterioration of bacterial water quality.

I would like to quote some words from Dr Alan Wade, who is Secretary of the National Health and Medical Research Council's Water Quality Control Committee. He describes trialomethanes such as chloroform and bromoform as `only the tip of the iceberg' and points out that chlorine reacts with organic matter to produce a vast array of compounds, about which not much is known. Those are some of the chemicals that are flowing down our pipes at the moment and going into our homes, not just on the Mornington Peninsula but all over Australia. I believe that the quality of the water that is supplied to Australia by our authorities is a disgrace.
I would like to read some other items of interests. A newspaper article states:

The $250 million Australian plastics industry is considering replacing lead in polyvinyl chloride (PVC) pipes with less dangerous compounds, following fears that our drinking water carried harmful amounts of lead.

The Secretary of the Federal Government's Water Quality Control Committee, Dr Alan Wade, says that the worst-case situation would be the poisoning of a new-born baby in a new housing estate. The lead comes from lead stearate added to PVC to make the pipes malleable. Unfortunately lead stearate leaches from pipes into the water-initially at a very rapid rate.
Even with industry complying strictly to official Australian standards, it is likely that PVC pipes could leach far greater amounts of lead into drinking water than allowed by health authorities.

All the chemicals that I have mentioned, plus lead, are going into our water supply. In my electorate one only has to boil a kettle and smell the steam to realise that something is wrong with that water. There is some residue left in the kettle. One of my constituents-whom I will not name-has been battling for many years with the Rural Water Commission and the Mornington Peninsula and District Water Board to get some sort of compensation for the actions they have taken to rectify the problem of the water supply in our area. To this stage the Mornington Peninsula and District Water Board has categorically refused to give compensation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Chair is concerned that the honourable member may be straying a little from the Bill. He should try to keep to the subject of the legislation if he can.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I was speaking to the section of the Bill which amends the National Water Resources (Financial Assistance) Act. I am speaking in that particular context, but I will get back to the Bill. As I was saying, the quality of water on the Mornington Peninsula is abysmal. I would describe it in one word: to me it is just disgusting. Even the inspectors of the Mornington Peninsula and District Water Board have installed rain water tanks for their own use. That shows how bad it is. I believe that instead of wasting money on a huge outlay in new buildings, flash cars and offices, the Board should be looking at the quality of our water and improving it. In relation to that section of the Bill that I have mentioned, my constituent has for many years complained about the water, and petitions have been taken up and submitted to the Board. As yet there has been no action. A professor has been appointed to look at the quality of the water. This professor, who is from the Queensland University, will analyse and check out the water to make certain that it does not contain bad chemical mixtures. This water is supplied to all the homes and, as I said, this affects everyone. Anything that affects all my constituents is of great concern to me. Water is like the air; it is a part of our environment that we can not do without and it should be looked at very closely. Some action must be taken immediately to rectify this problem.

SPEECH.PARA: In the short time that I have left, I turn to the other area of interest to me in the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill-that is, the part that relates to the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty Act 1986. I am very pleased to see that the United States and the Soviet Union have come together to sign this historic nuclear treaty. It is something that I personally would have liked to have seen some years ago. However, at long last it is coming about. It is the first step in a major campaign to rid the world of nuclear arms. Mr Reagan, Mr Gorbachev and the people who worked for this historic treaty must be congratulated on the work that they have done. I must say that Australia has played a great part behind the scenes in bringing about a lessening of tension throughout the world.

I trust that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), when he goes to Moscow very soon, will say that Australia may be able to play some major part in the verification team that is being established. We are a trusted ally of the United States and I think we are also looked upon as a friendly and reliable country by the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics. Between those countries, we can play a middle role and I am quite certain that we have the technical skills to enable us to take part in this verification and in this very historic nuclear treaty.

A few weeks ago I was at the United Nations. I was taking part in a conference called `Building a Global Security System'. It related to what we, as politicians, could do to try to bring about a greater sense of security and peace in the world. I will take an opportunity later in the life of this Parliament to bring to the House some of the decisions that were made at that particular conference. One of the main decisions was a call to change the whole structure of the United Nations. The United Nations has been in operation since 1945. It was set up just after the Second World War and things have changed rapidly since it was established. I believe that the time has come for some changes to the United Nations. I trust that the speeches that I give, plus those of the other 79 politicians who attended this conference, will bring about this change by the year 2000. Here we have a great opportunity to do something to better the whole of human kind. As I have said, I trust that the other politicians and I will be able to assist in speeding up this process to make certain that we leave this planet in a peaceful state for our children.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The quaint title of Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill 1987 covers 110 separate changes to legislation. Ten of them are primary production or agricultural pieces of legislation and some of them involve quite significant changes to policy as distinct from just mechanical changes. I understood that the purpose of such Bills is to be able to put together a whole range of smaller items and get them through the Parliament. I draw attention to the fact that some of these changes are very significant policy changes; some of them have other implications, and also some of them are very late. I will refer to some of them briefly, and only to a couple in any detail.

SPEECH.PARA: The first relates to an amendment to the Australian Apple and Pear Corporation Act and a change to the Auditor-General's requirements. Of course, we have going through the Parliament the Horticultural Research and Development Corporation Bill which will abolish the Australian Apple and Pear Corporation. It is an interesting situation as to which comes first. Also included are amendments to the Barley Research Levy Act, the Canned Fruits Marketing Act, the Dairy Product Act, the Honey Industry Act, the Meat Inspection Act, the Pig Industry Act, the Quarantine Act, the Wheat Tax Act and the Wine Grapes Levy Collection Act. Honourable members will be pleased to know that I will not be speaking about all of those, but I do want just briefly to comment on a couple.

The purpose of the amendment to the Wine Grapes Levy Collection Act is to increase the penalty for failing to submit a levy return from $500 to $1,000, or imprisonment for six months, or both, in the case of a natural person, or to $5,000 in the case of a body corporate. That seems to me to be a pretty significant increase for it to be hidden in this sort of legislation.

With the amendments to the Honey Industry Act, we have the interesting situation that the appointments of some members of the Australian Honey Board actually expired on 30 June 1987 or, in the case of one member, 1 August 1987. The purpose of this amendment is to enable the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) to fill the vacancy where the previous industry member is unable or does not wish to be appointed for a further period. In other words, this picks up the fact that we have an interesting hiatus period between those dates and now.

The amendments to the Dairy Produce Act are quite significant in that they change the ability of certain people to be elected to the Australian Dairy Corporation. They basically prevent any member of the Australian Dairy Industry Conference Executive Council from being able to be appointed to the Australian Dairy Corporation. As I understand it, that is to a certain extent in line with the Government's requirements for statutory marketing authorities. I do not object to, say, the President, the Chairman or the senior office bearers of the Conference being excluded-one could argue about the whole Executive Council-but, once again, this is quite a significant alteration to the eligibility criteria for appointment to the Australian Dairy Corporation, and it is hidden in this Bill.

The final and most significant amendment is to the Canned Fruits Marketing Act 1979. The Australian Canned Fruits Corporation is one of the major agricultural statutory marketing authorities in Australia. It is concentrated in the electorate of Murray, my electorate in northern Victoria, that is to say, about two-thirds of the total Australian production of deciduous canned fruit come from my area; the remainder comes from the Murrumbidgee Irrigation Area and the Riverland area of South Australia. Without this amendment, which extends the life of the Corporation for a further 12 months from 1 January 1988 to the end of December 1988, that statutory marketing authority would cease to exist from the end of December 1987. I support the extension of the life of that Corporation. It is a major agricultural marketing body and this is a significant aspect of legislation in agricultural policy in that a corporation is being extended for a further 12 months. I know why it is being extended. The canneries in the canned fruit industry are working very closely together at present on a merger proposal, basically to put all of the deciduous canned fruit canneries together, that is, Ardmona Fruit Products, SPC Ltd and Letona Co-op Ltd. Therefore, if that is approved by the growers-shareholders, which appears to be the case at the moment, and if it receives the approval of the Trade Practices Commission-I am not aware of any decision by the Trade Practices Commission at this time-that will be possible. Of course, if the major processors of deciduous canned fruits in Australia are merged into one operating organisation, there will obviously be no need for the statutory authority to continue. Hence, the Government has, sensibly and correctly, give a 12-month extension to it. But I do just make the point that this is rather an odd way for that extension to take place. I hope that the merger of the canneries is able to take place, because it will bring significant rationalisation and cost savings to the industry, and hopefully will increase the return to growers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gayler Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill 1987 has been debated in the Senate and the debate now rests here in the House. It continues the practice of introducing omnibus legislation into the Parliament as the expeditious way of making a large number of non-contentious amendments to legislation. The legislation deals with tidying up, correcting and updating routine administrative changes and changes of minor-I emphasise the word `minor'-policy significance.

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst I am aware of the debate that took place in the Senate, and the issues raised by some members of the Opposition in that place, I submit that it is clear that the legislation contains no contentious matters, matters involving lengthy drafting nor substantial policy issues. The amendments proposed in this Bill are, for the most part, a reproduction of the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill (No. 1) 1987, which lapsed after the second reading debate in the House of Representatives earlier this year.

The Bill includes amendments to a number of Acts which were not included in the earlier Bill. I would like to enumerate the additional Bills included in this legislation. They include the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976, the Acts Interpretation Act 1901, the Canned Fruits Marketing Act 1979, the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918, the Conciliation and Arbitration Act 1904, the Currency Act 1915, the Customs Tariff (Miscellaneous Amendments) Act 1987, the Extradition (Commonwealth Countries) Act 1966, the Foreign States Immunities Act 1985, the Minerals (Submerged Lands) Act 1981 and, finally, the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters (Consequential Amendments) Act 1987. It is to those pieces of legislation that I will address my remarks this afternoon.

First, I turn to the Acts Interpretation Act. The amendments will permit the simplification of language of Acts of Parliament. Having been a member of the legal profession, I commend these amendments. The amendments will permit some standard forms of words to be shortened in or omited from Acts. This is a welcome amendment, as anything which simplifies, or more importantly, clarifies, the language of legislation is to be commended.

Amongst the other amendments, the proposed amendment in relation to section 48 of the Acts Interpretation Act should be commented on. There is no doubt that the amendment, which allows for more flexibility in the actual commencing time of regulations, is justifiable, not least on the basis that it will remove doubt by enabling regulations to take effect from the commencement of an Act of Parliament or part of an Act of Parliament. It will also allow regulations to specify the time of day they are to come into effect. Additionally, regulations may be expressed to commence at the commencement of a specified Act, even if the Act is to commence on a proclaimed date. Further provision is made for regulations to commence at a specified time on a specified day. The proposed amendments deal with situations that have arisen in the past and which under the new legislation will not arise in the future.

I will quickly refer to some instances where the current legislation is deficient. A regulation under the Australian Capital Territory Tax Transfers of Marketable Securities Act had to come into force at 5 p.m. on a particular date. The current provisions of the Acts Interpretation Act make it impossible for regulations to come into force at a particular hour of the day.

Difficulties arose under the protection of the Sea (Civil Liability) Act 1981. Legislation was introduced pursuant to Australian ratification of the protocol. Regulations were required to come into force when another Act which provided for ratification itself came into force; that would be when the protocol come into force for Australia. Of course that date could not be identified in advance. However, under the amended provisions, the Bill is designed to deal with such a situation.

I now refer briefly to a number of other Acts which are affected by this omnibus legislation and I will refer initially to the Commonwealth Electoral Act. The proposed amendment to the Commonwealth Electoral Act is designed to clarify the powers of the Electoral Commissioner in relation to the direction of Australian electoral officers, divisional returning officers and other officers as defined under the current legislation. The amendment also places beyond doubt the power of Australian electoral officers to direct divisional returning officers and they, in their turn, to direct officers under their control.

Turning now to the Conciliation and Arbitration Act, the amendments included in this Bill are intended to remove doubts about the certification of rule alterations. The Act in its present form requires that certain rule alterations made by organisations registered under the legislation do not take effect unless certified by an industrial registrar as not contrary to law, the Act and regulations, an award or the rules of the organisation. Some doubts currently exist as to the power of a registrar to certify part only of a rule alteration submitted to him. The proposed amendment will remove such doubt. It is interesting that these amendments to the Conciliation and Arbitration Act in fact have no retrospectivity.

The amendments to the Dairy Produce Act will prevent persons who are members of the executive council of the Australian Dairy Conference, which is the peak policy council of the diary industry, from being appointed as members of the Australian Dairy Corporation. This change is in accordance with the Government's policy that, where a statutory marketing authority is required to account to the peak industry body, the members of the executive council of that body are not to be eligible for appointment as members of the authority because of the possibility of a conflict of interests.

The proposed amendments to the Honey Industry Act will enable the Minister to re-appoint the immediate past members of the Australian Honey Board to hold office until the end of 1988. The Board is to be restructured with new membership. Under the Bill which lapsed at the end of last sittings, the tenure of Board members was to be extended pending the restructuring of the Board. However, in the intervening period, the Board members' appointments have expired.

The Bill also proposes a number of minor amendments to the Housing Loans Insurance Act 1965. The most important of these fall into two areas. The first will allow greater flexibility in the appointment of a person to act as chairman and managing director of the Corporation. Under the proposed amendments, the Treasurer will be able to appoint someone to act as chairman in the absence of the chairman. This will overcome difficulties that have arisen when the deputy chairman's position has been vacant.

The second area of amendment will allow the Corporation to enter into re-insurance contracts with a subsidiary of an approved lender in respect of loans made by the approved lender and insured by the subsidiary. A recent trend for some lenders to insure their loans through their own newly established subsidiaries, and the fact that the Corporation is currently prevented by its Act from offering re-insurance, have restricted the Corporation's ability to compete for business in housing industry traditional services. The proposed amendments will enable the Corporation to respond to developments in the mortgage insurance market.

In my second reading speech I foreshadowed that I would be moving certain amendments in committee. In respect of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901, the first amendment circulated will substitute a new paragraph 48 (1) (b) of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901. It is similar to the proposed amendment omitted by the Senate. After consultation with the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, proposed sub-paragraph 48 (1) (b) (iii) has been changed to include an express reference to the date, or date and time of commencement of an Act, or of a specified provision of an action. With that change the Senate Committee supports the amendment.

Briefly, the amendment will allow for more flexibility in the commencement of regulations. At present, sub-section 48 (1) provides that regulations will come into effect from the date of notification or the date specified in the regulations. The amendment will remove a doubt by enabling regulations to take effect from the commencement of an Act or of part of an Act. It will also allow regulations to specify the time of day they are to come into effect.

In respect of the Audit Act 1901 the second amendment circulated restores some amendments to the Audit Act that were deleted in the Senate. The Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration has examined these amendments and has reported favourably on them. The basic aim of the amendments is to improve the efficiency of the Commonwealth's financial administration.

The Audit Act currently provides that funds cannot be expended from the Commonwealth Public Account, following the passing of Appropriation Acts, until certain conditions have been met. These include requirements that the Minister for Finance obtain a certificate from the Auditor-General that the amount sought does not exceed the amount available for expenditure, and a warrant from the Governor-General authorising the drawing of the amount from the Commonwealth Public Account. The proposed amendments to sections 32 and 33 will eliminate the requirement for the Auditor-General's certificate and the Governor-General's warrant before the Minister for Finance can make payments. They provide for the Minister for Finance to make payments out of the Commonwealth Public Account in accordance with an appropriation from the Consolidated Revenue Fund on the Loan Fund, and will authorise the Secretary to the Department of Finance to draw the amount. The Governor-General has agreed to the proposed changes which were also cleared by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts.

Section 57 of the Audit Act requires that Loan Fund expenditure be covered by an Act. Sub-section 57 (2) specifies the details to be contained in such an Act. The effect of section 57 is that should the Parliament pass a Loan Act which did not contain the details required under sub-section 57 (2), then the Minister for Finance could not lawfully expend the moneys covered by that Act. Parliament should be free to frame the terms of a statute in any way it considers fit and the existing provision purports to limit that scope. The repeal of the subsection will remove the risk without derogating in any way from parliamentary control of loans legislation. The proposal has also been cleared by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. Amendments 3, 4, and 5 are consequential amendments.

In respect of the National Measurement Act 1960 the final amendment is intended to clarify and improve certain provisions now in the Bill. The proposed amendments to the National Measurement Act in this Bill include amendments to require the use of metric units of measurement in real estate transactions. Proposed section 12a as passed by the Senate on 7 October 1987 provided that real estate contracts and transactions would be void if non-metric measurements were used, unless the documents of title relating to the land included or referred to non-metric measurements. On further reflection the Government considers that invalidating contracts and transactions is not appropriate. It is intended that the proposed section 12a be amended so that a contravention of the section will be an offence punishable on conviction by a fine. The amended section will also expressly refer to the duplicate certificate of title amongst the documents of title.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it the wish of the House to debate the International Development Association Bill concurrently with the Asian Development Fund Bill and the International Fund for Agricultural Development Bill? There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening I am standing in for the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) in my capacity as the acting shadow Minister for foreign affairs because the honourable member for North Sydney has begun a visit to a number of South Pacific countries. In doing so, I believe, he is setting a very important example which I hope Ministers will follow.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition does not oppose the International Development Association Bill, the Asian Development Fund Bill and the International Fund for Agricultural Development Bill and I do not think that will come as a surprise. But we shall be raising a number of issues in the debate and we will look forward to the Government giving us some response to the important issues we want to discuss. This afternoon I want to divide my speech into two sections; first of all, I will make some comments about the specifics of these Bills and, secondly, I will make some more general comments about the present Government's policies on overseas development assistance. I will start by referring to some of the specifics of these Bills.

Clearly, the purpose of these Bills is to provide Australia's financial contribution to three important international financial institutions-firstly, the International Fund for Agricultural Development (IFAD); secondly, the Asian Development Fund (ADF) and, thirdly, the International Development Association (IDA). The International Fund for Agricultural Development, as honourable members may well know, was established initially in 1974 after the two Arab oil price hikes, as they are sometimes known, as a way of not only getting concessional finance for agricultural development in the least developed countries but also harnessing some of the resources of the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) to assist the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) countries in providing that assistance. At the moment, the OECD provides around 60 per cent of funding for the International Fund for Agricultural Development-IFAD as it is known-and OPEC provides some 40 per cent.

Australia, since the inception of IFAD, has supported strongly the concept of the International Fund. Not only have we favoured the concept of agricultural development in developing countries-we have done so for very good reasons because we believe that that is the fundamental basis of economic development-but also we have regarded it as an international financial institution which can make a very real contribution to the least developed countries as distinct from those developing countries which are more advanced in economic terms. What has happened with the second replenishment fund for IFAD, which this legislation relates to, is that there has been a decrease, in real terms, in Australia's contribution to some $8.4m. That is not to say that Australia is being particularly ungenerous. Indeed, Australia's contribution has increased as a proportion of the contribution of the OECD countries. Our proportion has gone up from 1.68 per cent to 2.15 per cent of the OECD contribution. The important point to make is that this second replenishment of the International Fund for Agricultural Development is less than half of the first replenishment which was for the period 1981 to 1984. So the prospects for IFAD are clearly somewhat bleak compared with its present status.

It is well known that IFAD has come in for considerable criticism in recent times, in particular from Dr Helen Hughes of the Australian National University, somebody who all honourable members would appreciate is a distinguished commentator on these matters. Dr Hughes has made a number of points that need to be considered and addressed. One of the points she has raised is that IFAD covers a vast number of projects but is thinly spread in each of those projects. Clearly that diminishes, on the face of it, the effectiveness of IFAD as an assistance organisation. She also argues that IFAD is left with extremely risky projects which are often very poorly prepared and that as soon as the donor leaves the project, it simply collapses.

She has also argued that the staff at IFAD spend a very high proportion of their time doing little other than fund raising, although it has to be said that a lot of the specific project work by IFAD is carried out on IFAD's behalf by the World Bank, a point that needs to be strongly emphasised. She has advised the Government that it should cut out support altogether for IFAD and it would appear that the Government has accepted that advice from Dr Hughes because, as the Minister for Trade Negotiations (Mr Duffy) pointed out in his second reading speech, this contribution will be the last contribution by the Australian Government to IFAD.

We on this side of the House are not prepared simply to accept that advice from the Government on face value. We would like to hear from the Government what advice it has received, not just from Dr Helen Hughes but also from the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau (AIDAB). That advice has not been forthcoming and I hope that the Minister, in his winding up speech at the end of this debate, will take the opportunity of giving us that information. We on this side of the House certainly believe that since 1977, when Australia first became involved in IFAD, IFAD has conducted some very valuable work in the least developed countries. With that in mind and bearing in mind the important role Australia has played in both setting up IFAD and helping to encourage it, we would be very grateful to know what AIDAB's advice has been in relation to the Government's decision to abandon support for IFAD at the end of the second replenishment.

The second piece of legislation relates to the Asian Development Fund which, as honourable members will know, is the concessional loans arm of the Asian Development Bank. This legislation provides for the Australian contribution to the fourth replenishment of the ADF for the period 1987 to 1990. The contribution is some $410m which is 7.98 per cent of the total replenishment. Australia's contribution as a percentage of the total replenishment has increased in this legislation and I welcome that decision on the part of the Government. The Australian proportion of funding for the ADF is a relatively high proportion and that shows a recognition by the Government of the importance of the ADF as a regional multilateral aid organisation.

What interested me when I read the Minister's second reading speech on this legislation was that he made no reference to the fact that the reason Australia provided such a solid contribution to the ADF was that it was a regional international financial institution which provided concessional loans to developing countries. I would have thought that that would have been a very central point. I would at least like to hear from the Minister in his winding up speech that that is the reason why the Government has placed such a high priority on the ADF.

Like all international financial institutions, the ADF has, from time to time, been subject to some criticism. It has been accused of being more interested in ensuring that global lending targets are met than in ensuring that the loans that it provides are well directed. That is a very common criticism of aid agencies and the soft loans arms of the international financial institutions. However, we have no reason to believe that in the totality of its work the ADF has not done a fairly solid job. As I said earlier, it is a regional international financial institution and for that reason Australia should be an active and generous participant in its work.

The third piece of legislation relates to the International Development Association which is the concessional lending arm of the World Bank. In this case Australia is providing funding for the eighth replenishment to the value of some $335m. The only point I raise in relation to the IDA is the historic distribution of those soft loans from the IDA. The distribution over the years has been such that something like 45 to 50 per cent of the funding has gone to sub-Saharan Africa, basically for humanitarian reasons. Of course, that is something that we would strongly support. It is important to recognise that, if Australia is to make a constructive humanitarian contribution to that part of the world, we are more likely to be able to do that through an international financial institution of this kind than we are on a bilateral basis. That is one of the strong arguments for our providing some proportion of our aid in multilateral rather than bilateral aid.

I also note, however, that some 30 per cent of the IDA's funding has gone to China and India. I rather question such a high proportion going to those two countries. This concern has been raised in previous debates over the years on Australian funding for the IDA. India in particular is not one of the least developed countries. I would therefore not have thought that it would have necessarily been accorded the highest priority by the IDA. Yet clearly it is given a very high priority. I am not suggesting for a minute that India does not have very substantial humanitarian and economic problems; it certainly does. But India is coping well with those problems on its own and it is developing very effectively. Other parts of the world, such as sub-Saharan Africa, are suffering a great deal more than is India. We would question only the proportion of assistance from the IDA which happens to be going to that country, without wishing to suggest for a minute any criticism of India.

They are the specific points I make in relation to this legislation, but I would like also to make a number of general observations on the Government's approach to overseas aid and to the developing countries. The first is a fundamental point about our approach to developing countries; that is, that our generation of Australians-and, indeed, the people of the Western democracies-will be judged on the success or the failure of their approach to the relationship between rich countries and poor countries. If we fail to ensure that there is a constructive and developing relationship between those countries which gives some benefits to developing countries, we can look forward only to turmoil, bitterness and global instability. If we ignore North-South issues, as they used to be called-that expression seems to have lost favour for some reason or other, but let me revitalise it-what we are doing is ignoring the starving, ignoring death through lack of medical services, and ignoring the impoverished and hopeless lives of millions upon millions of people around the world. I am sure all honourable members of this House would accept that we have a moral responsibility simply not to ignore those things.

For those honourable members who are of a more cynical disposition, I make the point that by ignoring North-South issues we are also ignoring the security implications for our own society and for the Western world as a whole. We cannot divorce the problems of the developing countries from the East-West conflict. Developing countries will look to the Soviet Union, not for ideological reasons initially, but for assistance of both a financial and perhaps even a military kind if the Western world-I include Australia in that category-turns its back on developing countries and their struggle for economic growth simply to meet the needs of their livelihoods. If we turn our backs on developing countries and their problems we are simply handing the Soviet Union and its satellites a foothold in a whole range of areas of the world.

My objection-and I use the word `objection' very sincerely-to the way the Government has conducted the relationship between Australia and other parts of the Western world and developing countries is that it has given it an extremely low priority. It has really confirmed what I said earlier; that to use terms such as `North-South dialogue' or `North-South issues' has become unfashionable. The Press, of course, has always ignored these issues, and it has been very short-sighted in doing so. But it concerns me very sincerely that the Government has given such a low priority to these issues. Although this will not be a part of the political scene in Australia which will receive much discussion, I think history will record that in the foreign policy field, one of the greatest contrasts between the Fraser Government and the Hawke Government was the very sincere contribution that the Fraser Government made to attempt to resolve North-South problems.

It might be recalled that the commitment of Malcolm Fraser and his Government to North-South issues during their period of office aroused much ridicule from the Australian Labor Party and much criticism from the Press. Yet I am certainly of the view that the Fraser Government showed a sense of responsibility and global vision by placing such a high priority on North-South issues. My concern is that this Government has none of that sense of perspective. It has lost sight of the very simple fact that was repeatedly made by the Fraser Government; that Australia is in a very special position to act almost as a bridge between developed and developing countries.

We all know, for all the banana republic comments we hear, that Australia is still a developed Westernised country. But its geographical location is in the South, and it is largely, with the exception of New Zealand, surrounded by developing countries. The structure of our economy as a resource exporter is also much akin to the structures of the economies of developing countries. I know that the Minister for Science and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones), who is sitting at the table, exhorts Australia to become a brain driven country, and I support what he says about that. But the fact is that we still are not; we are still largely a country that thrives on exporting what it can dig out of the dirt or grow in its paddocks. In that respect we have a great deal in common with developing countries.

With that in mind, I think the Government should pick up again where the Fraser Government was cruelly cut off in March 1983 and again try to re-establish Australia's position as a bridge between the developed and the developing world. We should have a two-pronged approach to North-South issues. One of those prongs should be our commitment to overseas aid and the other should be our commitment to a fairer and more reasonable trading system, above all to the benefit of poverty stricken developing countries.

Let me very briefly look at what has unfortunately happened in the field of overseas aid. It is my view that this Government has not only given overseas development assistance a very low priority; it has gone further than that. It has regarded expenditure on overseas development assistance as a very low priority; it has gone further than that. It has regarded expenditure on overseas development assistance as nothing more than discretionary expenditure. By making that expenditure seem so discretionary it has undermined Australia's role and its reputation as a bridge between developed and developing countries. One has only to look at some of the statistics. In the 1987-88 Budget expenditure on overseas redevelopment assistance is expected to decline in real terms by 3.4 per cent. Taking the measure of overseas development assistance as a proportion of gross domestic product (GDP), expenditure has fallen now to 0.36 per cent in this financial year, which is the lowest level for almost a quarter of a century. Last year it was 0.38 per cent. Yet in 1982-83, when this Government came to power, it was 0.47 per cent.

Looking at what spokesmen for the Labor Party were saying at the beginning of this decade shows that it is quite remarkable that they should have taken this cavalier discretionary approach to overseas development assistance. The now Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Lionel Bowen), when he was the shadow Minister for foreign affairs, said on 24 March 1981:
The Australian Labor Party . . . is a party of concern. This Government-
and he was referring then to the Fraser Government-

should not delay any longer in making a generous response to the needs of the poorest countries. This Government's performance in providing assistance to the developing world is now at the lowest level it has ever been.

If it was at the lowest level it has ever been in 1981, the House can rest assured that it is at a very substantially lower level today. The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden) said on 13 October 1981, when he was Leader of the Opposition:
There is no commitment by the Prime Minister-
he was referring to Mr Fraser-
of a concrete timetable that in a specified period we will provide, according to our commitment to the United Nations' objective, 0.7 per cent of gross domestic product in official development aid.
He went on to say:

A Labor Government would do so and it would do so within one term of parliament. We would firmly commit ourselves to the second step of development aid-that is, 1 per cent of gross domestic product-by, at the latest, 1990.
We are now in the financial year 1987-88 and our level of development assistance has fallen to the lowest level as a proportion of GDP it has been at for a quarter of a century.

The overseas development assistance we provide has a lack of regional emphasis and a lack of proper regional focus. It is of very great concern to honourable members on this side of the House that the aid we provide to Papua New Guinea is expected to decline in 1987-88 and that that is just a continuation of a trend. In 1985-86 we provided $319m to Papua New Guinea. In 1986-87 it went up a little, to $325m. This year it will be $301m. One does not have to walk far into the government offices of Papua New Guinea to learn of the resentment felt against the Australian Government and therefore against Australia for broken undertakings on development assistance to Papua New Guinea and about the cavalier and discretionary approach the Government has to assistance to that country. The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade himself conceded at the time of the Budget that aid to our own region is going to decline this financial year. There is one special reason why it is going to decline as much as it will and it relates to Tuvalu. Nevertheless, it is a shameful thing that we should have such a negligent attitude to our own region, let alone to the whole humanitarian approach to overseas development assistance.

I now turn to trade, which is the second aspect of what should be Australia's contribution to North-South issues. During the period of the Fraser Government we pursued this two-pronged approach to North-South issues. We had constructive overseas development assistance policies and we had constructive trade policies. We realised at that time that important as overseas development assistance is as a humanitarian contribution, it is going to be still more important to ensure that developing countries have access to markets in the developed world. I recall that in 1982 the Fraser Government launched a global trade initiative which was not just about improving Australia's position in the firmament of international trade but about ensuring that the international trading system was a fairer system for developing countries. As long as the exports of those countries are blocked out of the European, American and Japanese domestic markets, those countries will not prosper. The Fraser Government recognised that and pursued trade initiatives to ensure that that objective could be achieved. I recall only too clearly that those initiatives were ridiculed by people in the Press and ridiculed by the Australian Labor Party in the Parliament at that time. I can say only that things have at least improved in terms of the political debate on trade initiatives. At least, some years later, the Hawke Government has now picked up the initiatives that the Fraser Government was pursuing way back in 1982 and has started to promote those initiatives on a global level. The Cairns Group which was initiated in part by Australia was a very constructive initiative. What it is pursuing will be important not just to Australia but also to developing countries.

I have ranged fairly freely over what I will continue to call the North-South issue. I worked in the Department of Foreign Affairs with Alan Oxley, the present Ambassador to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade in Geneva, as part of the two-man North-South unit. I have ranged fairly freely over North-South issues but I do think that they have become the forgotten part of foreign policy. We have a very strong humanitarian and moral responsibility to ensure that, as a relatively rich and developed country, we provide assistance to developing countries. It would be inhumane of us if we were simply to turn our backs on developing countries. We also have a vested interest in ensuring that we build a bridge between developed and developing countries, that we do all we can, as a country with a similar economic structure to many developing countries and as a country which is geographically located in an area which is predominantly an area of developing countries, to build that bridge and to ensure that developed countries are opening their markets to the developing world and providing sufficient overseas development assistance.

It is of great concern to me that the Hawke Government, in its 4 1/2 years-getting on for five years-has paid so little attention to these issues. There has not even been rhetoric, let alone concrete action. Whilst that point may not be picked up strongly by the media, it is a very strong criticism of the foreign policy of this Government. I hope that as this Parliament wears on the Government, particularly the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), will become aware of the importance of these issues and of what I said earlier-that our generation of politicians, our generation of Australians, will be judged as a success or failure partly on the basis of what contributions we are able to make to resolving the difficulties and the differentials between rich countries and poor countries.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the reduced time that Government members have agreed to for the purpose of their contribution to the debate on the International Development Association Bill, the Asian Development Fund Bill and the International Fund for Agricultural Development Bill, it will not be possible for honourable members to cover all of the issues that they may otherwise have wanted to cover. SPEECH.PARA: I think he may have misunderstood a reference in the second reading speech of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) to an article in the Canberra Times by Professor Helen Hughes. IFAD staff mainly attend to IFAD fund replenishment, persuading donors to pledge financial support to it rather than to other multinational organisations, including those like the World Bank that implements the bulk of its projects.

IFAD has a vast but thin spread of projects throughout the world.

IFAD projects generally lack the national government policy support necessary for success.

—I have not noticed any commentary from the honourable member for Mayo or from the honourable member for Dundas, who is so free with his interjections at the present time, to counter those claims that have been made.
