One of the reasons why the Australian contribution has been declining is because the general level of funding of that development fund has been declining as well.

SPEECH.PARA: There are important considerations in each of these Bills. On the last occasion when a similar package of Bills was considered last year I took advantage of the opportunity to refer to some of those matters to which the honourable member for Mayo has already referred. As I said, I think it is appropriate that they be canvassed in connection with these questions. One of the things that is disturbing is the fact that in a situation of the kind that we are presently experiencing internationally, when there is an increasing world recession, there is a greater need for international development assistance. However, the capacity of the more advanced industrialised countries in the world to provide that assistance is reduced, so that when the need is greatest, the capacity to assist is least available. I do not believe that the developed industrialised countries are presently making an adequate response to the needs of the underdeveloped countries.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nor is Australia.

—In response to the honourable member for Mayo, I do not resile from a similar observation. How could I? But there are some other observations that the honourable member for Mayo could well have made. His time was limited, as is the time for all of us. I am not suggesting that he was attempting to hide or camouflage some of the observations that I am going to make. But I think they are matters to which the honourable member for Mayo and others could well give their attention. They should not persist with an attempt at fairly cheap point scoring in connection with something which he himself acknowledged is of international dimensions and international importance.

SPEECH.PARA: I am concerned, for example, that the International Monetary Fund (IMF) believes that global growth of 3 per cent is the minimum that is required for next year in order for the world just to keep its economic fundamentals in place. But are we going to achieve that 3 per cent growth? Almost certainly not. In fact the IMF has downgraded its latest projection to a growth level for the whole of the world of between 2.5 and 2.75 per cent. The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) has again revised downwards its growth forecasts, particularly for the industrialised countries. It now expects that next year the growth rate will shrink to 1.75 per cent. Its earlier predictions had it at about 2.25 per cent. The United States of America is forecasting a fall from 2.75 per cent to a sluggish 2 per cent. So the economic growth of the world is gearing down, it is slowing down and the capacity of all industrialised countries to assist the underdeveloped countries, where assistance is so drastically and dramatically needed, is being reduced.

Of relevance in this connection is the question of the alternative for the underdeveloped countries to direct forms of aid being made available to them. What can they do, other than borrow? Of course their level of borrowing has reached a stage now where it has become one of the major destabilising elements of the world economy and the world financial system. It is one of those urgent matters to which the world economic managers must give their attention. For example, the five biggest Latin American debtors between them owe $202,000m. The total for all of the Latin American debtors blew out from $325 billion to about $400 billion, simply as a result of their need to reschedule their loans and also to borrow money to pay interest on the loans that they had already raised.

Private lending is overwhelmingly involved in the re-negotiation of existing debt, and in many cases export earnings for those countries are merely sufficient to service their existing debt. The total which is owed by the poor countries of the world to the rich nations of the world is $1,100 billion-that is over $1 trillion-over $1,000,000m. These countries are placed in a situation where they have to service those debts and eventually to repay them. They have to do that out of exports. They are doing it out of exports at a time when the price for their bulk exports is collapsing. There are two reasons for that. The first is the world recession, and the second is because the developed countries themselves are subsidising their own domestic producers in order to produce goods that compete against the bulk exports of those developing countries.

If ever a group of countries in the history of the world found themselves in a catch-22 situation, the underdeveloped countries do today. The result, of course, is that if we were to take away the debt servicing charges and the reduced prices for bulk commodities-especially as a result of the subsidised production, the subsidised export of bulk commodities in the developed countries and the increased prices that the underdeveloped countries have to pay for their manufactured goods-from the development assistance that is provided to them, we would finish up with a negative amount. That means that there is a net transfer of wealth, income and resources not from the rich to the poor, but from the poor to the rich.
As I said before, it is all very well for the honourable member for Mayo to attempt to make cheap political points out of some of these issues.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course he wasn't.

—Of course he was, and anyone who heard him, or who reads the contribution he made-there was some substance in it, and I have already conceded that-will see what I mean. But for anyone to suggest that it was not at the same time an attempt at cheap political point scoring is simply absurd, and the honourable member knows it. The OECD aid to developing countries reached $51.67 billion last year, a very substantial amount.

SPEECH.PARA: In conclusion, I make some observations about some of these comparable values and compar- able amounts. The OECD countries, the 26 most highly developed Western industrial nations of the world, contributed almost $52 billion last year to assist in the development of the underdeveloped countries. What did the world spend on military purposes? It spent $900 billion. From 1960 to 1985 the money spent on defence in American dollars was 14 trillion-or $14 million million. That is equivalent to 23 years current income for the poorer half of the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —What a terrible waste.

—As my colleague says, a terrible waste. It is a terrible indictment of the quality of man. Man should be devising means of living together on this relatively small globe, and doing so peacefully by applying man's talent and the world's resources to man's elevation, instead of wasting money in this shocking way. The honourable member for Fraser is renowned for his concern on this subject. Is it not also of concern that the arms imports to the developing countries between 1975 and 1985 amounted to 40 per cent of the increase in their debt? One could go on and on with such examples.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1986 Australia contributed over $1,000m towards international aid. We were the sixth most generous nation of the 18 OECD members who were giving aid to developing countries, and the figures are there. I know that there has been a reduction in the percentage of gross domestic product, and of the obligations and commitments that have been made. I shall now refer to a pamphlet that I received today from the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund (UNICEF). The honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore) is also involved in the attempt to establish a parliamentary group for UNICEF. I know that the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) also is concerned on this and similar issues. I conclude by quoting from the UNICEF pamphlet:

Today, fourteen million children die before the age of five, and estimates are that at least half these deaths could be averted, and as many disabilities prevented, by a handful of low-cost health actions.

Some four million children who succumb to diarrhoeal dehydration, for example, could be treated by a starch or sugar and salt mixture in water; many of the three and a half million children who die each year from measles, whooping cough, diphtheria, tetanus, polio and tuberculosis could be saved by immunization.
That is a cheap medical procedure. I continue:

Millions more malnutrition-related deaths could be averted by encouraging a return to breast-feeding and by mothers regularly weighing and monitoring their children's growth, thus enabling them to detect the first signs of undernutrition and take, in most cases, relatively straightforward remedial action.

I conclude by adopting the remark made by my colleague the member for Fraser. What a terrible indictment of the people of the world, their leaders, their parliaments and their planners that this order of priority should prevail. As a result we should all be damned.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad to have the opportunity to speak on the International Development Association Bill and cognate Bills. My comments will be addressed primarily to the International Fund for Agricultural Development Bill. I hope that the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown), who has accused Opposition members of wanting to take a cheap shot, will stay to hear the detailed discussion that I will have on the article by Helen Hughes and other matters relating to the Government's decision to discontinue, after the second replenishment, support for the International Fund for Agricultural Development. I regard it as a most unfortunate decision. I do not believe that the decision was based on a proper analysis of the facts, and I am not sure that the decision was based on proper advice to government from its own officials. I suspect that it has been based very much on the judgment formed after reading the one page sheet that Professor Helen Hughes served up on this issue.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me note what the Bill is designed to do. Its purpose is to authorise a contribution by Australia of $8,472,570 towards the second replenishment of the International Fund for Agricultural Development (IFAD). The Fund focuses on increasing food production for the poorest sections of the world's poorest countries. This is a statement drawn by the Minister's own Department setting out the objectives. Australia has been a member of IFAD since it was established in 1977 and participated in the Fund's first replenishment.

The Bill by itself would be unexceptionable. My concern is about the statements by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden) about the Government's intentions following our commitment to the second replenishment. I have for some time taken an interest in the future of this organisation. I spoke in the Estimates debates on 7 October 1987 and asked the Minister to clarify questions that I had posed about the future of IFAD. I said that the Minister would no doubt be aware of the important role played by the Fund for the rural poor, and also be aware of my continuing concern that Australia should make known its contribution to the second replenishment of that organisation as requested and its contribution to the sub- Saharan Africa pledge which Australia had been requested to assist.

I had on notice a question to the Minister in which I had sought information about the future of the organisation and our future commitment to it. The question I asked on 25 March was answered by the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I asked whether any part of the funds committed or paid in 1986-87 constituted part of the pledged second replenishment and, if not, whether Australia had sought any extension of time to fund its commitment to IFAD, or whether it intended to dishonour the pledge. The Minister said:

No, none of the funds paid in 1986-87 constitute payment of the pledged second replenishment and Australia has not sought any extension of time . . . IFAD estimates that the first call on any Australian contribution to the second replenishment will not take place until the 1989-90 financial year. As the honour- able member is aware from my answer to his previous question, a comparative assessment of the value of Australia's participation in international financial institutions and IFAD has been initiated as a basis for determining future contributions. This process is nearing completion and the Government will be considering the question of Australia's participation in IFAD's second replenishment in the context of the recommendations of this review.

That is the Minister's advice. Decisions will be made in the context of the review-which was taking place. I understand that the review was completed. I understand that the review has not been made public, but also understand that the review was not critical of IFAD. I might be wrong about that. If I am wrong, and the Minister believes that I am wrong, when he responds on this issue no doubt he will table a copy of the report so that I can see it and no doubt can apologise if I have in any way misled the House.

The report examined the question of whether, for Australia and Australia's interests, IFAD had the same capacity to advance our interests as do other organisations. That could involve different considerations. There may be trade-offs, as there can be with the World Bank, which is a large organisation, and which can be involved in dispensing a large number of consultancies, of which Australia gets its fair share, perhaps more than do others. But if it is a matter of looking at whether the aid that is given might ultimately find its way back to Australia by the purchase of products from Australia, if one is in the business of advancing the poorest of the world's poor in growing their own food-unless, I suppose, they buy the seed from Australia-one will not find trade-offs of that kind. If the first question that had to be asked was whether taking the funds away from IFAD and giving them to other organisations would better advance Australia and Australian interests, that might well have been the basis on which this decision was made. I suggest that that would be the wrong basis in this case.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—I am glad that the honourable member for Charlton agrees with me. We must attack the fundamentals. Is this organisation defective? Is it not achieving its objectives? Are the funds being squandered? Have the funds been defrauded? Or, as was said in relation to the United Nations Children's Fund, are the accounts not being produced correctly? Does the auditor qualify the accounts? I understand that IFAD has been reviewed by a large number of international agencies and other governments for the purpose of assessing the way in which it operates and I do not believe that they have come up with any fundamental criticism of the organisation.

SPEECH.PARA: I have looked at the most thorough-going review of Australia's overseas aid program that has been tabled, the report of the Jackson Committee to Review Australia's Overseas Aid Program, and I went to the index to find out what it had to say about IFAD. The index indicated that I should look at page 54, paragraph 3.46. I looked in vain to find any criticism of IFAD on that page. The honourable member for Charlton grins. He knows that there cannot be any criticism, otherwise I would not be drawing upon this example. The only reference to IFAD in the index-and, of course, there is no criticism of it-relates to its links with the World Bank, a respectable organisation to which Australia contributes. The report gives factual information about what we are doing in this area. Thus, the Jackson Committee did not offer any criticism of IFAD.

What has brought the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade to this decision which was announced in the second reading speech? This decision was not part of the Bill and was certainly not explained in the explanatory memorandum, which suggests that he did not get advice from officers to this effect. The Minister discussed this particular matter on page 2 of his speech when he said:
The AIDAB concluded that the IFIs are, in general, effective institutions and that Australia's participation in their activities complements our own bilateral aid program.
The Minister went on-and I stress that these are his words:
I feel that, with regard to IFAD, a rigorous assessment needs to take account of views such as expressed by Professor Helen Hughes. In an article in the Canberra Times of 24 October . . .
Here we have the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade saying that he thought a decision needed to be taken on this matter as a result of what Helen Hughes had to say.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, he did not say that; he had advice from AIDAB.

—The honourable member should have a look at the words used. I read them very carefully. I do not mind being corrected, but the Minister used the words `I feel' in the third line of his printed speech. I am not paraphrasing and I am not putting words into his mouth. He then went on to outline the problems that Helen Hughes raised. He continued:

SPEECH.PARA: IFAD depends upon the World Bank and other agencies to do much of its project preparatory work; IFAD's projects are highly risky as a result of poor preparation and support by host countries; IFAD's examination system is not yet systematic; IFAD is weak on infrastructure and institutional support.
The Minister added:
She concludes, as I do, that it would be wise to cut aid to ineffectual organisations and retain sufficient interest in the more effective ones to be able to have something of a say in their running.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a sound decision.

—That is the judgment. Let us look at what Helen Hughes had to say. I am interested in the article that appeared in the Canberra Times because this lady is an expert. The article in the Canberra Times qualifies her as an expert. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: Professor Helen Hughes is with the Development Studies Centre at the Australian National University.

She makes out a case which pits IFAD and its interests against another much larger organisation-the World Bank-and its interests. I do not know whether this is correct-I may be wrong and if I am wrong I may be corrected and I will certainly apologise to Professor Hughes-but I understand that in the past she has had a long term association with the World Bank. This may qualify her to speak on this matter but it is not disclosed in the article. Unlike members of parliament who are required to declare an interest, Professor Hughes did not declare her interest, if it was an interest. I am quite prepared to stand corrected but I do not believe I am wrong. Professor Hughes also had something else to say which is of great interest to honourable members. She made anecdotal judgments about IFAD and certainly judgmental views of her own. She went on to say:
IFAD has not been in business long enough to have systematically evaluated its projects.

She offers that as a criticism because IFAD claims some success. I offer it as a criticism of what she has to say about the organisation when she claims there is evidence that it lacks success. We need to understand that this is a unique organisation. I hope honourable members will read some of the available material about IFAD's activities. One pamphlet says:

In eight years IFAD has financed 188 projects in some 88 of the poorest countries of the developing world. When fully implemented, these projects will boost food production by more than 22 million tonnes a year in terms of wheat equivalent. IFAD has committed approximately $2.2 billion from its own resources . . . Projects approved in 1985-
that was when this document was written-
will benefit 1.9 million small farmers and landless people in 17 countries.

I think that IFAD is a particularly important organisation for the area in which it is working. I could give honourable members detailed statements about the work that it is undertaking in Gambia, Somalia, Mali and Bangladesh, but time prevents me from doing so because I want to make some important points of comparison between IFAD and the World Bank particularly.

Honourable members really need to understand that IFAD is one of the smallest organisations. It operates with a staff of 180 people, including only 80 to 84 professionals. It is tiny. On the other hand, the World Bank has about 6,000 staff with 3,800 professionals. It regularly uses 6,000 consultants. As I mentioned, Australia has an interest because we rank fifth in the world as a source for the bank's consultancies. Is it any wonder that we say the World Bank might be a more appropriate body in this area? If I wanted to produce anecdotal material about the World Bank, largely of the same sort as Dr Hughes produced in her article, I would have to say this about its operations: its projects do not benefit the poor. I will check the list to see whether the honourable member for Charlton agreed with me in writing a letter recently to the President of the World Bank about initiative change in its own activities and funding programs. That letter was written collectively by 107 members of the House of Representatives and the Senate. We said:

. . . it concerns us that so little of the Bank's lending focuses on the need of the poorest people. The `Focus on Poverty' report (1986) states that currently only 29 per cent of Bank lending is directly poverty orientated. We suggest that the Bank establish the goal of targeting 60 per cent of its lending directly to projects whose primary purpose is to assist the poorest 40 per cent of people. The Bank's own evaluations have shown that its poverty orientated projects have often shown the highest rates of return.

I think we have targeted the wrong organisation. I think we have done so for the wrong reasons. I do not think we have made an evaluation of that article upon which the Minister clearly, by his own words, made his decision. The appropriate decision that should be taken by this Government is for it to make an announcement at the conclusion of this debate that this matter will be further reviewed, that the reports that are available will be made public so that we can all see them, and that the decision not to participate in the third replenishment discussions will be overturned by the Government; in other words, the Minister should be big enough to admit that in this matter he was wrong.

I suspect, if one were looking for underlying motives for this decision, that there were certain expectations that IFAD would be supported heavily not only by the developed countries but also by the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries and that the oil revenues would be recycled through it. I suspect that there is a disappointment at the fact that, with oil prices turning down, other countries are not putting in as much money and other governments are not as committed to this organisation as they were in the past and that, therefore, the Government believes it is appropriate for Australia to say, `We are not going to play a part at all'. If that is the reasoning involved, I regard it really as quite shabby.

If Australia has a part to play, it is in being in the organisation, setting an example in difficult times and making sure that people are aware of what we think its priorities ought to be. Those priorities are the priorities that we are suggesting that the World Bank ought to adopt, and which it does not adopt, and the priorities that IFAD has been targeted to reach. Perhaps the Government thinks IFAD is making mistakes in the way in which it is undertaking its task in working with countries that do not have an infrastructure to be able to help them as readily as more advanced countries. If we look at what Dr Hughes has said, the criticism she has offered is that there is not good support on the ground from those people preparing submissions and that Bangladesh should be as efficient as some of the more marginally advanced countries at preparing its approach.

I must say that my own view is that that is not a reasonable basis upon which this decision should have been taken. I implore the Government to look at this matter once more. I believe it can restore its credibility on this issue. I do not want to make a cheap political point in advancing this view. I hope that members of the Government will take the opportunity to read the material on IFAD that I am arranging to have placed in the Parliamentary Library so that they can better inform themselves about what it is doing and so that they will bring pressure to bear, if it is needed, upon their colleagues to change their minds about assisting in the negotiations for the third replenishment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden) has already given the reasons for his decision to withdraw from the International Fund for Agricultural Development after this current replenishment is over, and I am sure the Minister will reply at the end of this debate, so I will not comment further on the points raised by the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock).

SPEECH.PARA: The International Development Association Bill, the Asian Development Fund Bill and the International Fund for Agricultural Development Bill are important Bills which authorise Australia's contributions to three international aid agencies: the International Development Association, the Asian Development Fund and the International Fund for Agricultural Development. They are important Bills because they ensure Australia's contribution to the latest replenishment for three significant multilateral aid agencies at a time when aid to developing countries is vitally important.

In fact, most developing countries are in the midst of a desperately serious crisis. Living standards in African, Latin American and some Asian countries have fallen substantially during the 1980s. In fact, the International Monetary Fund (IMF) has estimated that the average standard of living in Africa and Latin America has fallen by 15 per cent in the last five years. Those countries have gone through a depression during the first half of the 1980s at least as severe as that which the industrialised countries experienced during the 1930s. Average incomes have fallen, malnutrition has increased, health services have deteriorated and unemployment has increased. Many hundreds of millions of people are worse off now than they were in 1980.

Most people in developed countries such as Australia are not aware of the seriousness of this problem except through the television pictures of emaciated mothers and children during the African drought. When made aware of the seriousness of this problem, the wider community has responded generously. The aid work of Bob Geldof and his campaigns has alerted innumerable people to this problem for the first time for some years. But the response of governments has been inadequate. Total aid from Western governments to developing countries during the past five to six years has been stagnant. The proportion of aid to gross national product has remained almost constant at about 0.35 per cent of GNP throughout the eighties. In this context, it is particularly disappointing that Australian aid has had to be substantially reduced. However, the total net financial flows to developing countries from all sources, public and private, have collapsed during the 1980s. There has been a massive decline in the level of private lending from industrialised to developing countries. In 1981, for example, total net resource flows to developing countries were $132 billion. By 1985 that had fallen to $79 billion. This has caused what is known as the debt crisis. What it means is that the massive borrowings of developing countries are not being offset by new lending, so they have a desperately serious debt servicing and repayment problem.

It is important to understand the debt crisis because it is a severe constraint on development in poor countries and it also intensifies global economic imbalances and the danger of a global recession. The total debt of developing countries in 1987 was $1,200 billion. This requires developing countries to pay an estimated $170 billion this year in interest payments. The best way of showing the dimension of that is to compare it with the level of their exports. In 1987, interest payments by developing countries will require 23 per cent of the total value of their exports. Some regions are in an even more serious situation. Africa, for example, will have to pay 33 per cent of its total export earnings in interest payments in 1987. Latin America has an even more serious problem because 55 per cent of the value of its exports should be used for debt servicing. This dramatically reduces the capacity of developing countries to import. It also means that those countries are not receiving, in a direct sense, the economic benefit of the value of their exports. Developing countries are being required to make net transfers to the industrialised world. The poor, developing countries are aiding the richer industrialised countries.

The problem is that the commercial banks in the industrialised world have virtually stopped lending since 1982, and official aid has not increased. There are major problems for both developing and industrialised countries from this situation. First, there is a systematic risk of default by developing countries, which could cause major global financial problems. Management of the debt could become impossible. Several Latin American countries have a moratorium on part or all of their interest payments at present, which is adding to the danger of financial collapse.

Second, interest payments and debt repayments of this magnitude from developing countries are oppressive, particularly at a time of depression. Most developing countries have experienced a loss of export earnings due to the collapse of commodity prices. Australians can readily identify with that problem because we have experienced a similar type of deterioration in our commodity prices. Our terms of trade deteriorated severely in 1985 and 1986 because of the collapse of commodity prices. This has led to Australia's large current account deficit and to growth in our overseas debt. This is the same kind of mechanism as has been operating for developing countries.

We are fortunate in that lending to Australia has not stopped and that private lenders have been and are still willing to continue to cover our current account deficit. Our living standards have fallen only marginally as a result of this situation, but in developing countries the fall has been much sharper because lending has stopped and stringent adjustment programs have been forced on to the debtor countries. They have been required to cut consumption so as to reduce imports, often at severe cost to the poor and middle income earners in those countries. There are costs also to industrialised countries because our exports to the developing world have had to be reduced because the developing countries can no longer afford to import as much.

The volume of world trade has been quite severely retarded by the debt crisis. The debt crisis is, in fact, one of the most serious constraints on renewed growth within developing countries. It is, therefore, essential that it be addressed. In a 10-minute speech it is possible only to outline some central elements of a strategy for coping with the debt crisis, but I would like to propose seven elements of such a strategy. The first will be agreed to by everyone: the major industrial countries, the group of seven, co-ordinate their national fiscal and monetary policies so as to reduce trade, exchange rates and interest rate imbalances and instability. There is hardly a commentator in any country who does not agree with that as a goal, although all would agree that it is very difficult to achieve and that so far the results of the attempts at co-ordination have not been adequate. However, there have been agreements like those at the Plaza Hotel in New York in September 1985, at the Louvre at the beginning of this year and at the Venice summit, all of which have contributed to the reduction of imbalances. That process must continue and, in the wake of the stock market collapse, the motivation for improved co-ordination is stronger.

Second, it is absolutely essential that the current account surplus countries, principally Japan and West Germany, adopt expansionary macroeconomic policies so as to increase their imports and stimulate world trade. Both Japan and West Germany have been somewhat more expansionary this year, but the extent of their current account surpluses remains enormous. They do have scope for increasing their growth rates. They can be the locomotive economies for the rest of the decade. It is essential that they accept the role that has been forced on them by their own success.

Third, wasteful military expenditure by both North Atlantic Treaty Organisation countries and Warsaw Pact countries should be reduced so as to reduce fiscal imbalance and allow interest rates to fall and increase resources for more economically and socially useful activity. It was striking to see when I was in New York three weeks ago that mainstream commentators in the United States are now urging both cuts in United States military expenditure and increases in taxes, policies which only a year ago were regarded as wildly radical. The stock exchange collapse has had some productive consequences.

Fourth, the International Monetary Fund should be encouraged to establish a new facility for phased partial debt forgiveness and rescheduling. An excellent proposal for a facility of this kind has been included in the United States trade Bill by Senator Sarbannes. That proposal has some political momentum in the most powerful country and should be explicitly supported by other countries such as Australia.

Fifth, it is very important that all Western countries increase their aid to the greatest extent possible, with the ultimate goal of reaching the target of 0.7 per cent of GNP. At present, those countries on average are achieving only half of that target. The justification for increasing aid at a time of severe depression in developing countries is overwhelming.

Sixth, a simple and direct way of increasing the resources available to developing countries would be through restarting the issue of special drawing rights (SDRs) by the International Monetary Fund. SDRs are a form of international money which is normally issued to countries in proportion to their contributions to the IMF. It would obviously be more helpful to developing countries if SDRs were issued directly to them, but such an issue would require an amendment to the articles of the IMF and that would take some time. So the first goal would be just to begin reissuing SDRs.

Seventh, the articles of the IMF could be changed at a global conference on reform of the international monetary system. Such a conference has been suggested and supported by many responsible commentators and by some government leaders as the end point in a process of international financial reform. For example, President Reagan mentioned the idea in his State of the Union Address at the beginning of last year. Preparation for such a conference would provide a focus for many of the required reforms.

It is fortunate that we have this opportunity to discuss briefly one of the most serious elements of the current global economic malaise, the depression in developing countries and the debt crisis, which is one of its causes. I support these Bills as small steps towards resolution of those problems but emphasise that much more will be required before a serious impact is made on those underlying problems.

TALK.START.PARA: —In addressing the International Development Association Bill, the Asian Development Fund Bill and the International Fund for Agricultural Development Bill, I remind the House that, in fact, these Bills deal with additional contributions, firstly, to the International Development Association; secondly, the Asian Development Bank for the purposes of the Asian Development Fund; and thirdly, the International Fund for Agricultural Development, although in the case of the International Fund for Agricultural Development the Minister has given notice of his unwillingness to participate in a further round of funding negotiations. SPEECH.PARA: These Bills afford a chance to draw away from some of the immediate domestic issues to consider foreign aid in a responsible way on both sides of the House. Australia has, by and large, had a reasonable record on the foreign aid issue and providing assistance. However, in recent years, funding levels-particularly when expressed as a percentage of gross national product-have fallen and speakers from both sides of the House, including the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore), have acknowledged this but, of course, that reflects a range of factors which time does not permit me to canvass tonight.

There also has to be greater emphasis in our broad approach to the economic aspects of our aid. Aid can create economic opportunities for Australia while also being beneficial to the recipient nation. I highlight to the House that, in the case of some projects, foreign aid can lead to great success in terms of a ratio of as much as 6 : 1; that is, for $1 given, $6 of commercial opportunity is created.

I confess that, when confronted at branch meetings in my electorate, which stretches from Mount Kosciusko to Balranald and Wentworth, by those who ask why we give so much as $1 of aid to overseas countries, given the very harsh economic conditions faced by many of my constituents, I have to discuss the issue in a very fair-minded way; and I tend to highlight one particular project-the Thailand lignite mining project near Lambok in the northern part of Thailand not far from Chang Mai. I am happy to inform the House that Australia has advanced $5m of hard-earned taxpayers' funds to that project, and that has led to $30m of commercial sales. All of those sales may not be complete at this stage, but Australia is in the process of achieving $30m of commercial activity for Australian firms, Australian consultants and Australian enterprises of one kind or another. Whilst clearly not all aid will generate such a ratio of economic benefit-in some cases there will be no direct economic benefit; it is humanitarian aid-in looking at the foreign aid question we ought to be mindful of our commercial interests as a nation in these difficult economic times.

If honourable members feel some hesitation in going down that path, I point out that quite often in some of the capitals of Asia Australia is regarded as almost the only nation that has taken so long to get around to looking after its commercial interests with its aid. Every other nation does so, often with a ruthlessness that is hard to swallow. I will not name specific European nations, but they give very little which is not qualified, multiplied and in every other way directly related to their immediate commercial interests. Therefore, Australia should not apologise for injecting this commercial dimension into its foreign aid efforts.

As a member not only of the National Party but the coalition Opposition, I take this opportunity to extend our support for that emphasis in Australia's aid projects. This year it has been estimated that Australia will provide in official development assistance $1 billion. That is an extraordinarily high figure and it is the first time it has reached that level. To be precise, Australia will provide $1,007,600,000.

While there are lies, damn lies and statistics, it is interesting to compare two countries of equal populations. Nepal and Australia both have populations of 16 million. The budget of the Government of Nepal, in Australian dollars, is $1 billion. The budget for Australia for foreign aid is $1 billion. But let me do that comparison again. The budget for Nepal for all programs and expenditure by its Government is $1 billion. The budget of the Australian Government for just one item-drugs for Australian people pursuant to the pharmaceutical benefits scheme and the very justified repatriation pharmaceutical benefits scheme-this year, for the first time, will be $1 billion. The Australian Government is spending the same amount of money on legitimate drugs for its people as the Nepal Government is spending in its total budget. Again, I point out that both countries have populations of 16 million people.

I know that there are many other factors which rule out authenticity in respect of that comparison, but it is a statistic I place before the House for its consideration as we look at these three pieces of foreign aid legislation.

The main point I make to the House in considering these measures is the need for Australia to interface more and more with its own region. Australia should relate to its own region in terms of the South Pacific and South East Asia and also South Asia. Not all honourable members would be aware that in addition to the Association of South East Asian Nations (ASEAN), to which we give considerable aid and diplomatic effort and with which we enjoy reasonable relations, there is also the increasingly important South Asian group of nations known as SAARC-the South Asian Association for Regional Co-operation-which held a summit meeting in Katmandu in Nepal in the first week of November. The nations constituting SAARC are Bangladesh, Bhutan, India, the Maldives, Nepal, Pakistan and Sri Lanka. Of course, some of those nations, such as India, have enormous populations and emerging middle classes, with the economic activity associated with middle classes, which create opportunities for Australian exports across the board. Yet because of a long period in the 1950s and 1960s when Australia decided to overlook the Indian opportunity and look more to Europe and subsequently America, we have not been in on the ground floor in India or to the extent we should have been in the South Asian region.

As Dr Andy Stoeckel said in his recent economic paper, unless we relate more to our region and build on those opportunities, not only in the ASEAN nations but also in the SAARC or South Asian nations, we will miss the bus as we move towards the last decade of this century. I notice in Budget Paper No. 4 in respect of Australia's overseas aid program that a table on page 23 lists 20 countries receiving aid from Australia. It mentions only two SAARC nations-Bangladesh and Pakistan. To be fair, the table also lists aid flows to five ASEAN nations-Malaysia, Indonesia, the Philippines, Thailand and Singapore. I do not for one moment suggest that Brunei should be listed in that table; perhaps it should be giving us aid.

The Parliament and the Government must become more conscious of the need for Australia to relate to the South Pacific; to relate to the ASEAN nations and to Papua New Guinea. But we must also relate to the South Asian nations and the economic opportunities offered by them and their problems by assisting them to improve their standards of living and doing it in such a way, where opportunities permit, as to provide mutual economic benefit.

Finally, I take this opportunity to pay a tribute to many Australians who are up front in terms of our aid effort and who are located in isolated circumstances, often with no access to what we would regard as even primitive medical assistance. Yet they put themselves and their families at risk in climates which are extremely uncomfortable for the average Australian. They do that as part of their dedicated work pursuant to a number of categories. I refer, firstly, to Australian aid workers directly working as consultants and in other capacities on projects-for example, on the Tung Kula Roghai project near Roit, which happens to be managed by McGowan International Pty Ltd with headquarters in my electorate in Albury. I have seen the excellent work being done under that project in a very poor part of Thailand. Its work includes connecting water-the first ever water supplies in many cases-to villages where previously people had to walk five kilometres or more to drag water on their backs back to their villages. The conditions there and in many of these overseas locations are harsh. I pay tribute to the dedication of those Australian aid workers involved in those projects.

There is also another category of volunteers who are members of non-government agencies, such as United Missions in Nepal and Australian Volunteers Abroad, who are not paid anywhere near full remuneration because it is part of their effort to make the voluntary agency funds go as far as possible. They are very dedicated people and they are not being remunerated even at a commercial level. I take this opportunity to pay tribute to them.

Finally, I also pay tribute to the officers of the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau who work in these countries, albeit as a rule from the safety of their embassies. I pay tribute to the dedication of many of the embassy staff. It is not as easy as honourable members might think when we consider the localities of some of these smaller embassies in countries such as Burma, Laos and Nepal.

In recent times, there have been some terrible accidents, including the crash of a relatively new Fokker aircraft in Burma in which the parents of one of the embassy workers at Rangoon were travelling and, of course, killed. One hesitates to mention the aviation safety aspect, but that is one of the many pressures faced by people in these locations. They also include the lack of sophisticated, comprehensive medical and other back-up resources which we take for granted here in Canberra, Albury and even some of the smaller towns in my electorate. For example, in Nepal many people have to walk for days to get to a major town because there are no roads. There is limited access to a handful of helicopters in the country, even if weather conditions would permit flying. I pay tribute to all Australians in isolated overseas locations who confront many difficulties. I also pay tribute to the embassies, small and large, in countries such as Thailand, India-including our High Commission in Bhutan-Indonesia, and the like. I hope that they will continue to carry forward our interests in a proper and efficient way.

As we provide additional allocations of taxpayers' money to the three agencies involved in this legislation, I implore the Government to carry out the necessary monitoring to ensure that we are getting value for the dollars expended, that mutual economic benefits will be taken into account when assessing and planning future aid, especially aid of a bilateral nature, and that effort is made to monitor adequately the multilateral agencies which too often go unmonitored because of their very structure.

TALK.START.PARA: —The poorest countries are in need of development assistance from those wealthier, self-sufficient countries that are in a position to offer financial support. That is the concept right at the basis of the International Development Association Bill, the Asian Development Fund Bill and the International Fund for Agricultural Development Bill. SPEECH.PARA: As the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden) has said to this House, organisations such as those being discussed in the Bills today depend on developed donor countries such as us to provide most of the resources to carry on their work. It is also our responsibility to ensure that the funds we allocate to needy countries are distributed most efficiently and, therefore, further reviews of these international financial institutions are justified. While this Government may gradually phase out its funding of some international financial institutions, it will certainly not discontinue funding to needy countries but will redirect funds to ensure maximum benefit to the poorest countries.

I will comment briefly on the three Bills. Australia has been a member of the International Development Association (IDA) since its inception in 1960. IDA is the concessional lending arm of the World Bank which directs resources to the world's poorest countries. There have been seven previous replenishments to IDA and Australia has contributed each time. The purpose of the International Development Association Bill is to contribute to the eighth replenishment of IDA. IDA8 is designed to cover concessional lending operations over the three fiscal years 1988-90. Total basic replenishment of IDA8 from all countries, plus special additional contributions, brings the total level of resources available to cover IDA's lending operations for these three years to $US12.4 billion. Australia has pledged a share of 1.98 per cent of the basic replenishment, maintaining our share in the previous replenishment-IDA7.

Our current economic circumstances have prevented us from increasing our relative share of IDA. I join honourable members on both sides of this House in looking forward to the time when we can increase our share of aid in order to develop nations generally. In essence, this legislation pledges a maximum of $335m for the eighth replenishment of IDA over the period 1987-88 to 1989-90.

I turn to the International Fund for Agricultural Development Bill 1987. Australia has been a member of the International Fund for Agricultural Development since it was established in 1977 and we participated in its first replenishment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to bring to the House a matter which affects my electorate of Lowe. It relates to the storage of explosives in barges moored around Spectacle Island off the foreshores of Drummoyne. The Department of Defence has clearly stated that there is a risk of these explosives actually exploding. Accordingly, it has drawn up a blast zone. This blast zone includes a fair amount of the residences in Drummoyne, Cockatoo Island, Spectacle Island, Snapper Island, the shopping centre at Birkenhead Point, part of Hunters Hill and Drummoyne Sailing Club. The residents in that area, I am sure, will receive small comfort when they learn that they are not to be blown to smithereens but will only be incinerated in this blast zone.

SPEECH.PARA: On the basis of this blast zone the Department has evicted the sea cadets from Snapper Island. The sea cadets, I might mention, have been there for 40 years or so. They have actually reclaimed the land from what it was originally, which was a few rocks. They have built several buildings and they have a very impressive museum there.

The next stage, I understand, is that the Department is planning to stop sailing races in the area. This, of course, will destroy the Drummoyne Sailing Club. This is planned on the pretext, of course, that these explosives might blow up.

Obviously, if there is a risk to the sea cadets, to be consistent this Government should evacuate Drummoyne, close Birkenhead Point shopping centre, close the sailing club, close Cockatoo Island, as well as blockading the river between Drummoyne and Hunters Hill. That is obviously completely ridiculous.

The risks are not clear. They probably are very small. But there is, of course, a risk from vandals. The barges which contain the explosives are covered merely with wood and canvas, as far as we can tell, and, of course, they are a prime terrorist target.

There really can be no justification whatsoever for storing explosives in the heart of Sydney. No risk, however small that risk might be, is acceptable to the people of Drummoyne. I might also point out that there is a bonus in removing the explosives from the area and that concerns Spectacle Island itself. On Spectacle Island there are six buildings which were built in 1865. Indeed, there are 30 which were built before the turn of the century. There is a superb museum of naval relics and, with a little work, this island could be made into a delightful haven for the people of Sydney-a much more worthwhile bicentennial gift, I might add, than the enormous Darling Harbour complex. I therefore appeal to the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) to move the explosives out of the area, to use some common sense and justice, to restore the sea cadets to Snapper Island and, as a bicentennial gift, to give Spectacle Island back to the people of Sydney to enjoy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts, I was most pleased to read the Australian Science Magazine, issue 3, 1987, published by the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority, on current research into the plague outbreaks of the crown-of-thorns starfish. The adult crown-of-thorns starfish is not a very attractive creature. It can measure up to 700 millimetres from one arm tip to an opposite arm tip. It often has 23 arms and is covered by thousands of spines, with those on its upper surface reaching a length of between three centimetres and five centimetres. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: Not only are these spines extremely sharp in having three raised cutting edges on the tip, but they also are known to produce a toxic reaction, often severe, in humans.

It is not known how the chemicals are respons- ible-perhaps several other chemicals also are responsible-for causing allergic responses. The range of reactions recorded to date in patients who have been wounded by this starfish include nausea, vomiting and extensive swelling of tissues. The magazine states that care must be taken at all times when handling or undertaking activities near this animal.

Two plague outbreaks involving millions of starfish have broken out on the Great Barrier Reef between 1962 and 1977 and between 1979 and 1986. A 1985-86 survey has indicated that 28 per cent of the reefs investigated were either experiencing or had experienced an outbreak. The effect on those reefs varied from slight to very severe, but the outbreaks were largely confined to the central third of the Great Barrier Reef and began in reefs off the coast of Cairns.

The Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation of the previous Parliament in its November 1985 report entitled Protection of the Great Barrier Reef recommended that the Commonwealth Government continue to provide funding for studies into the crown-of-thorns starfish. As Chairman of the Committee I was most pleased when the recommendations were taken up by the Government. I congratulate the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority and the scientists involved on their report in the magazine. I found it most interesting and informative reading. I recommend it to all honourable members of this House. The report makes it clear that there have been a number of misconceptions about the crown-of-thorns starfish outbreaks. It is not true that the entire Great Barrier Reef is in danger. On the contrary, the vulner- able but faster growing coral will regenerate within five to 15 years. Nor can it be proven that pollution from fishing is responsible for the outbreaks. Whilst the scientists still view the crown-of-thorns issue as controversial, research is beginning to provide some clues to the reason for the plagues or infestations.

There is a considerable lack of information about the early life cycle of the starfish in the first 12 months of its life, from the larval to the juvenile stage. Many scientists believe that the answer to the sudden appearance of thousands or millions of adult crown-of-thorns starfish on a coral reef will be found by studying the juveniles and particularly the larvae. Biological control involving studies of diseases or the causes of starvation which can kill the majority of starfish in their early life may be possible. As a mature female may produce many millions of eggs per year, most scientists believe that population control must occur at the larval stage.

Whilst the manual eradication of adult starfish is possible and has been successful on a very small scale, it is very expensive and inefficient on a large scale. Some scientists theorise that the plague outbreaks of the starfish are a natural occurrence. One way to test this theory is to undertake geological studies of the coral reefs. A great amount of work has been done. It is possible that the outbreaks may be the result of a number of factors which, collectively, can trigger the huge population increase which can be so devastating. As I said before, one thing that is clear from the report is that continuing research is absolutely essential if we are to find the answer to the infestations. I congratulate all the scientists involved in the valuable work they are undertaking in this most important project.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I have just returned from attending the display of the replica of the Southern Cross at the Canberra Airport. SPEECH.PARA: I would like to congratulate the sponsors of these trips around Australia for the Bicentenary, because the profits are going to go to the Royal Flying Doctor Service. The Royal Flying Doctor Service is a unique service, with the pedal radio and with the old Austers, et cetera, that used to be flown in the early days. There is a Flying Doctor base at Charleville, in my electorate, which services a very large area in the Channel Country out to the Simpson Desert and to Birdsville. Many of those communities have functions throughout the year that raise funds for the Royal Flying Doctor Service. Unfortunately, they have a continuing battle to keep going because of funding problems. The government of the day does give some funds to this very important service, because without it operating throughout the Outback many people would lose their lives. These people are very dedicated to the health of the people who live not only in outback Queensland, including my electorate, but in many other electorates throughout Australia. Bases are established in Broken Hill, Cairns, Cloncurry, Mount Isa and other parts of Australia. The honourable member for Kennedy (Mr Katter) is a great supporter of the Royal Flying Doctor Service. I would like to read into the Hansard the record of Smithy's flights, along with Captain Taylor and others. In June 1927 he flew around Australia in 10 days and 5 1/2 hours, and of course, at that time it was a record. In June 1928 he undertook the first flight across the Pacific-actual flying time 83 hours. In August 1928 he made the first non-stop flight across Australia, from Melbourne to Perth. In September 1928 the Southern Cross made the first flight across the Tasman Sea. In October 1928 he made the return flight, from New Zealand to Australia. In July 1929 he flew from Australia to London in 12 days and 18 hours. In June 1930 Smithy continued the journey, making the first highly successful flight across the Atlantic Ocean in an east-west direction. In July 1930 Smithy flew the Southern Cross from New York to San Francisco, and then across the Pacific, making him the first man to circumnavigate the globe in the same plane. In October 1930, 5 1/2 days were cut off Bert Hinkler's London to Australia record. In December 1931 he undertook the first Australian airmail flight to England. In October 1933 Smithy established a solo flight record of seven days, 4 hours and 44 minutes. In March 1934 Smithy flew over the towering Southern Alps of New Zealand, and so the record goes on. Smithy, of course, was one of the most famous aviators that Australia has produced. Unfortunately for him, in October 1935, in attempting to fly from England to Australia, he ended his flying career in death off the coast of Burma.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight is probably the last occasion this year on which I will get a chance to speak about the new voluntary contracts and work agreements legislation which was implemented recently by the Bjelke-Petersen, until today, Government. It is an issue to which I alluded in my maiden speech and I raise it again for two reasons. Firstly, it is a source of major concern to working people in my home State of Queensland where the National Party State Government has introduced this legislation. Secondly, it is a proposal which is pushed by the New Right in this country and, as such, it is something which a future conservative Federal government could introduce. Although the likelihood of a conservative government in the near future is very slim, even the slightest possibility of work contracts should concern all working men and women in Australia and, in fact, employers.

SPEECH.PARA: The concept of work contracts is based on the notion of flexibility in the work place. In fact, the Queensland Minister responsible for industrial relations, Vince Lester-he was Minister until today-has made quite a point of the benefits of a more flexible industrial relations system. However, the problem is that the Minister uses the word `flexible' interchangeably with the words `union free'. The National Party State Government's protestations about flexibility can be seen to be very selectively applied and ideologically based. After all, there is no evidence of the State Government's commitment to the notion of flexibility in its attitude towards rural production and the market controls it places on such production through its myriad of marketing boards. No, only when it comes to the work force and to wages and conditions does the National Party Government in Queensland make reference to flexibility. Of course, when one thinks of the notion of flexibility, one would imagine that it implies that flexibility would allow increases in worker's wages and conditions. Minister Lester often states that that is the case.

The problem is that under current award arrangements, over-award payments or provision of conditions is tolerated. The advantage in an individual contract arrangement such as it proposed is all one-sided. The only flexibility which it would provide, which is not already inherent in the present system, is that which would allow employers to decrease wages and conditions. That lower wages and working conditions are on the Queensland Government's agenda can be shown to be the case by the fact that it persistently parrots off the old argument that lower wages will allow more jobs to be created. That is not the case, as many studies have shown. For example, Professor Hancock, in a paper presented in January this year, said that wage differences have very little to do with the level of employment. In addition, the argument about wage rates assumes that wages is the only factor which hinders profit and, therefore, the only factor which limits industry's ability to employ. That is clearly an oversimplification.

The other factor in this debate which employers should, and I believe do, acknowledge is the great wage restraint which the arbitration system under the accord has delivered. The Hawke Labor Government has shown that the arbitration system is capable of achieving restraint through the exercise of a responsible and acceptable wages policy. The voluntary contracts proposal ignores the real fact that there are many aspects of working conditions and working life which are common to all workers. Superannuation agreements, safety issues and workers compensation are but a few examples of issues which are far more efficiently negotiated with a representative body, such as a trade union, rather than with individuals. Industrial conflict is another aspect of the work place which is not catered for in the proposed contract legislation. Conflict in the work place cannot be described as either good or bad. It is a fact of industrial life that disagreements between employees and employers will exist. What the arbitration system does to very good effect is institutionalise conflict resolution so that the very debilitating consequences of industrial confrontation are, in most cases, avoided.

It is interesting to note that, despite the ramblings of the Queensland Minister that only benefits will flow from the proposal, the National Party State Government has recently decided, after going away and having a bit of a think about the legislation, that it will exempt its entire work force from its provisions. The State Government is too gutless to have the legislation, which it says will bring about a better system of industrial relations, cover its own workers such as teachers, police and other public servants. In conclusion, the current centralised system of awards and arbitration has, through the Hawke years, shown that flexibility can be achieved within existing structures without affecting the very real benefits of the tried and true arbitration process. The Queensland Government needs to be condemned for the introduction of the legislation some one or two weeks ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a few comments about the shocking state of the city of Canberra. I have admired this city, although I do not think that I would like to live here for a long time. Canberra is too structured and too planned for my tastes. However, I have been amazed and appalled at what has happened to this city in the last six months. The atrocious bureaucracy that overrules the wishes of people in having half the beautiful picturesque spots around the city ripped up for asphalt carparks is appalling. There has been no planning and no thought. All the mistakes of capital cities around Australia are being made again here in Canberra.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no city in Australia where office buildings would be allowed to be built without any parking facilities. There is not a council in Melbourne or Sydney that would be allowed to do what has been done in the centre of Canberra. High block after high block has gone up without any provision for car parking for office staff or for those who may wish to visit those offices. These are drastic, stupid and unnecessary mistakes.

The mistakes made in this city were obvious in capital cities around Australia 20 or 30 years ago. That shows how far behind the times Canberra planners are. There is no representation process for the citizens of this city, and the Labor Government is to be blamed for that. Citizens who wish to vent their feelings have to call protest meetings. They have no elected representatives to take forward their views to government at any level. I do not know what has happened to the federally elected members of this city. Members of the Australian Labor Party representing this area have been silent on the issue. The only person who is constantly complaining about the ruination of Canberra and Canberra city area is Senator Reid.

The mistakes made in Civic and on City Hill are abysmal and appalling. The planners who have been responsible seem to think that they have a capacity to override commonsense statements. When I have arrived at Parliament House early, before the House commences, I have heard them say on the radio that they have a right to make these decisions and that Canberra residents must wear them. The citizens have no right of protest, no right to disagree with what is happening, or to require more sensible planning. That City Hill has been destroyed in the way it has been, with parks and gardens ripped up to be replaced by asphalt, is appalling.

Citizens of Canberra who want to understand what is in store for them should look at the City of Parramatta. The Minister with responsibilities for this city was an alderman on that council for many years. If the people of Canberra want to know what can be done to ruin a city they should visit Parramatta. For many years every decision in that city was made on an ad hoc basis. That city has gradually choked to death. I am concerned that the City of Parramatta will finish up as the type of city which it is only possible to enter by public transport, where shopping facilities are so limited that people do not go there. TALKER.NAME: Mr HOLDING
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment Services and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I take part in this debate as Minister on duty, but also as Minister with specific responsibilities for the operation of the Commonwealth Employment Service (CES) to answer some of the remarks made by the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew). I wish to deal with the suggestion that an organisation such as Bridging The Gap could not do worse if it took over some of the responsibilities of the CES. I would not want to discourage Bridging The Gap or any voluntary organisation which can play a useful role in the employment market. Many of the Government's training programs are based upon the involvement of many people in the community who are prepared to use existing community resources and the voluntary efforts of community organisations to give adequate training and skills to young people trying to enter the work force.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important to see the role and responsibility of the CES throughout Australia in a much broader context than that which was put to the honourable member for Wakefield by one of his constituents. Last year the CES found about 700,000 jobs for those seeking to enter the work force. The problem that faces the CES is that it is really servicing two clients: the employers and those who are desirous of entering the work force. It is often a complicated and difficult task to match them.

Apart from that, the CES is playing an increasingly important role in advising young people. We are creating youth access centres in many CES offices. Basically their function is to advise young people looking for advice in respect of jobs and careers as to the best course they could follow. In many cases they will advise young people to stay at school, to seek further education. The youth access centres will provide general information to young people as to the best courses to follow in either a technical and further education college or a high school to fulfil their long term employment objectives. Whilst that advice is tremendously important, it cannot be equated with job statistics.

It would perhaps assist the honourable member for Wakefield if I informed him that only last week I had the privilege of opening a new CES office, known as the Town Hall office, in the inner heart of Sydney. That office will face the problem of having to find 6,000 jobs in the next 12 months for people seeking work as a result of the Darling Harbour developments. There is no way in which a voluntary organisation, no matter how well motivated the people running it might be, can fulfil that sort of employment objective. Many large hotels and others involved in the hospitality industry have no hesitation in using the facilities of the CES. It is a very considerable saving to an employer if he can fill positions through the CES. Many large employers in the hotel industry-those who build the big, luxury, four-star hotels-do not hesitate to say to the CES, `We need to fill 1,500 or more jobs and we would like to have them filled in three or four weeks, if you can do it'. The CES is continually meeting that sort of challenge right around Australia, including our rural areas. I visited CES offices in rural Victoria and New South Wales recently. The managers of those offices are very much part of their local community and provide a continuous, ongoing service to large and small employers in regional centres in a way which saves those employers large sums of money. If one is an employer, particularly if one is running a small business, it is important to be able to minimise the cost of one's operation.

The CES plays a major role. It is fulfilling its objectives. The kind of ill-founded criticism that is often made of the CES is made without justification or real thought. The developments that are taking place are important, but that does not belittle the role of voluntary organisations.
